Mine is black, and I love how it feels like it's coated in fine-grit sandpaper.  It looks slick without being shiny and has a great grip compared to other point-and-shoots where you are left gripping with four fingers.  The texture is really an added bonus to this camera; they did it right.  I've had people pick it up and say it feels like it's made of 'cheap plastic,' but I think it's because of the small size and light weight, combined with the foreign feel of the camera, itself.  I've never felt a piece of electronic equipment made to feel like sandpaper before.  I love it.Being small, it still has a sizable screen, and I love the 24mm lens; I compared it, side-by-side, to my Canon SD1200IS, and the depth is really amazing.  The field of view is significantly closer to the actual viewpoint (your eyes have a serious wide-angle on them).  At the same time, the zoom gives it the capability to bring it closer, as long as you don't push it too far - pushing beyond the 5x point (it will digitally enhance up to 20x) results in pretty noisy images.  The video is fantastic, other than the Full HD; the camera just doesn't have the capability to record it smoothly enough.  720p is perfectly smooth but if you move the camera at all in 1080p, the video will be distractingly choppy.  But, in Auto mode, within the standard zoom range, in anything other than 1080p, this camera is smarter than I am.  There is almost no reason to leave Auto mode, which was not the case with my SD1200IS (I was never in Auto on that camera) - you can use this camera touching only two buttons: the shutter and the video button.  However, there is a flaw to this camera...The Program mode is an absolute nightmare.  This marks the first time I have ever had to read a user manual for a camera, in 25 years of using pocket cameras.  They really shouldn't be this hard to figure out.  If you want to do anything other than point, shoot, and adjust ISO/lighting/resolution, you'd better get ready to learn an entirely new interface.  It's like an electronic maze.  Changing shooting modes (other than the basic macro/landscape) or changing video (like the slow motion and '4 second video capture' whenever you take a picture) is truly so challenging that it took me hours to get it all right and days before I could do it without checking the manual.  And I'm a techno junkie.  So, that's a place where Canon really dropped the ball.  The included hard-copy manual is pathetic but the one on the included CD is fantastic, with a hotlinked TOC - why they couldn't make the camera as user-friendly as their manual, I do not know.Overall, you're not going to do better than this camera, for less than $200.  It's a year old and it still beats 2012 cameras that are priced at $300.  Bottom line is this: if you like taking pictures/video enough so that your smartphone makes you angry, this is the perfect camera for you, as long as you never take it out of Auto."
20120531"
column328:
This camera greatly exceeded my expectations. The picture quality is excellent for such a small device. Obviously, anyone considering buying this shouldn't expect SLR quality, but for the price, it's an excellent value. The only quip I have with it is that the auto/program mode switch isn't attached very well and is loose. It hasn't fallen out yet, but it rattles inside the hole it's placed it. It might just be a defect, but it's certainly not worth returning over as the camera still functions 100% normal."
20120531"
column331:
this camera is great.  Long battery, amazing screen and huge value for the money.  Very happy with product and as always with cannon."
20120531"
column334:
this camera is  perfect for me, easy to use and the price is reasonable, a steal! I will definately recommend this to my friends."
20120530"
column336: For price, size and functionality its a great Camera
column337:
My wife and I were looking for a smaller point and shoot camera to replace our old one, saw this one in Best Buy and looked into it for a while.  It is small and compact, light and looks good.  It has a rough kind of outside cover which offers a better grip.  It has a ton of different functions and picture settings that it can do.  You have to go into the menu a little bit and it isn't as accessible to change like on other cameras, but not a problem at all.  It takes very clear pictures and they show well on the computer.  I didn't like that you have to have a battery included with it (I liked my old camera I would just charge at my computer) but this camera does come with a port to re-charge the battery.  I got the package which included the camera + a case + a 4g memory card + an extra battery all for $170.00, the camera itself was $129.00, down from $229.00 a short while ago.  I know its been out for a year, but this camera for the price offers a great deal of power, especially for its small sleek size.  Only problem I have noticed so far is that the flash is in a bad spot and its easy to cover up with your finger when taking a picture.  Will just need to adjust how I hold it so I don't see it as a big problem."
20120528"
column340:
Me and my mom went on a trip to New Zealand and I wanted to make sure that I took a lot of pictures, and I sure did. This is a great camera, the picture quality was shocking, this thing can take some really beautiful shots. I have one set as my wallpaper on my 24 inch mac and the detail and the richness of the colors is very impressive for such a small camera( or any camera I have owned). I had it in my pocket the whole time, its smaller then my wallet so it's very portable. I was turning it on and off the constantly as photo opportunities kept coming up and never had a problem with the battery life ( we weren't able to charge it that much because of the electric inputs they used there and didn't have the right converter ). It also has alot of features and effects, a few of I used, they were kind of cool but I can't say they were a game changer, your basic stuff, the zoom never let me down on capturing the things I was unable to reach. Over all, if your looking for a compact light camera that will not fail you on quality this is your camera, and for the price it's a no brainer."
20120527"
column342: Love the camera and the HD video...
column343:
I really can't say enough about this camera - the quality is great, especially for the price. In addition, the HD video it takes is amazing. Highly recommend."
20120527"
column345: You've got to pay more if you wish to video indoors at low light
column346:
A fine camera, but a bit disappointed when using it to film orchestra performances indoors at low light levels.  Other that that a good product, though if I could stand to take a larger camera along with the family on trips, I'd own a larger, better camera instead.  Size matters, and in this particular case, the smaller the better."
20120112"
column349:
Let me start off by saying I have a strong loyalty to this brand and usually don't write bad reviews.That being said, I am very unhappy with the picture quality from this camera.  I had a Fujifilm camera that was only 2 megapixels that produced sharper clearer pictures.Lest some people think its not the camera but the user, let me say I know this is a point and shoot camera - that's all I use it for.  I don't adjust the settings too much or screw around - I just use it for snapshots.  However, it simply doesn't meet my expectations. It is just a dissapointment.For simple snapshots I would recommend another product."
20120112"
column352:
I did a lot of research before deciding on this camera and it appears that all that work paid off. This camera is everything I was looking for: super compact, takes 12MP photos and 1080p video, easy to use, rechargeable battery, long battery life, fast start-up, fast picture to picture time, large rear screen, and quality construction. I have been blown away by how long the battery lasts compared to my old Nikon Coolpix. One of my favorite features is the video button on the rear of the camera -- no need to go searching through menus on the screen or spinning a dial to select movie mode. I highly recommend this camera to anyone looking for the above features at a great price."
20120112"
column354: I LOVE The Canon PowerShot Elph 300 HS!
column355:
I give this camera 5 stars! Woot! This camera is my first-ever snap and shot camera. I watch so many things on YouTube and read so many reviews on this one camera and the Elph 100. I bought this to replace my old pocket camera that I got in 2009, which was the Vado HD 1st 8gb. I love that pocket camera, too. I bought this on the 4th of this month, so I've been using it everyday. I love the pictures and videos. It's so different from my old pocket camera, which I sold my old camera for extra money to buy the Elph 300. I'm super super impressed on the video quality. I will be posting videos on my production site, which is swatshow.blogspot.com. I made 3 videos with my cousins and sisters with my old pocket cam. I think the Elph 300 will help a lot with filming short films and other videos on that blog site.PROS:-Great in low light-Super wide lens-Auto Focus is very impressive-FULL HD with the options to lower the resolution to 720p, 480p, and 320p-Image stabilization is very noticeable-Macro video and pics are excellent, but not perfect-So much detail in the pics and videos-Super portable and pocket sized-Many different effects such as slow-mo, toy camera, and miniature mode-Battery life is great-Feels pro in the hand (Built well...)-Easy to learn and use-Ability to trim videos in edit mode and crop pics-Great zoom-Super fast start-up and shutdown-Stereo audio in video recordingCONS:-FULL HD, 1080p, is 24fps instead of 30fps, which causes minor choppy video-Weak flash that can get blocked by part of the lens area-Slow zoom during video-Video file sizes are too big-Auto-Focus (AF) can be quite laggy and jerky at moments-Smaller screen size than the previous, Elph 100 HS-You need a good memory card to help speed the camera up when taking full HD vids-Poster effect is not enthusiastic enough-No internal memory-No in camera battery charges (Need external charger to charge)-Did not come with a mini HDMI to HDMI cable-Outdoor wind can be super annoying when taking videos... sooooo loud...-It looks sturdy, but it has a feel that makes me feel like it'll get super destroyed if I drop it at least onceI bought this camera to shoot videos with my cast and myself for vlogs and films. I've always wanted a point and shoot camera that is simple to use. Memories is the main reason why I bought this camera. Pictures and videos that are taken now are going to be memories for when I get into college, which I'm a senior this school year. I thought of taking the camera to the DR with me, but I just have a fear of having it getting stolen or broken. I'm an official Canon fan. ;)Hope you liked this review.... I'll keep you updated!---Bugbite250 (Timmy)---"
20120111"
column358:
I purchased this as a gift for me fiancée.  I did extensive research on the different options and I could not find a better camera for the money.  We are not professional photographers so we were looking to find a good camera under $200.  This camera has definitely fit the bill.  I know some have had problems with the lense and I will update if I experience the same."
20120111"
column360: Great buy! Notes on the 300 vs. 500
column361:
I purchased this camera a couple of months ago and have been very satisfied with the results. After previously owning the Canon PowerShot SD750 and using it consistently for 4 years, I decided to upgrade to another Canon and I have not been disappointed. The 5X optical zoom is great, and the wide angle lens has been a huge help for shooting from a closer distance and still being able to capture the scene that I want. The start-up time is very quick, which is great for capturing those spur-of-the-moment candid shots/videos you always wished you could catch.I debated between the 300 HS and the 500 HS for a while but ended up choosing the 300 for a few reasons. In terms of actual hardware differences related to camera function (as opposed to just the interface), the only advantage of the 500 HS is that it has a larger aperture, meaning it can capture more light. Besides that, the differences are that the 500 HS has a larger, higher-resolution screen and uses touch-screen technology, which lessens the number of physical buttons needed. However, I figured that the larger screen might drain the battery more quickly, and I actually prefer physical buttons since in my opinion, they are more reliable than a touch screen. In addition, the 300 HS is smaller, lighter, thinner, cheaper, and has a faster shutter speed.Perhaps the only minor complaint I would comment on is that the camera might be a little too small for my hands. However, I would say that my hands are larger than average so I would imagine that most people would not find this to be an issue. In addition, the camera comes with a strap, so if you make it a habit to put the strap around your wrist when you're shooting (which you should do regardless), you won't have any problems."
20120111"
column364:
After extensive searching for a low-priced point and shoot, I narrowed my search down to the Canon ELPH. I've had them in the past and they're great to use. You should go check out SnapSort (.com) and do a side-by-side comparison of this camera and the newer version, the 310HS. You should stick with this camera for the price, considering the newer model is actually lacking features. Go check out what the experts have to say. You won't be disappointed!"
20120110"
column367:
i bought it last week since it had mostly great reviews. right after i bought it for close to 200 dollars i noticed that amazon lowered the price to 140 bucks. i called but they werent much help. when u check out the reviews u really get ur hopes up u really think that ur gonna get excellent pics.  first of all the camera doesn't work unless u buy the sd card. second i took a few shots at home with the flash on shot a video and reviewed it online to see how well was my much anticipated resolution.  i quickly learned that the resolution is ok but nothing that wowed me. i zoomed the pics to see how well it retained its resolution but i noticed it became pixelated.  then i played the video to see how well it looked...i gotta say it looked ok not great...i think that this camera probably throws some excellent pics on places with lots of light or sunny environments....the pics look ok with some in the good range, but i wouldn't vote it a 5 or 4 stars like many people do so here.  i think its a great camera and would say excellent if it costs under 140 bucks....well these r my initial complaints...hope it helps...if u r new into digital cams and r looking for a decent camera i would recomm it but don't pay more than 140 bucks....if u have owned digital cameras and ur searching for something nice and with really amazing high resolution pics then i would research other cameras cuz i don't think u would be wow by this camera....good luck and god bless"
20120110"
column370:
Classy looking and feeling.  Great to put in pocket and forget about.  Video is superb and pictures surprisingly good.  5x zoom is enough.  24 at wide end is excellent.  Fast.  Battery better than expected.  Definitely recommended."
20120110"
column372: Easy to use!  great little point 'n' shoot!
column373:
This camera is super stylish and easy to use.  You literally open the box, put the battery in, and start shooting amazing pictures that are vibrant and clear!  The camera is thin so it fits in your pocket or purse - I like putting on the strap right away so that i don't accidentally drop it.I've had great success with Canons and I haven't had any reason to switch!  If you're on the fence, you don't have to worry about getting a poor quality product!"
20120110"
column376:
Bought it as a gift for my Father, he loves it, he is amazed by the quality of shots for the little camera. He has a DSLR that takes amazing shots but he would rather use this since the pictures are almost as good for your everyday shows and its so compact / light!"
20120110"
column378: I've had really good luck with Canon
column379:
This is my 3rd Canon (compact) camera. I've had good luck in keeping them functional for years on end. I make an effort to keep them safe from moisture, temperature extremes and hard knocks (invest in a nice case, it's a must).I don't recall ever having any functional problems - outside the protective shutter on the lens not fully opening without some encouragement. A problem that can be expected for an older camera that's been everywhere with me.What I've found that really separates these types of cameras is how intuitive and functional the many options are. Getting around the camera's menu options takes lots of practice, and I've found other brands to be very difficult to learn. I've never HAD to open the Canon user manual, with others I've been forced to. If you're not someone that has been shooting for years you really should peruse the manual and get a grasp on what your options are. If you're old enough to have shot actual film, these cameras simply blow away your imagination.This model offers a 'tilt-shift' shooting option (referred to as 'miniature') and fish-eye lens option. Both very useful and fun to make your images stand out.I always tell people the most critical component to getting a good pictures is to first, have a camera with you. If you own a large SLR with extra lenses you'll get some great pictures no doubt, but are you going to bring that camping or vacationing? Maybe, but it won't be with you all the time. This camera (with case) takes up a little more space than a smartphone. It can be with you at all times.The video is another reason I upgraded; bigger and sharper than my previous model (SD 1100). Video can capture so much that a still-shot can't.My only real complaint is that getting to the 'photo stitch' option seems to get harder and harder with every model. I should find that manual."
20120109"
column382:
Very happy with this camera. Small, capable, controls are not too complicated. Being able to shoot video has turned out to be a really fun addition to the still image capture for which we bought it."
20120109"
column385:
If you plan to ever take pictures in dim lighting then this is not the camera for you!  You will get a sickly bright yellow light to all your pictures and Cannon will do nothing to help you with this.  When I called them they said I could change about 62 settings to make it just right--yea, like I have time to do that when my child is doing something adorable for 2 seconds.  They did not even offer to take a look at it or exchange it for another model.  So, I am stuck with a costly mistake and will definitely never purchase another Cannon product due to their insanely unstellar assistance."
20120109"
column388:
This camera is wonderful! I love all the features. And it truly is point and click. The picture image and clarity is amazing! No more blurry or out of focus photos!! I had to return the first one because the shutter stuck and the second is phenomenal! No problems, no weird sounds... Would definitely recommend to anyone!"
20120109"
column391:
Purchased for my son who seemed very pleased with camera's features.  I was pleased with the price.  Was impressed with the camera's compact size."
20120108"
column394:
I recently had to replace my wife's camera.  She wanted an easy to use compact as she was shooting a lot of our great-grandchild.  After researching all the options I ordered this one even though I am a dyed-in-the-wool Nikon lover.  I have to say I am extremely impressed with its easy of use, quality of picture, very compact size and the fact that the wife has bonded with it easily and quickly."
20120108"
column397:
This is my 5th Canon Digital Elph series and wanted this model to replace my SD890IS.  I also bought the 100HS (6th Elph :-)) to replace my wife's SD1100IS.  I generally replace my point-and-shoot cameras (P/S) about every three years.Like many other reviewers have mentioned, Canon does make very good P/S cameras.  I bought these cameras for the HD (720p/30fps and 1080p/24fps) video capabilities.  There are plenty of good reviews on the video capability of this camera so I will not mention it here.I am a 'tech-y,' and researched beyond just the number of mega-pixels.  Truth be told, MP does not mean anything to me if the image captured isn't sharp or useable.  I am a super fan of the Canon Elph series for their overall quality, image quality, size, weight, battery life and the response time between pressing the button to take a photo to the time the camera's shutter is released.  (This has been the number one factor (for me) in not taking blurry pictures.)  To me, an imaged captured is worth more than not getting anything at all.I generally do not write reviews on products that I would assume would 'stand on their own.'  However, the 300 HS has me a bit perplexed, and here's my assessment:Image quality:  Less sharp than any of my previous Elphs.  This is most noticeable at the wide angle (4.3mm/24mm equiv to 35mm).  The sharpness improves as you step up the zoom but still less sharp as any of my previous Elph models.  However, the depth of color and contrast is the best of all my previous Elphs thanks to the 1/2.3' (6.17 x 4.55 mm) CMOS sensor and the DIGiC 4 processor.  The softness is very noticeable on images taken at wide angle.  The center of the image is very soft and gets progressively worse away from the center.  If you take a landscape picture, this it isn't as noticeable.  However, if you take pics of your kids three feet away, you will notice it.  These pics are useable especially for small prints (3x5) and of course online publishing on social media sites.  The sharpness improves on pics taken zoomed-in (tele), but they still are NOT as sharp as my other Elph models.  The softness can be seen viewed even at 30% zoom on a normal computer screen.  On the flip-side, the 24mm equiv is a nice feature to get those wide shots.  For a P/S, this is very wide.  The widest angle my other Elphs models were 28mm and 35mm (of course 35mm equiv).  (My Nikon dSLR only gets 26mm equiv with a 17mm lens.  Of note:  for those wanting more 'tech-y' info: the image quality in 24mm focal length is far worse than my other Elphs in terms of sharpness, chromatic aberration, pincushion, and other distortions.  However, 300 HS favors f/2.7 (95%+ of 1500 pics taken thus far both indoor and out) which would certainly explain CA and sharpness!)(Sorry for a long review, I didn't intend it to be so long but I know someone hopefully at Canon will read this?)Picture taking modes: First of all, this isn't a dSLR.  It isn't meant to be.  That said, it does not take as sharp focused pics compared to older Elphs.  I use the 'Children & Pets' mode and the fastest the shutter will take is 1/60th of a second.  Really?  However, the fastest the shutter will go is 1/2000 of a second!  I think this is a programming issue that Canon can easily fix.  The shutter speed for Children & Pets should be higher like 1/80 to about 1/250.  Certainly 1/60 is insufficient for kids.  1/20 to 1/60 is a great range for indoor non-moving subjects.  The rest of the modes are adequate, scenery and hand held night shots are very nice, although don't expect sharp focused pictures.  Later, I will post on Flickr some of these samples with the modes and all the meta-data (i.e. shutter, ISO, and aperture info).The CMOS sensor (the 'HS' name on the model) allows the camera to use super high ISO ('film' sensitivity to light) speeds without the pics being grainy or 'noisy.'  This means you can take fairly decent indoor shots with or without the use of a flash.  I noticed 'jump' in the image quality immediately compared to my other older Elph models.  Yes, this is a nice indoor scenery camera.  The 300 HS does very well at controlling noise at high ISO levels.Tech-y note: Overall the 300 HS favors open aperture, higher ISO, and then shutter in compensation in that order.  While this is super for portraits, this does very little for taking pics of children and pets, or any moving subjects.Bottom line: This 300 HS will get the image for remembrance sakes.  It'll get the 'job' done.Recommendations?  If you can, wait for v2 of this model.  As for recommendations on competitive products?  I do like Nikon; however, none of their P/S (in this model's category, i.e. price, features, and etc...) compares."
20120107"
column399: Great TINY point & shoot, not quite as crisp of pictures as my old powershot, though
column400:
I thought this would take 'as good' or better pictures than the powershot I had to replace when I broke it (an 800is from about 3 years ago), but unfortunately it's not quite as crisp, especially during movement.  THAT being said, it still takes better quality pictures than my friends/family point & shoot cameras, when we compare.I love all the functions available on this camera.  Lots of options for taking continuous pics, color tinted pics, b&w, sepia, borders, fadeouts, and lots of pre-set settings (for aquariums, fireworks, nighttime, etc.).  I'm not ready to jump into the world of fancy cameras & setting my own everything, so I enjoy having those available to me when the auto setting isn't quite cutting it.I also love how easy it is to start shooting video.  Instead of having to switch a dial & wait & then hit my shutter button to start, there's simply a single 'play' button on the camera to hit & it starts recording a precious moment RIGHT THAT MOMENT.  It's wonderful."
20120107"
column403:
I love Canon digital cameras. They are the only digital camera I will buy! They are easy to use, the pictures are always crisp, and they last forever!! I've had Nikon and Fuji cameras that are newer than my Canon Elph that I bought several years ago, and the old Canon outlasted them both. I finally got a new one and I am not disappointed! It is a great little camera for travel too. If you plan on taking a lot of pictures on vacation, get an extra battery and charge both of them."
20120107"
column405: bar room video will do works well in low light
column406:
low light video will do.The wideangle lense will let u do video in low light.marry unit with magnet trypod $30 set for 640x480camera will record for 59minutes.  set it and forget itI use my camera for dance shots, http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tOUrozsIkz4in this vedio 945-5 Genda-David,Leba-Elaina,Ralph-Lynn,Cathrine,Jenny,Melanie-HatMan,Jeanie-Lane.wmvthe camera was hung upside down and left on for an hour. using the windows editor that came with my laptop select picture rotate then picture rotate again and the video is right side up.  it works greatu must leave the zoom on full wide angle. in low light conditions the light through the lens is very restricted when zoom to telephoto."
20120106"
column409:
Very nice camera, excellent pictures and very easy to use. Bought this for my wife for Xmas and she loves it."
20120106"
column411: You Get What You Pay For
column412:
I've used many Canon P&S and was looking for a compact, good quality one to bring around with me to parties and events. I currently own a SD907IS and replaced it with the ELPH300 because it's much more compact and easy to carry but was greatly disappointed. Not sure if I was just given a faulty one, but every other picture I took with the flash on was blurry. I had no problems with it in well lit settings, but in dark settings this camera doesn't do it's job."
20120106"
column415:
I think this is a great camera for the price. There are tons of reviews on youtube that can give you a better idea and visual of the camera. Those reviews sealed the deal for me. The camera is light weight,easy to hold and store, many options, and easy to use. I suggest reading some of the directions so you can get the most out of the camera. I have had it for a couple of weeks now and I'm so happy I bought it!"
20120105"
column418:
After some Gypsies stole my belated camera in Hungary, I was looking everywhere for a replacement. I'm glad I found this one. I use it often and have been nothing but impressed. It's a handy little point and shoot and I've taken some great shots with it. I just hope it stays on my person when I go to Hungary this summer!"
20120105"
column420: First Digital Camera and I love it!
column421:
At 27 years old, I finally bought a camera to film for my youtube series.  Everything about it works well including the microphone, the zoom, the video recording (full HD), and the battery life.  The only feature I do not like is the video limit being 10 minutes.  After 10 minutes, you have to stop recording and start a new video.  However, for the price and the quality, this is an excellent buy."
20120104"
column423: Good little camera, lots of features
column424:
I received this camera as a Christmas gift and really enjoy the range of features it has. I don't expect anything near perfect from a compact camera (that's what my dSLR and arsenal of lenses is for), but this camera takes pretty good pictures and is quite fun to play with. I find the menu to be fairly intuitive (I never even opened the instruction book). I received the red version of the camera, which I wasn't crazy about at first, but guess what I haven't misplaced  yet! It is also very light and compact, which offers a bit of a catch-22: it's easy to carry around anywhere, but I'm constantly afraid I'm going to drop it if I don't have the wrist strap on simply because there's no curve or girth to hold on to.The only two things that drive me somewhat nuts about this camera:1) The flash is located right above the lens, which creates a shadow in almost any picture you take up-close while using the flash. Also, as a lefty I normally have my left index finger on top of the camera to steady it; however, the flash is so close to the top of the camera that my finger sometimes cuts off part of the flash - and I have tiny fingers!2) There's no view-finder (although I've found this to be a problem with most recently made compacts). Personally, I don't always like holding my camera more than a foot away from my face and looking at an lcd screen. Sometime's it's nice to put my eye up to a camera to take a picture. Plus, this means I can't turn off the lcd screen to conserve battery life.Overall, I am satisfied with this camera and do recommend it for the average to moderately advanced camera user."
20120104"
column427:
Ordered this for my girl friend.  She loves the color red. She loves the camera...can't stop pressing that button. Camera was a deal and amazon prime offered fast 1 day shipping due to holidays. THANK YOU AMAZON!"
20120103"
column429: Good things come in small packages
column430:
I was sincerely impressed by how much power this camera has, specifically because it is TINY. I love it though. I love the texture of the camera itself, I love the touch screen, I love the resolution, and it's all relatively easy to use. If I could think of one complaint, it is with the battery time, but its battery is rechargeable and a wall charger comes packaged with the camera. It's not worth docking it a star, but is something that could be improved. Overall, an excellent value for the price."
20120102"
column433:
A selling point for this camera was its ability to take clear pictures in low light;however, I've found that my Elph1000 does a better job at that.  I do like the redeye correction feature and am trying the resizing feature.  Quality of pictures in good light or within flash range is very good. Erasing an image require many steps which is a nuisance."
20120102"
column436:
Bought for first camera for my daughter. She seems happy with it and she says it's easy to use. Time will tell. It is definitely better than my SD1000 camera."
20120102"
column439:
I have owned 4 Canon Powershot cameras the latest being  SD1000 which I replaced/supplemented with this new 300HS.I haven't done a lot of technical shooting with it but am very pleased with its ability to shoot low-light pics.  The tiny wrist strap was constantly getting in the picture so I took it off. BAD IDEA.  When I dropped the 300HS the LCD display screen cracked and I now have web lines running through my shooting/review screen.  I looked at the squarish metal case of the SD1000 and saw dozens of dents and dings where I had dropped/banged it with no ill effects.  Maybe this new girl is just too sleek and pretty for a daily driver."
20120102"
column442:
Bought this for my teenage grandson.  Arrived quickly.  He loves it!  Small size (fits in his shirt pocket) and it takes great video.  Very good clarity - hard to look at my grandma face!  He wanted it to take videos for Youtube and he's happy with the gift of course, he picked it out. Price was good for me."
20120101"
column445:
This is the perfect small but high quality camera.  I used it in low light for some holiday photos that came out great and then used it outside for scenic shots and low light sunsets.  All came out great.  Very easy to use.  Highly recommend"
20120101"
column447: Does anyone else's camera take a long time to shoot?
column448:
Hi, I got this camera after reading all the rave reviews. I am having a problem that I didn't see anyone else discuss, so I am wondering if it is just me or maybe my camera is on a strange setting? Basically, it takes a good few seconds from when I press shoot until it actually snaps a picture. I am constantly missing the moment, my kids look away and the moment I'm trying to capture is lost. Does anyone have any ideas on this?Thanks so much!"
20120101"
column451:
Unbelievable capabilities in such a small package. Favorite feature: Plug in to HD TV & watch videos immediately (Order A - C Hdmi cord).  But, wish I had waited a week - went to Costco & saw the Elph 310 which has an 8x Zoom (Fifty buck more - but worth it to me)."
20120101"
column454:
Great little camera!  I shopped around and read many review before purchasing the Elph, and I'm very satisfied with it.  I love the sleek body, the pictures turn out really good, and I like the fact that it has buttons and not a touch screen.  If that's what you're looking for, I would highly recommend it.  It's user-friendly for the most part, although I like to get the user's guide out so I knew what/where everything is.  Also, get the silver color because the black finish is easily scratched and looks horrible.  Not sure about the red.  Overall great camera, very happy with it!"
20120101"
column457:
The Canon HS300 is a great little camera. It's very slim and compact and can easily be carried in one's pocket. Canon can't be beat for the quality of it's sensors. The image quality is very very good. This camera also produces great video output."
20120101"
column460:
True to form, this Canon Elph presented an Error E32 message within days of purchase. It seems this is common with Canon brand digital products.  This camera is going back and I am done with Canon products. Switching to Nikon and not looking back after a bad run of Canon digital products with bad picture quality, errors, and quickly dead batteries."
20111231"
column463:
Owning a DSLR with multiple lenses I wanted a point and shoot for trade shows  and other occasions where a DSLR is too cumbersome.  Yet I did not want to compromise on photo quality, especially on close ups ( I work in the textile business ) where I needed good macro quality.I really thought the Canon S100 would foot the bill.  After all it cost three times the price of the Elph 300 at the time.  two hundred pictures later I had to accept the fact that the elph 300 was better than his expensive brother in almost all compartments of the field, except maybe lowlight - and in wide angle at that- and shooting RAW, which, in all fairness is waste of time most of the time as the JPG engine in the Canon does incredibly well.The real shocker was the comparison of the macro performance to my DSLR.  The Elph was clearly better than my kit lens.  So I borrowed a 105mm Macro lens designed specifically for the purpose.  AFter playing with exposure, depth of field, tripods and the like, we gave up... the ELPH was better even handheld than all this expensive hardware... live and learn.my only downgrade was for the battery problem mentioned by other reviewers.  Otherwise, this machine is perfect for its purpose.  And I tried many other ELPH like the 310 or the 400 and so on, but could not justify the price difference.  This is a great value and a great little companion"
20111230"
column465: Best Camera, Rivals and Eats DSLRs for Breakfast
column466:
First off, let me be the first to tell you that I was a sceptic of this camera. I did not think at first that it would be as good as it really is. I do not write reviews, EVER, so this is a very compelling product that you should buy because it brought me to write one :).I bought this camera two days ago, and got to 'break it in' that very night when I got it. My sister in law had her baby, and boy did it ever perform. I was taking pictures in a very low lit room. It was medium sized with only one lamp on. (REMEMBER, you are not supposed to use flash with newborns, so I did not, and this served as a real world test for this camera. I feel that the only way to see how powerful a camera really is, is to see what it can do without a flash) I was scared to look at the pictures when i got home, because, after all this is one of the worlds smallest cameras, and a point and shoot at that. I plugged in my memory card into my computer and what I saw still shocks me. The pictures taken in a dark room,without a flash, were clear, and were even brighter than the real life room itself, and no noticable noise showed. Beings I used no flash, this is stunning. There was minimal to NO noise at all in the pictures! This camera is treading on the grounds of both of my sisters DSLRs and taking it by storm.I saw one revewer saying that the build quality of these were bad. That is the biggest load I have ever heard. This camera is rock solid, and feels quite literally like a very solid block of iron, it seriously feels that rigid. Absolutely no sense of plastic-ness feel here. It even has a rough (that isnt quite the right word, it is textured) but in any case makes you feel like you will never drop it. All in all it just adds to the feel and performance of this device that, if i had the money, would pay double price for.As for the flash, it is very bright. dont let the small flash lens fool you, this sucker packs a punch. I took a pic of a dark room with flash, and it illuminated the whole room in the picture to appear like it had full lighting on. this was not a small room either.It has absolutely stunning 1080, plus you have the ability to zoom in while taking video. That in and of itself is one selling point for this camera. Only select few allow you to do 1080, that is all on top of the zoom while taking video which isnt in 97 percent other point and shoots. lots dont even give you 1080 either. Colors were ABSOLUTELY awesome.Need i mention the CMOS sensor? that is what is allowing me to take the great low light photos. Paired with canon's software, these low light photos are grain free (with very very minor exceptions, only noticable when pictures are blown up HUGE!)As you can see, i could go on, and on, all night about this, but you will never experience it until you get one. Go and buy one. Trust me, you will not be dissapointed. Please disregaurd these people that are badmouthing it! Many people hate canon because they are simply being biased and want a different camera company to be better. Reguardless of what they say, i can tell you that if you can stand still at all, even remotely, for just one second, you can a great photo, even without flash in dark situations. with flash, I could quite literally be dancing around, and get a good pic. Enough said."
20111230"
column469:
I purchased the Canon Powershot ELPH 300 HS about 2 weeks ago and have been using it nonstop. I've been using it all the time, and still have not had to recharge the battery. So the battery life seems pretty great to me. Also I like the fact that there is a tab type thing where the battery goes, so when you open the cover, the battery will not fall out. Which is pretty ingenious considering breaking the battery would be a big deal, since it has its own special battery. Not AA's or anything standard like that. I got the black color, since it was on sale at the time, and it has a kind of texture on the back of the camera, so holding onto it isn't a problem at all.Bottom Line: I would recommend this camera to anyone who likes to take pictures of family and friends. It does great in low-light. And the pictures come out AMAZINGLY clear. The 12 megapixel isn't as many as some cameras, but I think it is plenty for this camera. It seems to be able to take in enough light to make the pictures clear, without needing the extra 2-4 megapixels (I hate flash with a passion and use it only when i absolutely have to)."
20111230"
column472:
It's just great how easy it works. We love the compact size as it fits in any pockets. Recommended for travelers."
20111230"
column474: Happy New year! I hope everyone had a joyous Christmas!
column475:
I received this easy camera for Christmas and so far I am enjoying it. The size is perfect to carry with me all of the time.  I got the red one because, why not? It's pretty.  The pictures are sharp, the zoom is most convenient and videos are crisp and clear.  It is a wonderful pocket camera and easy to use."
20111230"
column477: Exceptional camera for a great price!
column478:
After reading the wonderful reviews for this product, I decided it was a good choice and purchased it.  It is truly a great camera for the money.  Very sharp pictures and video.  Bought it for our 17-year daughter, who can be a little rough on things from time to time, and she especially loved the textured finish on the camera, saying it was much easier to hold.  Doesn't have a slick finish that makes the camera slip out of your hand easily.  Nice pocket size, too.  Highly recommend this product!  Initially when we ordered it, it was out of stock and not expected for delivery until a few days after Christmas.  But, I have had such good experiences with Amazon, I chose not to cancel the order.  It did come in early and we received it 2 weeks before Christmas.  Always love purchasing from Amazon!"
20111230"
column481:
Basically, with the Canon 300 you can take a picture of a pile of trash and it will look beautiful. Auto mode without flash is all most people will ever need to take a great picture, but you can also have some real fun with the various special effects - right now my favorites are fish eye, miniature, and vivid. And don't even get me started on the video! The 1080p quality is amazing (especially outdoors), and the 240fps videos can be really interesting.Build quality is great. The camera feels heavy and there's a textured finish for better grip. Button layout is perfect. The lens is amazing - 24mm wide angle in something this size? You'd be crazy to pass it up!It feels great to have so much functionality in something smaller than my smartphone, which regardless of what some people say will not be replacing the point and shoot camera anytime soon."
20111230"
column484:
Cute and multifunctional. Easy to carry. Acceptable picture quality. Reasonable price. Efficient delivery. Little bit disappointed because the original package of the camera doesn't include SD card, making it unconvenient for a test use. Have to place a seperate order for a card."
20111230"
column487:
Had the camera 3 weeks and have already had quite a few opportunities to use it. Haven't had time, which is necessary, to master the menu, but have already taken many great stills and video all in automatic. Color, focus,sound and depth are great. Love the fact that video zooms in and out even in auto play, and that the camera has multiple face recognition. Sure I will enjoy this little camera, and it is little, even more when I master the menu."
20111230"
column490:
This is simply an outstanding product. I've had earlier versions of this series which have been great. The video quality from this camera is fantastic. For a simple point & shoot it is wonderful. I love it!"
20111230"
column493:
This is a very functional, very compact camera that is well built. It was a gift for my wife who had an older EL:PH that she gave to our daughter. This one has the benefit of more pixels, full HD, and annotated menus -- the last one is a nice feature. This camera also has a slightly rough surface compared to the smooth finish of the last ELPH, which makes it easier to hold (less likely to slip). I also got an excellent Cyber Monday price on it."
20111230"
column496:
Great camera to take around especially for college students. I needed to copy some papers, but had not scanners. Work fantastic!Takes really good quality photos esp portraits!"
20111229"
column498: Absolutely the BEST. Will never buy anything but Elph again.
column499:
I have always had the Canon Elph series of point and shoot cameras since it was on the strange APS film Format.  Must have gone through 5 different Elph formats.  They have ALWAYS been excellent - easy to use - compact - great quality cameras.  I will NEVER switch brands again.  This 300HS is absolutely the best.  Just buy it and enjoy with NO regrets or worries.However, Last year I veered off course and bought a Nikon s8100 Camera with 10x Optical zoom lens.  BIG MISTAKE.  Do not get me wrong, the photos and video were good from the Nikon, but the interface and usability was AWFUL.  I just could not get used to the camera and my wife absolutely HATED it.  I read through the Nikon manual over 6 times and I still can not get the hang of the camera (I consider my self a Techie and very savvy with mechanical or electronic things.)  Also the Flash on the Nikon was just too much so all the photos were almost always washed out.  This Nikon was twice the price and takes lower quality photos compared to this 300hs Elph.Just had to switch.  So I just purchased this Canon Elph 300HS and took 60 photos and 10 mini videos today.  WOW. What a MARVELOUS improvement.  I did not even read the manual and just used the camera.  All the buttons and controls are laid out nicely and easy to use and intuitive.  I especially love the small switch from auto to manual in the top right corner.  Absolute genius whoever thought of this = no more silly dials or obscure minuscule figures to figure out.The photos came out perfectly balanced both indoors and especially outside.  What is especially GREAT is that the lower light photos used to come out 'grainy' with this HS sensor = WONDERFUL detail with MINIMAL to NO graininess.Videos in .MOV formal are sharper and clearer than my 3 year old HD video camera.  The only slight negative comment is that the microphone is very sensitive and picks up wind rubbing noises easily.  Very small compact and easy to pocket camera.  100x better than my iPhone 4s for both photos and video. GIven how portable this camera is, I am going to carry it around everywhere from now on.Just go for it.  You can NOT beat the price for quality and functions for this camera.  ABSOLUTELY LOVE IT!!!"
20111229"
column502:
I purchased this camera after upgrading from an old Canon PowerShot that I have had for 8+ years and saw it had good reviews.  I am not pleased with zoom quality.  When I zoom, the picture becomes fuzzy and blurred. I will be returning this one and looking at other PowerShots to purchase."
20111229"
column505:
My daughter loves it.  we got if for her for a trip to europe.  so far it is a big hit.  I hope it lasts the whole trip!"
20111229"
column508:
I would have given this a higher rating but the cameral only comes with a few pages of how to get started and no user manual. I don't know what the icons mean and I don't really know all of its capabilities. It came with a CD Rom in place of the manual but my computer's operating system isn't updated enough for this new camera. What about others who don't even own a computer but just want a nice little camera and know how to use it. Canon should be able to provide me with one but there are only download links and I'm a dial-up user so there again I'm out of luck. I really hope that Canon Company will be able to send me a manual. This should just be an automatic item included."
20111229"
column510: Canon camera is easy to use.
column511:
While browsing in stores trying to select the perfect camera for myself, a professional photographer was also looking for a camera for herself.  She explained she just wanted a camera for everyday use and not one that would require her to change lenses for different pictures.  I told her I wanted a good camera with quality pictures, but needed a 'camera for dummies', since I have difficuties figuring things out!  She said this camera was one of the best I could buy--easy to use and great pictures.  Then another person said order it from Amazon and get it at a more reasonable price.  I did, and I am most satisified."
20111229"
column514:
I had high expectations for this camera. There was a high volume of overwhelmingly positive reviews, and my previous camera was a 6-year-old Canon Powershot A620. Any new camera would be an improvement, right? While the low-light photos definitely came out better than with my A620 (not great, but better), I felt that, on a whole, my old camera took photos that were much more clear and crisp. While I loved that the ELPH 300's size and weight made it easy for me to tote around, and I found the camera itself easy to use and navigate, I was very disappointed in the quality of the photos. I tested the camera out in multiple environments and on multiple settings, but around 90% of the photos were unsatisfactory. The photos looked great on the screen, but as soon as I uploaded them to the computer I saw that none of them were actually crisp. To be fair, many of my photos were taken in low-light settings and without flash which already makes for less crisp photos. However, for a camera that boasted being able to take better photos in low-light settings, I don't feel like it delivered. I did play around with many of the settings: changing the iso, utilizing the tungsten or fluorescent light setting, etc. and while on the camera screen the photos appeared great, again, as soon as I uploaded the photos to the computer I saw that I was mislead. FYI, my camera/card was set to the largest size and highest quality photos so that wasn't the issue.I am unsure as to why I couldn't get more than a few good (not great) photos with this camera, since there are so many positive reviews (not to mention great photos uploaded by users) for this camera. I might have received a lemon, or it might be error on my part; but seeing as how I have already spent a great deal of time and effort trying to get the best out of this camera (which is supposed to already take good photos without ANY effort), I think there is a problem here.I originally intended to purchase the ELPH 100, but opted for the 300 instead because so many more people had [positively] reviewed it, and because even though I was paying more, I was saving more off of the original price. However, $150 for a camera that I do not love is more than I am willing to pay. While I would love to only pay $100 for a camera, it doesn't seem like there is a great option in that price range (if the ELPH 300 failed me, I am assuming the ELPH 100 will as well). I would rather pay more for a camera I love. After almost 4 weeks of trying to work with this camera, I have decided to return it. I have since ordered the Canon Powershot sx230 (as high as I'm willing to pay for a point-and-shoot at this time, otherwise I would have gone for the Canon Powershot sd90 which seems like a safe bet) and after only a few hours of toying around with it, I am already much more impressed. Even with the 14x zoom (which is a definite perk), the photos have been coming out more crisp than the ones I took with the ELPH 300. I find it most helpful to read reviews for comparable items left by the same person, so once I decide for sure whether or not I am happy with the sx230, I will leave a review for it, as well as modify my review here.*update 1/5/12I still have only had the Canon sx230 for a few weeks, but I will absolutely not be returning it!! It has lived up to, and exceeded my expectations. I see that the most recent reviews for the elph300 are positive so I'm not sure where the disconnect is between their experiences and mine. If you bought the elph300 and are happy with it, great; but if not, I highly recommend the sx230!"

column559:
I have a Canon SX20is and it has been a very good camera for macro pictures of wildflowers, family and birds.  Of course, it has been very slow for birds--no pictures of small, fast-moving birds.  The main problem with it has been the bulk and size.I bought this little Canon Powershot Elf 300 HS to have a camera that I could always have with me. It has been a delight to use and enjoy.  I can always have it in my jeans pocket.  I put it in a little pouch to give it extra protection inside my pocket.  During Christmas week, my wife and I went to dinner with a couple who are friends.  I took a picture of the couple at the table and then the waiter took a picture of all four of us.  The camera is so simple, automatic and easy to use, it required no instructions to the waiter about how to use the camera.  My picture and his picture were both excellent.  The Christmas lights shinning through the glass behind the table was beautiful background.  The little flash did a great job of giving even lighting to each person.  The skin tones and colors were beautiful.The macro shots of wildflowers are excellent with very appealing colors.  And macros are extremely easy to take.I have been using the little camera to take digiscope pictures of birds.  I take the pictures through a Nikon Fieldscope 82MM.  I zoom the little camera to nearly full zoom and place the camera lens in line with the eyepiece of the scope.  It is easy and takes great pictures.  The image is a little soft compared to an expensive DSLR with long telephoto lens.  But, the softness gives the picture a romantic look.I took digiscope pictures this week of Great Blue Herons and Snowy white Egrets.  Both of these birds are photogenic--the pictures captured their beauty and elegance.I try to remember to put my little camera in my pocket each time I leave the house.  I never know when I might see a picture of something worth remembering."

After reading tons of reviews, I bought this camera because it is one of those rare ones that allow you to use the zoom while shooting video, continuously focuses, adjusts for changing light and has Image stabilization. I'm happy with the video. The audio, wind noise is typical of every camera that uses the mic type that these do. I'm in the process of making a dead rat to encompass the whole camera, as even handling the body of the camera introduces unwanted noise.The pictures tho are very disappointing. You'd think for any camera approaching 10mp the pictures would be sharp and crisp with some nice detail. No so with this camera. It seems to have a lot of useless effects, but lacks important options like a sharpness setting. If you're taking landscape type pictures with this camera, expect soft, bland, detail-less pictures, especially of trees, foliage, bushes, grass, rocks. Detail and color are blotchy. I quit using it on Auto and use the Program setting all the time now to try to salvage what I can out of it.My Canon A620 7mp takes better pictures."

I don't think I'll be going back to CCD because of the pure speed CMOS offers. after walking into the gulf of mexico with my old olympus stylus in my pocket i was devastated. it was the best point and shoot i've ever had. my mom surprised me with the elph 300. she looked at reviews and researched and decided to go with 'quality'. this camera is the biggest disappointment! first i was surprised by the bad design. its small and heavy which is good but the flash is on the corner right where your fingers go. yes you can hold it differently to get your fingers out of the way but then you have an insecure grasp on the camera. the video is a nightmare. i haven't stumbled on the secret of a decent video. sometimes you get one sometimes you get nothing but pixels. if you set the camera on auto you will get the camera shake symbol for every situation. does a point and shoot really have to be on a tripod for any and every shot? so the only thing to do is set it on manual and put it on the scene you want. bright sun dim indoor what ever. and then you hope for the best. when you get it its great but its a dice toss... i need a dependable camera. many of my photos are used at a professional level and i wont be getting anything salable out of this canon.... keep on looking if you're considering this camera"

column612: Before you buy 310 HS, read this ...
column613:
Best bang for the buck when it comes to portable P&S. I originally wanted Canon S95 and then S100 since they have bigger sensors for small cameras (bigger sensor is usually better with less noise) but I couldn't justify their cost for my needs.Canon 310 HS is an update of 300 HS but in my opinion, it is not better.  Wide angle starts at 24mm for 300 HS, whereas, it's 28mm for 310 HS/510 HS. They have longer reach but when it comes to small cameras in close quarters, wider lens is more useful - Save $50 over 310 HS. Otherwise, it has same excellent Digic 4 processor and fabulous 1080 HD video and same excellent CMOS sensor that does better in low light.The camera is fast, responsive, focuses quickly and very portable.  People with big hands may not like this model since it is tiny.  You can zoom while shooting video, which is a plus. Pictures are fine compared to other small sensored P&S cameras. People who wants to shoot RAW and manual controls should look elsewhere.  For everyone else, I consider this model to be one of the best P&S currently available in the market, taking into consideration cost, capability and build quality. I've looked at Canon S95, S100, 310 HS, 510 HS, SX230 HS, Nikon S9100, S8200, Olympus XZ-1 and chose this one.The black model has a 'rough' finish that helps to grip it better but some might be turned off by the texture.  The silver one has the usual brushed aluminum texture and reassuringly solid metal build quality."
20111222"
column615: Lovely but this has been by far the worst Canon when it comes to battery life
column616:
I love the sleek little camera, and loved the red color, how pocketable it is. I am Canon person and have had several through the years, powershots and other elph cameras. Unfortunately after a few months of using I am getting rid of it because its battery life is really poor. Low light conditions less than satisfactory for me."
20111222"
column619:
I purchased this camera for work so top specs were not a major consideration but it needed to be decent. However after using for a little while and looking at the pictures on screen at 100%, I must say that this is a surprisingly good camera. The camera is very small and portable and the fantastic rough texture of the black paint makes it very easy to hold on to.  The camera is also made out of metal and is very sturdy. There is no noticeable flex or deflection on any surface even if pressed or gripped strongly.  The lens barrel and surround also appear to be metal and look like top quality parts.  Overall I was really surprised at how 'quality' the camera appeared and felt in terms of construction at this price point. Especially when you compare it to comparable PS cameras in the same price range that are made mostly out of plastic.The menu system is easy to use but it does have the new 'rolling' menu interface. I prefer the old Canon menu style but this one is easy to get used to after a while. I use the camera mainly on Program and not on Auto. The auto function seems fine but it is constantly 'searching' for the right setting and updating its choices on screen. I found it to be 'busy' and slow down the camera.  I will only use it on Program mode.  It has a lot of the usual Canon camera settings including the popular 'miniature setting'.  Picture quality, considering the size of the sensor, is also surprisingly good. I compared pictures from this camera to the same pictures taken by a Panasonic LX5, which has a larger sensor and brighter lens, and unless you are pixel peeping and looking at things very critically, the pictures taken by this Canon can hold their own.  Sure the Canon has to go to higher ISO settings due to its slower lens (not F2.0) and the pictures are not as tack sharp and color saturated as the Panasonic but noise is extremely well controlled for a camera in this price range. Color noise was particularly well controlled and, although some may disagree with me, at times better controlled than the LX5. Also color is typical Canon, in its rendering, which in some cases was better than the Panasonic.So if you consider that this camera is now around $150 and less than half the cost of the LX5 (remember the LX5 was originally close to $500 at one point) and a heck of a lot more portable, it is a very good performer and in my opinion one of the best camera values I have seen. Other reviewers have opined that unless you need the manual controls of the Canon S95 that this Elph would be all that one would need.  I do not have the S95 so I can't back that statement up personally but based on what I have seen so far I can see why they would say that.  The flash is small and typical of an ultra compact so I would not expect it to be a top performer but the camera does well without a flash so it's not that big of a problem. I have not used it for video and will probably not often so this is not a consideration for me."
20111221"
column622:
I got this camera as a replacement for a Canon A75 Powershot thatis more than 5 years old but still takes sharp, well-exposedpictures.  The only feature I really wish my A75 had is opticalimage stabilization.  Unfortunately, while this camera has lotsof features the image quality leaves a lot to be desired.  Thepictures look washed-out and lack detail.The main reason for the poor image quality is the small (1/2.7')image sensor.  This size sensor is used in almost all compactcameras and they simply can't produce good quality images at lowlight levels.Note that although the 12 Megapixel 300HS has 4 times a manypixels as my previous 3 MP camera, the sensor is the same sizeand so each pixels gets 4 times less light.  This makes for morenoisy images.  The camera processes the image to try to hide thenoise but a side-effect is that the picture gets fuzzer.I tried to filter out the luminance noise in a raw image savedusing the CHDK firmware.  The result had less noise but also lostdetail. The result was arguably no better than the camera's JPEGoutput.  My conclusion is that, not surprisingly, the cameraalready does the best possible job at removing image noise.There may be specific situations where you could do a better jobmanually, it would quickly get tedious if you tried to do it forevery photo.You can find many examples of photos taken with this camera usingflickr.com's 'Camera Finder' feature.  The image noise is clearlyvisible in full-size (3000x4000) images shot at high ISO.  Butmost of these pictures look just fine when reduced to fit thescreen which is why most reviewers are happy with the imagequality.Going to a 1/1.7' sensor as used in the better compact cameras(S95 or LX5) would help a bit (about 1 f-stop), and so would awider lens (another f-stop for an f2 lens).  But more improvementwould require a larger sensor.  Unfortunately, a larger sensoralso means a larger lens.  Interchangeable-lens cameras areeither too large to fit in a pocket or their lenses leave outimportant features such as zoom and image stabilization.I spent some time trying to get the best image quality. Here'ssome guidelines I found useful:- White Balance: set the white balance manually or use the nifty  custom white balance feature.  The AWB setting often fails;  perhaps it gets confused if it can't find something in the  picture to calibrate itself with.- Saturation & Contrast: set custom color to 'Positive Film' or  use a custom color setting with increased RGB levels and  contrast - the default modes are under-saturated and have too  little contrast- ISO:  for stationary objects: set a fixed ISO that is as low as  possible while keeping an the shutter speed at 1/8s or faster.  This assumes you can hold the camera steady enough for the  image stabilization to do its job.  The automatic ISO settings  are too aggressive and set needlessly high ISO values.  Once  the ISO climbs above about 400 it's probably worth using the  'Handheld Night Scene' which reduces noise significantly by  automatically taking four shots and combining them.  for people and other things that move: set the ISO to Auto.  The camera may choose very high ISOs and produce noisy images  but at least you'll get your picture.Note that the sample photos for the ELPH 300HS on Canon's website use manual white balance and ISO 50 (which is strange sinceISO 100 is the lowest manual setting).There is an alpha version of CHDK available for this camera andperhaps the HDR and raw modes could, with post-processing, beused to compensate somewhat for the limitations of this camera.I had also expected the smaller size of the 300 HS to be anadvantage but, actually, it's too small!  The smaller size makesit harder to handle and operate the controls and yet doesn't makeit any more likely that I'll bring it along with me.The camera does take excellent HD videos and has lots ofinteresting modes if you're into tinkering.  But in the areawhere it matters most -- image quality -- this camera is astinker.I returned the camera and am looking at other compact cameraoptions."
20111221"

20120515"
column651: (4.5 stars) A very good point-and-shoot camera, available at a good price
column652:
THE QUICK TAKE:  The Canon ELPH 300 is a very good point-and-shoot camera.  The size makes it easy to carry, which means you're more likely to have it when you need it.  The 5x, almost-wide-angle optical lens provides flexibility while maintaining quality.  And while small cameras like this involve a number of compromises, Canon has made the right compromises.CARRY A REAL CAMERA:  Some people would argue that the camera on their phone means they don't need a point and shoot camera.  Ummmmm .... sort of.  It is great to always have a 'camera' with you, so a phone does let you catch some photos you might miss.  But if you know you're traveling or going to an event - give yourself a chance to get some good pictures, carry a real camera (such as this one).  The photo quality is so much better than any phone, and it provides much more flexibility - to zoom, use flash, etc.THIS IS A VERY GOOD SMALL CAMERA:  The Canon ELPH 300 is a very small camera, about as small as a camera needs to be.  It's reasonably quick (except when you're taking a series of flash photos - but it's not unusual to need some time for the flash to recharge).  The photos generally have good exposure, focus and color balance.  The Auto selections are generally well made, though it doesn't seem to pick up on backlit subjects and force the flash on or otherwise adjust.  The flash works well enough for something this size.  HDMI output is nice to have.THE USUAL COMPROMISES, WELL BALANCED:  Small cameras have small lenses and small sensors.  Small lenses and small sensors capture less light, so perform best in bright light.  The processing and shooting modes help somewhat to address that.  (If you learn to use the Scene shooting modes in Program mode, that should help as well.)  Small lenses also don't have the sharpness of large lenses.  The extra megapixels of this sensor help a little with the sharpness - you're probably not printing 16x20 photos from these.  Overall, Canon has done a good job of balancing the inevitable compromises that come with a point and shoot camera.THINK ABOUT THE VIDEO SIZE:  While it's really cool to shoot 1080-line video, I'm not sure what I'd be able to do with that.  To reduce the file size and processing complexity, I've mostly been shooting 720-line.  That's still better than DVD-quality (480-line).By the way, the microphones seem to work well given the limitations of this type of camera.SOME ROOM FOR IMPROVEMENT:  There are a couple areas that Canon could improve:- The biggest problem, and it is significant, is that sometimes highlights are washed out or lost altogether.  The dynamic range of the camera seems surprisingly limited.  So the face of a child laying in dark grass will lose a lot of detail.  So I'll be taking a more capable camera some of the time, to get better picture quality.- Mostly an annoyance, but an unnecessary one - you can choose to set the Review feature (how long a photo stays on the screen) for 2, 3, 4, etc seconds.  All are too long in real life shooting situations with any action.  How about half a second, or one second?- It seems you can't force the flash to fire, or force the camera into Macro mode (for close ups), unless you switch to Program mode.  That's an unnecessary extra step for very commonly used features.As far as the other reviewers disappointed by this camera, I can only think of three reasons:(1) They paid full list price.  It wasn't worth that, but at current prices (not much more than half that, look for a deal), it's a very good value.(2) They got a defective camera.  It does happen.(3) They're just not realistic about what to expect from a small camera.This is a very good, and in some ways remarkable camera, given what's possible with current technology."
20120515"
column655:
I had an older canon powershot. It was heavy, big, and it was slow, the video was poor quality. So upgraded to this and I love it! It's so small I keep it in my purse all the time for unexpected picture moments. I use my camera phone, but when I want to take a lot, and even better quality pictures I use this. It turns on fast. The quality is excellent for a point and shoot and the pictures are not blurry. Outdoor pictures are excellent and it takes great pictures in low light situations.The video is awesome! I used to have a different camera to take videos and a different one for pictures. WIth this, I have only one for both purpose.One charge of the battery can take hundreds of pictures. I can't say enough about this. I just love it as an everyday camera. Great for vacation/travel. I have a DSLR but really, it's too big to bring around on vacations."
20120514"
column657: Great camera for a casual camera user
column658:
I have owned two Canon digital cameras in the past, and they've both been good to me.  When I was using them in my college years, let's just say those late nights were not always easy on my cameras, but they both lasted and were quite durable.  This time around, however, when I decided to purchase a camera, I was looking for better image quality.  I'm now taking pictures of my best friends getting married and nieces and nephews as opposed to random nights in random places.  Admittedly, I don't have a particular knack for photography, but I have several friends who do, and seeing their photos made me want a camera that could capture quality images without my needing to be an expert, without me having to lug around a huge camera, and without it costing me an arm and a leg.  This one fit the bill.  I've had the camera for over six months now.  It seems to have the same Canon durability that I've grown accustomed to (I've dropped it onto concrete a time or two now).  The image quality in daylight and well-lit areas is wonderful.  I get compliments all the time on photos taken on sunny days.  In low light, this camera does better than any other camera I've owned before.  That's not to say the low light pictures are perfectly sharp, but they're much better than average.  I appreciate the size, quality of the images, and durability of this camera and it's a great option at this price point for a casual non-photographer."
20120513"
column661:
I just bought this camera at Best Buy for $129.00. It came with a 4GB memory card, case, and $15 gift card for this price."
20111219"
column663: Not as good as it looks
column664:
I like the camera overall.zoom sucks if you looking for a really good zoom this is not the camera you should look for.Picture are shaky not to the canon standardsVideo is amazing but again low light sucks"
20111218"
column666: Came free when I bought a computer.. I love this camera more
column667:
So Dell threw this camera in for free when I purchased a 14z laptop. I was not expecting much from this camera since it was one of those free items that come with a purchase. But this camera really surprised me. I had a Nikon DSLR for a little while but I have a lot more fun shooting with this camera. I equipped it with a 16GB SDHC Class 10 card  and found this camera easy and simple to use but also loaded with features. The low light settings is impressive and the rapid shots are great for capturing my 14mo old daughter. The quality of the video is amazing and records in full 1080p. The computer and camera shipped separately when I ordered on-line and this Canon arrived first because the laptop was still being built. A few days after the camera arrived I forget that I had purchased a computer."
20111218"
column670:
I considered many cameras before settling on the Canon 300.  I wanted a pocket camera for everyday use but with good quality.  I have had Canons in the past and felt comfortable buying another.  One thing I find annoying is the ever-expanding megapixels in small cameras. Sucks up room on the computer, makes them harder to upload or email. Just not necessary for snapshots. My last camera was a 6 and did the job just fine.  It is several years old and showing some loss of quality, so I wanted to upgrade a little.  I use my camera for general grandma snapshots, simple scenic photos and at work to record visitors for Facebook.  I am really happy with the results.  Work is particularly challenging because the lighting is very bad.  Photos were excellent if I turned off the auto flash.  The size and weight are perfect for me.  Easy to put in my pocket when taking the dog to the beach,etc.  Or can keep handy on my desk.  I found it very slippery at first, dropped it right out of the box (on carpet, luckily)so now I am careful to use the wrist strap.  Haven't had a chance to test it on grandchildren yet, but Christmas is coming!Can't say anything about the video.  Haven't used it and am unlikely to use it much.  Clearly, not a pro - but this is a great camera for the typical snapshot taker.  I set it on auto and rarely change.  Easy to use with great quality.  Highly recommended to grandmas everywhere.P.S. It was a struggle to get all four grandchildren to look adorable at the same time.  Must be the darn camera!  :-)"
20111218"
column673:
Very easy to use out of the box.  Clear bright viewing screen.  Surprised by the clear, sharp photos with the telephoto settings and in low light without the flash.  Fits comfortably in the shirt pocket and palm.  I was looking for a simple, easy-to-carry, point-and-shoot camera providing good quality images.  This one certainly provides value for money."
20111217"
column675: Canon shame on you - disappointed 300HS owner
column676:
To start with, I am Canadian from Quebec and I didn't buy this camera on Amazon.com site. I appreciate Amazon's principles to let people express their opinion about products and I always use this site as a reference before buying anything - thank you Amazon for this.I bought camera online based on positive reviews (note: I had several Canon ELPHs in the past and Canon DSLR, I like photography and I understand it). I still use Canon SD880 and SD1100, older ELPHs with CCD sensor. This camera is exactly what I wanted, small, wide 24mm angle, 5x optical zoom and HD movie. Camera size is very important to me and my DSLR is always home..When I received camera I really liked it, kudos to Canon engineering team! This is beautiful P&S camera with nice spec.I was disappointed with a first picture taken in Auto mode and I immediately spotted that camera was selecting very high ISO (note, this cam is having small CMOS sensor so high ISO means digital noise, soft/blurry images - possible to print 4x6 pictures but that's it and I guess majority of people are doing exactly this). I am not 'pixel peeper' but images are not sharp at all. High ISO for this camera is 640 and above (400 is acceptable), and this cam goes easily to ISO 1000 and over which is horrible  (still possible to make small 4x6 print but images are soft, full of noise, missing detail etc --> very bad).I selected Program mode and lowered ISO to min which is 100. Pictures were dark even I had enough light and using flash didn't help. Increasing ISO to 400 in P mode resolved issue but it also introduced additional 'softness' into image - which is normal for such small sensor. I didn't investigate further but it make me think that Canon is using some ND filter which is causing darker images in lower ISO (because of CMOS sensor?). This was still much better since in Auto mode camera was selecting ISO 800 and 1600 (just because of the high contrast situation - this was indoor with daylight).My all older ELPHs (with CCD sensor) are limiting ISO to 250 max in Auto mode which assured clean images (these are cameras with small CCD sensor, with their limitations so lower ISO is recommended and I could trust Auto mode).Another issue with 300HS is that camera is using high F (aperture) when zooming in (it's normal but not to this extent). Again, I never saw this on any of my older Canons... I would suggest to disable iContrast from menu, it will not eliminate problem but it will help a bit.Even some professional reviews are mentioning these issues.For example read: [...]---------------Auto flash produced dark results with our Indoor Portrait scene when set to ISO 100, and the camera selected 1/60 second shutter speed. However, switching over to the Slow-Sync mode results in a much brighter exposure, though shutter speed is a very slow 1/4 second. You'll definitely need a tripod at this setting to prevent blurring from camera movement. Shot taken at ~5 feet (~1.5m) on a stable tripod.---------------------Note that he is stating that that he could NOT take a clean ISO 100 image without using TRIPOD and Slow-Sync flash mode in this shot, which is indoor. It's same situation I experienced with daylight-indoor shot.He could do it with almost any other camera, in same situation, and since this is P&S, who will use tripod in real life? We buy these cameras not to use tripod and to rely on Auto mode or moment is gone.In his conclusion he also mentioned that images are soft,not sharp, but he recommended camera. By comparing pictures on the same site you can judge it by yourself and note that camera will ALWAYS use high ISO in Auto mode except in bright daylight outside.My initial thought was that I received 'dude' (something was wrong with a camera - and it was made in China).
