I went to closest Best Buy and Future Shop store and guess what, all other 300 HS and 100 HS were behaving same way, made in Japan or China, so nothing is wrong with a camera.Conclusion:This camera is having totally different, unwanted/bad, behavior from all older ELPHs I used which is affecting image quality. In Auto mode pictures are BAD majority of time as explained above.This can be done on purpose by Canon to make a difference between higher P&S model as S100. In my opinion Firmware is culprit. In any case, shame on you Canon for ruining such a nice device.We deserve better and these issues can be fixed in Firmware (which Canon will never do and I assume that's why camera went on sale for a half price).People owning this camera should email Canon and complain about it !I do NOT recommend this model because of poor image quality in Auto mode (which majority of people will use).If you don't believe me test it, I can guaranty you that cam will select high ISO even with wide open lens (f2.7). Check image - see that noise, softness and blown highlights if you had any bright spot?There are several 300HS owners that experienced same issues I described so read reviews with one and two stars.For me, this is so far nicest ELPH (looking into camera spec) and at the same time it produces worst images due to the bad firmware (lens could be better but I am happy with it)."
20111217"
column679:
this camera is amazing!! we have had so much fun exploring it and seeing all the things it can do.  i would recommend it to anyone- it is easy to use and takes great pics and videos."
20111216"
column682:
I have owned many cameras over the years,  and this is by far one of the best quick shooters ever.  I have never really been a fan of using a camera in auto mode as I always feel the need to tinker with the settings to get the right shot, the right lens speed, exposure, etc.  But this truly is the first camera that i have owned that I flick the switch to auto and am perfectly satisfied with the output.  The biggest down side for me is when you are shooting video the zoom is agonizingly slow so if your subject starts to move after you have zoomed in for a shot its best to just stop filming otherwise you will get a good 10 seconds of background while you try to zoom out and find it again.  I take lots of pics of my dogs and while the single click shutter speed isnt mind blowing there is a pets setting that in combination with the burst mode makes my work SO much easier.I originally got this camera for my wife, but the last few times I didnt really feel like dragging out the rebel and all the glass so I grabbed this instead!"
20111216"
column685:
Awesome camera with quick easy to manage interface.  Has so many photoshop like features integrated into the camera such as cropping, color balance, rotation, etc..."
20111215"
column688:
If you are looking for camera that will fit in your pocket or small purse. This is the camera to buy. Very good picture quality. Tons of features. No more carrying around the bulky camera. This camera is 24/7......."
20111215"
column691:
I think that this product is very good!!! It is very beautiful. The battery can last a long period. I recommend this camera!"
20111214"
column693: small compact, and ready to shoot
column694:
I just wanted to put my 2 cents on this. I originally wanted to purchase this to replace my S95, but comparing the pictures, the S95 always delivers better indoor pictures. The quality of the outdoor pictures are the same for both. There is slight better telephoto on the 300HS, but usually I don't use it at full telephoto. You get severe pin-cushioning on this small camera.Nonetheless, I think I'll keep both and perhaps use this one on my outdoor trips since it will get more abuse. It's definitely much slimmer, and more pocketable, though, I'd get a case for it. You really only have two choices from the canon line which is the psc-55 and the psc-1000. Do not get the psc-1050 as it will not fit. You may also want to go cheaper and just get a sleeve. You can purchase something like this from the palm pre line. It's a soft cloth that fits this camera perfectly. It also acts as cloth to polish your camera too.[...]I will say though, with this camera, you better have a steady hand for your indoor shots, still, a better value currently than compared to the newer 310HS which doesn't provide much more in my opinion."
20111213"
column697:
I had a Canon XSI that I never used and decided to down size.  After many reviews and comparisons I decided to purchase this point and shoot.  I do not regret this purchase whatsoever.  I love the gritty texture of the body of the camera and the marco setting.  The screen is a decent size, could be a bit bigger but it lets you zoom in on the photos so that is nice.  It does not come with a memory card or adapter so make sure to purchase one otherwise you cannot save your photos."
20111213"
column700:
Previously I owned a Sony DSC-N2 which at 10.1 Mp was a $300 camera 5 years ago. It took reasonably great photos with a few exceptions. I half expected the Canon to be on par since it is 12.1 Mp with similar features, knowing that the technology had improved over the last 5 years, even though it cost half as much. The Sony was fully 'touch screen' while the Canon is not. I just received it today and after charging the battery, took a variety of indoor & outdoor pictures, with and without flash, wide angle and zoomed. I did not test the video feature as I use a good Sony HD video camera and a GoPro HD video camera as well. I didn't buy the Canon for the video feature even though it got good reviews for the 1080 video quality.These are my initial positive impressions:1) better than average (compared to the Sony) in low-light (no flash) conditions.2) about the same weight as the Sony digital although thinner which makes it possible to store in a shirt pocket.3) turns on and is ready to shoot in half the time that the older Sony took.4) without reading the manual, I went through all the set ups successfully in 5 minutes easily (very intuitive UI).5) happy to see that it can shoot in 16:9 aspect ratio as this makes it easier to import into video presentations at the same ratio.6) at the mid brightness setting, the LCD screen is much brighter than the Sony at full brightness setting.7) with a SDHC card with a 4 Rating (not high), I was surprised at the rapid transfer rate. Slightly better than the Sony with the more expensive proprietory Duo-Pro card.Why only 4 stars ?  I reserve all 5 star ratings exclusively for products that exceed my expectations. 4 Stars means that it met all my expectations.Side note: I replaced the Sony because it developed an issue that I was surprised to see in a camera in that range. It was meticulously handled, never abused, carried in it's own case, inside another camera case. It developed a problem with either the CMOS or the image stabilization. When shooting indoors with excellent lighting, it produced blurry pictures while flashing an icon which interprets as 'either insufficient light or camera is not held steady enough'. Even on a tripod, with the camera set to use the timer, it still produced the flashing icon and blurry pictures. A very negative ordeal with Sony CR convinced me that Sony was no longer the brand to have ... in my opinion."
20111213"
column702: Great little camera for the price
column703:
I bought this camera a few days before a trip to wine country in California. I normally would use my DSLR for such trips, but I wanted something more pocketable. This camera really impressed me with the quality of still and video. Got some amazing shots of the Golden Gate Bridge covered in fog. The panorama stitch feature came in very handy for that one. The lens is sharp, the color is fantastic, and the features are abundant. My only complaint is that the menu system is a little convoluted, making it difficult to change settings from one to another. I'd give it a half star off for that. Since I can't rate half stars, I'll still give it a 5."
20111213"
column706:
I bought this camera for a vacation, and it worked great, pictures were really good, easy to carry around, and all for a great price.  I recommend this to anyone looking for a camera in this price range.  I hope you enjoy it as mch as I do."
20111212"
column708: Solid performer but not exceptional - I returned one and the new one was better
column709:
I am just an average user owns a few cheaper point and shoot and a Canon SLR. The point and shoot camera I had all very good at day light but sucks at indoor pictures. The Canon SLR took great indoor pictures, with or without flash. I thought I could get better pictures perhaps with Canon point and shoot since the SLR does a good job.This was pretty disappointing. I wish I have not sold my old camera on ebay.Pros - Good looking; decent price. Okay with low light. Great HD video. Good battery life. Video button is a good idea. Good 24 mm and 5x zoomCons - too many:--Blurry pictures and no manual override to correct focus;--Over exposure - picture too bright;--JPG Compression too high, losing detail; making the 12M looks like 8M but worse; And No RAW format to count on--Out of focus even at video mode - my kids were dancing and the camera struggles to find focus - result in out of focus video - why Canon why?--Not very sturdy. Don't put it in your pocket without the case otherwise, I can imagine you'd get lens errors like other reviewers.Like other reviewers, I tried many things to see if I can come up with better results but I could not.Unlike other reviewers who want to know where its made of, I don't really care. Mind you, those iphones and ipads are all made in China and have the best quality. These days electronics use standard parts and standard quality control. Honestly, the Chinese workers are the most hard working. I would actually prefer stuff made in China, cause I know these workers are normal people. Assembly workers in Japan? That's so 80s. Only bombs in Japan would go work there. Same logic goes to labor work force in the US. We may have the best software engineers but best labors? Gimme a break. The Germans are different. I know they train professional workers like truck drivers for 3 years after high school. That's a trustable system. Anyway, my b.s. not related to Canon.I will keep this camera only because I sold my Kodak 893 - the 893 was great only a bit disappointing indoors.Canon, you'd better improve otherwise you will be just like Sony's TVs, getting killed by the Koreans and Chinese brands.----Updates ----Amazon lower the price by another $20 and don't have price protection? So I returned this one and got a new one. This new one can focus much better - I no longer have 50% of the blurry photos. Pictures still not as sharp (due to compression?) but at least its focused. So now I revised the rating to 4-star. It's good but not impressive; but consider the price its a good deal."
20111212"
column712:
Overall, the camera is great and it does great job as a video camera well.  It is highly rated at various sites and i am glad i researched and found this camera."
20111211"
column715:
I got this camera for my brother on his 20th BD. Great photo quality and simple to use. You can't go wrong with 149 dollars CANON Camera!"
20111210"
column718:
I bought this camera to replace a Samsung camera that stopped working.  I've had one Powershot before and never had any problems with it so I thought I'd try my luck with another one.  At first I thought it was a horrible camera, but I only used it on the auto setting.  Once I changed it from auto to manual and messed around with those settings, the pictures instantly got better.  It's still not the greatest camera I've ever owned, but hopefully it doesn't crap out on me like my last one did.Battery life is good, just like my last Canon.  I really like the compact size.  It's really small, but still easy to manipulate the controls.  I was able to get it on sale for $125.  I don't think I'd be willing to pay much more than that.  I'm fairly happy with this purchase, but I'm not expecting this to last more than a couple years before I'll start looking for a new one again."
20111210"
column720: I really want to like this camera!
column721:
This camera's build is very nice!  Good finish and feel.  Buttons are easy to use, unless you have very large hands.Outdoor photos in natural light are mostly good but the widest angle has severe distortion at the edges.Low light photos without flash are good due to the CMOS sensor.Taking indoor photos with flash is another story.  The auto white balance rarely gets it right, unfortunately.  Again the widest angle which I thought useful indoors in limited spaces, severely distorts everything but the center.  The flash cycles very slowly also, probably due to the small battery capacity.I'm disappointed with this camera in general, I was expecting better results.  My SD1200 took much better photos.I would recommend this camera with some reservations, but I would not buy this camera again."
20111209"
column724:
After getting this camera to replace my SD890, I took it on a week long cruise for testing.  Here's my findings for the black version:Pros:  (out of 5)Image quality 4.5 -  crisp, vibrant images.  JPG compression well done. Low light wasn't too impressive, but maybe I took it off Auto.  Auto settings good. Optical image stabilization awesome  ( boating pics turned out great despite wave rocking)Usability 4. - fast start up, fast image tracking, medium fast auto focus, medium fast flash charging, fast shutter speed.  All in all, good enough for shots at a sports game.  Menus a bit hard to get used toVideo 5.0 - superb 1080p at 24fps. Crisp, excellent color, slow but very accurate auto focus, even during zoom.  Play back from camera to hdtv super smooth.  File size large.Characteristics - lighter and slimmer than the sd890; black has a fine sand papery finish that doesn't bug me, battery life relatively good.Cons:- flash easy to cover flash with the left finger- slow auto focus on video, but excellent quality and works during zoom- large file sizesI can't believe how good this is.PS - Amazon shipped this free so quickly."
20111209"
column727:
i GOT THIS CAMERA AS AN EARLY CHRISTMAS GIFT AND HAVE HAD IT FOR ABOUT THREE WEEKS NOW AND I LOVE IT! I STILL DISCOVER THINGS ON IT I DIDNT KNOW IT DID. THE DIFFERENT SHOOT STYLES IT HAS UNDER THE PROGRAM SELECTION ARE GREAT. YOU CAN TAKE ALL SORTS OF PICTURES, WE ARE USING ALL THE DIFFERENT STYLES TO MAKE UNIQUE PHOTOS AND GIVING THEM OUT FOR CHRISTMAS GIFTS TO THE PARENTS AND GRANDPARENTS! IT IS LIGHT WEIGHT AND EASY TO CARRY AROUND EVEN IF U ARE HOLDING A SMALL CLUTCH BAG (FOR THE LADIES). I RECOMEND THIS PRODUCT AND IT IS SO MUCH CHEAPER ON AMAZON THEN IN THE STORES."
20111209"
column729: Muy bonita pero algo no convence
column730:
No soy experto en camaras, pense que la camara era mas delgada, sin embargo es pequeña y portable, las fotos estan bien y el video en 1080p se nota, lo unico es que algo le falta y no se que es, algo hay que no me deja 100% satisfecho, sin embargo es una excelente camara para toda ocasion y el color rojo esta muy chevere."
20111209"
column733:
Purchased in the US for travel as I have grown fed up with poor performance of phone cameras, despite their portability.The small size but big screen make this a pocketable camera, but one that is at the same time easy to use, good screen size and menu design allow for a quick selection of the most important features.  So it's already seeing lots of use. A big range of features and modes is there instructions in the CD instruction manual for those who wish to explore the more esoteric modes, but you will soon settle down on a handful of modes that fit your choice of photography.The metal case gives the camera a little heft which helps steady the camera for low light / night time shots more compared to a plastic-only model.  Of course a tripod screw is on the underside, so timer shots, night photography at high resolution are possible.The 3MB burst mode is great for photography at parties or for candids as the kids play; you just need the discipline to ditch those pictures that actually aren't any good, and the pictures are a decent resolution.  Optical zoom is also flexible and quick; AF performance is quick and markers on screen show what the camera has focussed on to avoid those out of focus foregrounds discovered later in picasa.The higher resolution modes give great quality and allow close cropping without the images appearing pixcelated at decent size, or decent looking enlargements that aren't embarrassing when you get them back.All in all, a well specced truly compact camera with a quality feel and good ergonomics."
20111209"
column735: Nice features in an easy to take with you package
column736:
This camera is easy to take along, as it is small and lightweight.  The black finish is non-slip and looks nice.  The video quality is very nice and you can zoom in and out while taking video (optical at least...I keep digital zoom turned off).  Has quick to access scenes and has a dedicated video record button.  Also starts up fairly quick to begin taking photos.  My dad liked it too and bought one for himself.  One con is that I couldn't just cable it up and begin viewing...software had to be installed.  But a card drive is easy too and gets around that."
20111209"
column738: Great Camera For the Price - Beware of Amazon incentives, though
column739:
One of the reasons I bought this little camera was because of its reputation for taking good pictures in low light conditions.  And it indeed does an awesome job of it.  I can get pictures of the deer in my yard at night through the window with only the porch light on (no flash), and they turn out great.My only complaint has nothing to do with the camera itself.  Amazon offered Corel VideoStudio Pro X4 Ultimate or Corel Paintshop Pro X4 for only $9.99 as a reward when I bought this camera.  They sent a link in an email to use for this offer.  I never could get the link to work - kept taking me to some 'error' page.  So it was a bit like false advertisement to me!!"
20111208"
column742:
I am most pleased with my Canon Powershot ELPH 300.  This is the second  Canon Powershot that I have purchased the past few years.  It does a superb job with quality pictures.  It is lightweight and easy to carry and very quick and easy to operate."
20111208"
column744: Love(d) Canon, but this has broken on me twice in 6 mo!!
column745:
I am a long time Canon owner. Have owned multiple PowerShot cameras now (this is my 3rd) and also two Canon SLRs. So, obviously I like Canon products.This camera, however, has given me so many problems that I feel compelled to share. I've also been so frustrated with Canon and the warranty process that I wonder if I should stick with Canon in the future.I bought this camera in April of this year. In May, the lens got stuck in the extended position. I called Canon, sent the camera in, and a few weeks later they sent a new (refurbished) one. Now, the camera has broken again - exact same issue, lens stuck in the out position. They say this is rare - but given that it's happened twice, on two different cameras, I doubt that. I'm leaving for a 3 week international trip and customer service basically said that there's nothing they can do. I can send it in, wait a few weeks, and *maybe* get it fixed (only limited cases are covered under warranty apparently). If I want to take photos on my trip, I'll just have to just buy a new camera. They were also rude and insulting, suggesting it was my fault. It was definitely one of the worst customer services experiences I've had to date.Canon does make good camera products, but given the awful warranty/customer service support, I'd definitely think twice before buying again."
20111208"
column748:
I returned a more expensive feature rich Canon SX230 HS for this more simple compact camera. Picture quality is great. Ready to shoot pictures or video in a second. Not too much settings or setup. Perfect for someone like me who just want to point and shoot. Highly recommend it, and at $150, it's a bargain!"
20111208"
column751:
The 1 star reviews are not kidding! I saw them and chose to ignore, and wasted a lot of my time for doing so.  My lens failed with less than 100 photos on the clock.  This thing is very cheaply made- feels like a toy compared to my SD870is it was supposed to replace (slower to startup/shut down too) Mine was made in China- I am guessing Japan ones were an earlier production run and are all gone. Please don't support the company by buying their cheaply made products.  Very disappointed in cannon for taking a nose dive in build quality.Oh, and the photos were nothing special."
20111208"
column754:
My husband bought this for my B-day.  We take a LOT of pictures of our girls and family... We love it.  It isn't anything professional, but the settings are so much fun to play around with and it has GREAT quality for the size.  The toy camera setting is fun... so is the monochrome setting.  We liked it so much... my mom bought my dad one for Christmas after he fell in love with our pictures!  GREAT buy!"
20111207"
column757:
I have owned another Canon point-and-shoot and was very happy with it, so had no problem picking this out and I am likewise very happy with it. The body is textured to allow easy grip, the menus are all fairly standard, it is a very small camera but very easy (with the image stabilization too, I'm sure) to take very stable, long-shutter pictures."
20111207"
column760:
Purchased both Elph300 (the Japanese version) and S95, returned S95 and kept Elph 300. Because: 1) Elph 300 has better video features - full HD, plus, you can zoom during the video recording; 2) the battery on Elph300 lasts at least two times longer. I was able to take more than 230 shots vs ~110 shots with S95; 3)  In terms of image quality not much difference. The S95 has a slight edge when shoot in manual, but IMHO it does not justify 2 times higher cost. I shoot mainly in auto mode, so no noticeable difference here.4) Elph 300 is significantly smaller."
20111207"
column763:
After going through multiple cameras (Canon EOS, Nikon point and shoot, and others), I fell in love with the Elph 300. It takes brilliant pictures across all environments - in low light, action (kids playing soccer and running), evenings, snow, sun, etc. Its also compact enough to fit into my pocket and I would recommend this to anyone looking for a family camera with great prints."
20111206"
column765: Great camera for pics and video
column766:
I was looking for a compact camera that took great pics and could also shoot HD video.  I found it with the 300HS.  It's got great features for photos and handles low light very well.  It is VERY small...almost surprisingly so.It does a great job with HD video. I shot this music video with the 300HS and it looks great:[...]This tiny camera looked funny on top of a large tripod, but it got the job done.  I recommend it if you want a camera for photos AND video."
20111205"
column768: Macro Function with Depth of Field
column769:
At first I didn't note this because I thought it could be tied to user error. After further review, I had to give this product 4 out of 5 stars. Best case scenario is that I have a rare dud.When the camera is on (battery fully charged, memory card in place), if you depress the primary function button slightly as to trigger the auto focus), the camera will crash as much as 3 times out of 5.I had to keep 4 stars because it is still a fantastic product. Returned it for a replacement, though."
20111205"
column771: If you are a laymen to point and shoot cameras, here's an easy review if this is for you.
column772:
A great camera, ranked 3rd among snapshot.com base on pricing, compact, sensors, etc against all the other point and shoot competitors that were even $499-$599 in retail price. I bought this during Black Friday on Amazon and it was $149. Its a great deal considering its one of the smallest to have a 24mm lens, shoots 1080 HD video (high quality). Its macro (shooting in close up) lets you close in on your subject up to 3cm in distance, something the Canon s95 (priced $299) couldn't even do. The one big thing that I couldn't stand is the sandpaper body. I have a sensitive touch and every time I pick up the camera, I have goosebumps. My girlfriend on the other hand, doesn't get any of this. I still give the camera a 5 star because the pros really out weight the cons. However, if you don't like the touch of really rough sandpaper, this will really get in your way. The low light of this camera is decently acceptable with canon's HS technology even though its sensor is a 1/2.3 meaning to say if you're shooting photos indoor, this camera will give you better results than most of the others competitors. But of course you can't compare this to a DSLR or higher end proconsumer camera because those sensors costs way more than this camera itself.If you're a casual photographer, this camera is decent enough to get you through most photo and video shoot. Lots of folks I know talk about camera lens, sensors, low light, af, noise, color of a particular camera saying the picture quality is bad or whatsoever without even realizing that even professional photographers have to depend on 3rd party flash light, great daylight and software manipulation to attain that stunning photo. The canon elph 300 HS is by far the best bargain for the cheapest and smallest point and shoot camera."
20111205"
column775:
I purchased this camera and loved it for the first 200-250 photos.  Approx two months later the shutters that opens and closes to protect the lens stopped working.  Now I'm stuck with a $200 inop camera.  DO NOT BUY THIS PRODUCT.  I took very good care of the camera and used caution when using it."
20111205"
column778:
I had some gift cards to use and thought how about a new camera?  I've been using an older Nikon S1 so I looked at the Nikon updated similar cameras as well as Canon (we have another in the house). I chose the Canon quite frankly because of battery charger similarity.  These kind of cameras are all a gift to photographers with any semblance of intelligence.Positives: Durable. Easy to use. Long Battery Life.  Good results in low light. Big (12.1) but not unmanageable file sizes.  Too big and I will have a hard time stitching photos, this size is perfect.Low Points: None really.  Lack of a higher zoom is NOT a low point.  Zoom past 3-4X is useless without a tripod, people, listen up!  These cameras with 12-21X zoom are unusable."
20111204"
column780: It may sound petty, but the button's silkscreened symbol really rubs me the wrong way
column781:
I have bought many of the ELPH-series cameras. All have been very good. For two years in a row, I used the old ELPH 600SD (only 6MPX) for my annual greeting card pictures and people couldn't believe that all pictures were taken with a pocket camera. (Of course, the lighting, subject matter, and composition make the picture, not the camera).Although it works fine, I just don't like the fact that the functions are painted on, not etched and painted. This one is even slanted. Take a look at the 'customer picture' area and you will see what I mean.Not really a big deal, but FYI."
20111203"
column784:
I had this camera 5 months ago but it was stolen. I recently bought another one off amazon on Black Friday and have been playing around with it for a week. I was disappointed to learn that the video playback on my computer was NOT clear; there were squiggly lines in it as if the camera was defective. In addition, the screen on my camera would randomly have squiggly lines too.Also, when I tested the zooming, it was much louder than my first camera. I have read some reviews about the quality difference between cameras that are made in China vs. made in Japan. My first camera was made in Japan; the one from Amazon is made in China. I was hoping this wasn't the case but I believe that's the reason my product is defective. I truly love the Canon 300 but am disappointed that I will have to return it."
20111203"
column786: Best quality you can get for under $200
column787:
Overall, this is the best under $200 camera you will find. My simple advice is: there is power in reviews. I looked at a dozen professional reviews for this camera and after 3 weeks of owning this camera, I am completely satisfied with my purchase. I will just list a few quick points about this camera rather than pro's and cons because there are a ton of other reviews doing that. If you don't have the time (or commitment) to read through this entire review, the first sentence of each bullet will summarize the point. Also do remember that out of cameras within 5 years old, this is the only one I've owned so I suppose you can take the review with a grain of salt. When it comes to me comparing it to other cameras out there, I am simply re-hashing what I read on other professional reviews. Think of it as me doing your shopping research for you. Bottom line, I highly recommend this camera.-I am not a professional, I am not an amateur, I am a casual user. I don't take photos for fun, I take them for the memories. I believe if you don't have the camera with you, it is worthless. But..if they are low-quality pictures, you will regret it in the future when you look back.-I bought this for $150, and you will not find another camera for a better value in my opinion! The other camera I was looking at was the Sony WX-9, but my bias towards Canon won out and I'm glad it did.-If you are shopping for a camera, shop by price. I know it shouldn't boil down to money, but the truth is it is all about money when it comes to electronic purchases. If you are willing to spend more, you will always find a better camera. Pick your budget and stick to it. In the under $100 range, I have no suggestions because I did not want to spend that little on a camera that I expect to last at least 5 years. If you are in the $200-300 range, I would suggest ignoring the basic point-and-shoot altogether. Get a Canon S95 (the newer version is the S100, but it is $120 more), it is a borderline DSLR while still being a compact. It has manual controls, control rings to adjust focus and aperture and ISO settings, and altogether is in a whole different class of cameras. Do note though that the S95 only has 720p video (although the new S100 has full 1080p video). I would not suggest the elph 500/510, because those are up near $300 and there is no reason to get a basic point-and-shoot that costs as much as cameras with decent manual controls and settings, not to mention much higher photo quality. Unless you must have a touch screen.. The pro's are a better user interface, a larger screen in general (because you don't have to place buttons on the layout), and the ability to select your focus point with a simple touch. The downsides are not being able to use it with gloves on, and a significantly lower battery life (the reason I didn't want one.)-The black camera has a sandpaper-like finish, while the silver and red versions have the traditional, somewhat slick finish. The black camera has the sandpaper finish that owners have either praised because it give more grip, or loathed because it felt cheap or picked up lint and dust too easily. I actually originally bought the black version because it was cheaper (also $150 at the time..but the silver was $180) and I knew about the texture going into it. When I got it, I thought I liked the sandpaper texture because it provided more grip, but after owning it for about a week, I didn't like it anymore because of said reasons. I bought the silver version for my brother because he was also in need of a camera, and lo and behold, it was a sleek, traditional finish. I liked it enough to return the black one i bought and get a silver one for myself.-There are indeed versions of this camera that are made in china, and others made in Japan. My thoughts (albeit just speculation) is that all these cameras were originally made in Japan, but considering the tsunami and the fact that there is a newer version (elph 310) out, production was shifted to China. There are others saying that only the Made in Japan versions are worth it because of the zoom 'knock' around 3.8x zoom in the China versions, but I will say that both of the cameras that my brother and I own do not have this problem. They both will have a motor zoom noise, but whether it has the knock or not I suppose it's just the specific camera you receive. Yes, traditionally Japan will have higher quality products than China, but in this case I did not notice a difference. I actually read another review (this one a professional one) that said the China versions had a quieter motor zoom noise, but that just depends on the specific one you receive. I actually was planning on returning mine to look for a Made in Japan one, but after playing around with it for a few weeks, I decided not to. Since the 'knock' isn't present, I figured they aren't going to get any quieter than what I have. If you are paranoid about it (as I was for a little while), good luck on your search.-turn off the 'AF-assist beam' setting for taking macros. In general, Infrared rangefinders are very inaccurate in short distances (under 6 inches), it will make it impossible to focus on close shots. The only time you need this setting on is when it is very dark (almost no light), but you want to take a shot with no flash. Then it will be able to properly find a focal length. But if there is light present, this camera will auto-focus without it. Also, when using flash, there is another setting in the camera that will allow you to use this infrared rangefinder only when you use flash.-there is a newer version of this camera, the Elph 310. The basic differences are: 310 has a 3' screen vs 2.7' and a higher resolution at 461k vs. 230k pixels, 310 has a macro rating down to 1cm vs. 3 cm, 310 has 8x zoom vs. 5x, but it has a worse sensor in it (maximum f3.0 aperture vs. f2.7..the smaller number actually means a better aperture on cameras). I don't know why a newer version would have a downgrade on it..but it does in this sense. This mostly only affect low-light shots without flash, but that is something that deterred me from upgrading. Professional reviews that I read said the overall picture quality of the 310 was slightly worse than the 300. The 310 also costs $200 while the 300 is $150 (assuming you find decent, albeit somewhat common sales on them).-The startup time is very quick (under 1 sec) and delay between pictures is also quick, assuming you turn review off. There is also almost negligent shutter delay. It focuses in under a second. Overall, a very fast camera. There are also high-speed burst modes (~8shots/sec, but at a lower, 3MP quality) and continuous shot mode (~3shots/sec, but full quality). Do note that the speeds of these shots is dependent on the memory card speed (see below). Also, their focus is dependent on the first shot's focus, so you won't be able to change subjects in the burst (same as any camera)-This camera has one of the best auto modes out there. If you are buying a point-and-shoot, I'm assuming you are not an avid photographer that is going to go through menus and settings to find a good photo, you just want to have the camera do it for you. I am a fan of not having to use flash if possible, so this camera was perfect for me. It has the best low-light pictures out of others in its price range. But in reality, the only difference between a camera with good picture quality and a camera with bad picture quality is its ability to take low-light pictures. Cameras from 8 years ago already had fantastic pictures in good lighting, but they were grainy and soft in low lighting. This camera is fantastic in low lighting settings. Reviews I read said it will be completely crisp up to about an ISO of 800, but even at 1600 I found it to be ok. High ISO settings require a longer exposure, so if you are very steady of hand or have a tripod, that will vary your 1600 and higher ISO photos (for the better or worse). But if you are taking pictures in that low of light, you'd probably be better off using flash.-Like other reviews have said, I am quite surprised that Canon did not prevent this, but there is a shadow in the bottom right-hand corner of pictures when you use flash, due to the flash area not being wide enough and it being too close to the lens. However..what isn't stated in most reviews is that the problem is dependent on the distance of the photos. At macro range (within 6 inches), the shadow covers almost an 1/8' of the corner, which is unacceptable as a photo, but that shadow gets much smaller as you get further away from your subject (somewhat common sense, but I might as well say it). at around a foot, the shadow is nearly gone, but still faint and present. Anything past 1 foot away there is no shadow. To be honest, 95% of your pictures that require flash are going to be taken from further than a foot away. I don't know anyone that takes macro shots in very low lighting that requires flash..they're all taken in good lighting. So..it is a big problem that you will most likely never encounter (making it a small problem?).-The image stabilization is very good in my mind. It isn't going to completely eliminate large vibrations from a very unsteady hand, but any regular shakes in you or the subject will not appear in the photo. Unlike almost all cameras in the under $200 range, this camera has true lens optical stabilization rather than a digital stabilization.-the video does cut off at 10min (or when you run out of memory), but you can always start taking videos again once it cuts off. I will admit, that can get annoying, but I suppose you don't really take long videos on a P&S, get a camcorder for that. I know other P&S cameras have limits up to 30min (the Sony Cybershots in particular), but that was just a minor irk for me.-Put a class 10 memory card in there. For 1080p video, anything less than class 6 will have your video cutting short because it cannot keep up with the filesize. But class 10 cards truly maximize the speed of the camera, going from being dependent on the card to the maximum limit of the camera's processor. This is useful in terms of the delay between shots, the speed of rapid shot bursts, and the speed of continuous shots. I would recommend Sandisk Extreme disks. I bought my 16gb class 10 for $24, but that was a black friday sale. Normal prices are 8gb for ~$20, 16gb for ~$35, and 4gb for ~$12. Class ratings for memory cards denote their minimum speeds: class 4 at 4mb/s, class 6 at 6mb/s, and class 10 at 10mb/s. However, the average speed for cards is not noted in class ratings. The sandisk cards have ratings of 'up to 30mb/s', and reviews I read on the cards have sandisk cards being almost twice as fast as other class 10 cards. 4gb translates to 15 min of 1080p video, 8gb as 30min, and 16gb as 60 min of 1080p. You will get well over 1000 pictures (the highest quality..largest size) with a 4gb card, so if you don't plan on taking any video, 4gb should be sufficient.-this camera has plenty of toys to it, but my favorites are the long exposures (up to 15s) and the slow-motion (high fps) movie modes. I live in Salt Lake City where the Christmas lights are absolutely beautiful, and to have a little fun, long exposures let you create effects with lights. You can write words with a flashlight, etc etc. This is also the same setting you use to get that motion-blur effect. Just make sure you are very steady of hand or have a tripod when using it, or your final subject will be blurry too. The slow motion video can be taken at 320*230@240 fps, or 640*480@120 fps. I prefer the slightly higher quality, but both these are somewhat low qualities. It's good for a laugh and entertainment though. There is no sound with the slow-motion movies though.I also wrote this as a reply to Stephan Krasner's review, but i figured it had good info in it so i will put it in a product review: ([...])I also purchased the elph 300 semi-recently, and I did not have the same problems you had with indoor and outdoor shots, sorry to hear that. You have to remember by default, this camera in auto mode will pick up an aperture/exposure from the entire shot's lighting (with the ability to change that in manual mode..but to be honest that isn't what people buy this camera for). This camera by far had the best auto-scene selection out of under $200 cameras out there in my opinion.As far as the screen goes, you might want to give the elph 310 (the new version of this camera) a shot if that is bugging you, it has nearly twice the resolution and a 3' screen vs. this camera's 2.7' screen. It is ~$200 rather than $150 though, assuming you do a little shopping to find a decent price (these were the most common prices I saw leading up to and during Thanksgiving). That was also one key concern when I bought this camera, but after playing with it in-stores, I found it to be decent enough for my liking. Do remember that there is an option in the menu called 'AF-Point Zoom' that magnifies the focus subjects on the screen, both while taking and reviewing photos (they're 2 separate settings). It's enough for me to tell if I got a good picture or not. But yes..it would be nice to have a Sony-quality screen on there. Just not essential.Concerning macro, I did notice that when you have the auto-focus assist beam (from the menu) on, macro shots have a very hard time focusing. Simple solution, turn this setting off. The only time the camera really benefits from having this setting on is in really really (near black) low light. With any reasonable light present, even semi-low lighting, the camera does a fantastic job range-finding a focal point in my opinion. This camera is rated at a 3cm macro distance (that is from the tip of the lens at 1x zoom, remember..), but I found it able to focus well down to almost 2cm. I really believe that auto-focus infrared lamp was what was making your images so blurry. The simple truth is infrared rangefinders cannot correctly read distances at that close of a distance, but they work really well at mid-to long distances (anywhere past 6in). That is the truth about infrared rangefinding, in this camera and any application. I got beautiful shots from macro, and i suggested the Elph 310 to you earlier, that camera is rated down to 1cm macro. Since you said you were a huge fan of macro shots, that seems like a high recommendation to you. I can post or send some macro shots I took, they look fantastic to my eyes. The thing I love about this camera is the quick-key tracking auto-focus by simply pressing the up button. As long as you have a steady hand and basic knowledge of maintaining distance to keep the focal length, the center-focus allows me to focus on the subject I want and then offset and reposition the shot I want after focusing. Works wonderfully.I am glad you have found a P&S you are satisfied with, but personally i find a difference of opinion when it comes to picture quality. I will admit, Sony Cybershots on average have much more bells and whistles, most notably their screen quality (most of them i shopped around for had 921k screens, vs. the 230k on this camera, or the 461k on the elph 310), but when it comes to picture quality (and with the elph 300/310's case, video), the Canon P&S camera's blow them out of the water. Canon puts the goodies where it counts, in the actual sensor and camera rather than its toys and trinkets. It's nice to have a nice screen, but this one was decent enough for me (esp with the af-point zoom setting on) considering pictures are taken to be shared on a large screen or printed rather than on the camera.I am by no means a professional photographer, but I don't think this phone was marketed to professionals. I wouldn't even call myself an amateur, simply a casual user that takes photos for memories, not hobby. If you want a compact but slightly more 'advanced' manual control camera, I would suggest the s95 ($300) or s100 (the newer version, albeit $120 more), but this completely satisfies me. It looks like Canon's marketing scheme is working..after buying this camera, which in my opinion is way above its pricerange and is the best value you can find on the market today, I am really enjoying photography and just might take it up as a hobby. One of these days I might fork over the big bucks for a borderline DSLR camera, but my philosophy still stands that if you don't have the camera with you, it is worth nothing. But you do have to remember that value is the entire judge of a products quality..if you are willing to fork over more money, there are always more competitors that are higher quality."
20111203"
column789: Amazon Black friday offeed memory card
column790:
I just received camera but positive when I placed order on black friday 11/25, it offered free 4 GB memory card.  customer service checked but said does not see such an offer."
20111202"
column792: Wouldn't buy this from AMAZON again
column793:
My complaint is with AMAZON not CANON! They did not ship the HDMI cable or the 4 GB card as advertised the day I made my purchase and to top it off there is NO packing slip and no way to contact them. My family spent a bit of money with AMAZON this season. Won't next year!!!"
20111202"
column796:
For those buying this camera, you need to know that a memory card is not included with it, therefore you will not be able to use this camera out of the box, even with the battery charged. Also, the Canon webite does not sell a memory camera specific for this camera. Don't be disappointed at Christmas, remember that the memory card must be purchased separately. The camera will not work without it."
20111202"
column799:
The Canon 300HS an excellent camera as long as you accept that it's not a 'baby S95.' If you want fast access to manual controls, this is not the camera for you. If you like scrutinizing the image pixel by pixel, this is not the camera for you. However, someone who's a non-photographer and wants good-looking photos from a small camera in 'Auto' mode will almost definitely love it.Likes:--------------1) Image quality is good for a camera in this price range. Yes, there is some mild corner softness at 100% magnification, and there are some chromatic aberrations in high contrast areas, but looking at the whole photo at any reasonable magnification, I'd be hard pressed to criticize the quality. The noise is well controlled, and there is enough fine detail to avoid the dreaded 'water color painting' effect of some other popular cameras. Auto white balance does a good job under a variety of lighting, exposure is generally spot-on, and low-light images are better than I expected. ISO 1600 is usable for small prints in low light.2) Video quality is very good. It uses a high bitrate compression, which eats memory fast, but I can see details in the video that other cameras simply smudge over. My only complaint is that the 1080p video is recorded at 24fps, and is somewhat choppy in motion. Switching to 720p or lower resolution results in 30fps video, which produces noticeably smoother motion. The stereo sound quality is decent, and the mics are plenty sensitive. When zooming during video recording, there is some motor buzz that's picked up by the mics, but it's only noticeable in a quiet environment.3) I like the 24mm wide angle lens, and prefer that over some 100x mega-zoom. It lends itself well to landscape shots, interior shots, close-ups, and other creative photography scenes.4) The camera is pretty quick to power on, and the controls have good response. It focuses in under 1 second, there is minimal shutter lag, and shot-to-shot times are about 2 seconds.5) The controls are intuitive, well-organized, and the buttons are plenty big for such a small camera. I had most functions figured out in a few minutes without having to resort to the manual. The mode switch provides a convenient thumb rest when holding the camera.6) Construction and build quality seems solid. I bought mine at a local store and made sure to get the version made in Japan. I haven't observed the problems mentioned by other reviews, like shaky video zoom or easily scratched finish. The battery door seems somewhat fragile, though.Dislikes:--------------1) When completely zoomed out, the lens casts a shadow from the flash in the lower right corner.2) Video mode is mostly automatic, you can't even adjust exposure compensation. I have older compact cameras which can do this, it would have been nice to have that feature here.3) The quick-set menu is somewhat slow to operate because it does not present as much information at once as other cameras, for example Panasonic's Q-menu. It's a vertical layout with vertical submenus, whereas a horizontal layout with vertical submenus would have been better.4) There is no wind-cut option for the microphones.I'm not taking points off because these are relatively minor issues, considering the camera is aimed at a novice user. It's not perfect by any means, and it's missing some toys found in other cameras, like a high resolution screen, auto HDR, or auto-stitching panorama. However, if your priority is the end result - the quality of images or video coming out of the camera - this one stands above the competition. I would recommend it to anyone looking to produce good-looking photos with minimal fuss."
20111202"
column801: Canon is riding on it's name.
column802:
The Canon I had before this one was more expensive ($250) but not that much more expensive and it took way better pictures with a superior build quality. The body was metal, but the battery/SD compartment felt cheap and flimsy as did the zoom control ring around the shutter button. A 240k LCD may have been good 3 years ago but my cell phone has had a better LCD for years, it's definitely an important part of the camera so you can see what you have shot in the field. They should have stepped it up a little more here. The form factor on the other hand is VERY good. It's the best looking small camera I have ever owned. The controls on the 300 hs are better than my old Canon.Despite having a back-lit CMOS chip, pictures indoors were washed out, blurry and extremely grainy. My old canon had this problem too, in fact ALL Canon compacts have this problem. They cannot seem to perform well indoors. The photos were either washed out so you could not see any detail, or they were grainy and blurred. Think night time security camera.Outdoors, the performance improves significantly, but still not enough to replace my old Canon. Bright light will completely blow out objects. Distortion is harsh outside around the edges of the photo. Trees for example become silhouetted by light lines. Outdoors on a sunny day is usually where canon compacts shine, but the 300sh is a big disappointment here. The colors however were extremely accurate, but if you are looking for a camera to take to the slopes, look elsewhere. I took it to a football game expecting to get some good action shots and almost every shot was blurred and hazy IN BROAD DAYLIGHT!The macro was the biggest disappointment of them all. This is usually another point where canon compacts shine, but with this one, I had a very hard time focusing on what I wanted, shots also blur a lot easier than my old camera. I am a big fan of macro sots. this is one point that has inspired me to return the camera. Honestly my Blackberry torch does smoother macro than this one...At one time cheap canon compacts were my instant go-to solution for a carry around. This camera felt like an old camera. From the screen to the images, complete disappointment all around. I have since switched to the Sony Cybershot WX9 and I can say with out a doubt that you are getting more bang for your buck, and way better picture quality."
20111202"
column805:
I purchased this prior to going away on vacation, which for many of you is a probable reason that you are looking at the camera. My overall experience was great. It has a high quality lens, something Canon is known for. It also has a decent sized screen for easy viewing after photographing. The fact that it is 12.1 megapixels is great for my purposes. A lot of people see the new cameras and see 14.1 megapixels, 16 megapixlels and more. Megapixels only help when enlarging a photo. You will have no problem enlarging a photo to almost any reasonable size with this camera. If you need anything bigger, I would recommend a Digital SLR. In summary, great camera, great price, overall a great deal."
20111201"
column808:
I had this camera for a while and absolutely loved it. The shutter speed was great and it is compact and easy to use. Unfortunately, I, along with quite a few others on here, ended up with the lens breaking. It no longer closes. The camera is now useless. I took it to a camera repair shop and it was going to cost $143 to have it repaired. Now I have to buy a new camera. If you buy this camera, I would highly recommend buying the warranty."
20111201"
column811:
I am (was) a dslr guy and was looking for something to supplement my Nikon D40.  This camera has pretty much replaced the D40 (sorry man).  It is small versatile and takes pics that rival and in some cases beat out the D40.You will not regret getting this camera.  Do get an extra battery and keep it charged if you plan to be doing a lot of pics (esp with flash or video).  It has a great variety of settings (read the book).What more can I say."
20111201"
column813: Silver over Black for the ELPH 300 HS
column814:
I, too, have a black Canon Elph 300HS (for 8 months) and now a new silver Elph 300HS. I found, as did others, that the movable cover over the lens for the black did get easily dented, such that it would not completely close.  A bit of mashing now allows it to close completely. In general, both take great photos, and I am pleased with their performance.Do note that the black camera is made in China, the silver in Japan."
20111201"
column816: Tiny, sturdy and high quality compact camera
column817:
Replaced an older Canon ELPH with this one and it hasn't disappointed.  This thing is tiny (about as small as they could make it without impacting useability) yet incredibly sturdy (metal construction) and - so unusual these days - is manufactured in Japan, not China.  It's small enough to take everywhere and takes infinitely better photos than a phone will with strong battery life."
20111201"
column820:
I strayed from Canon and now I'm back and will never leave again.  I loved my first Canon Elph 10 years ago which was only a 2mp at the time (this one being a 12mp).  I've gone on to the larger powershots but always said I missed my little elph.  I love the texture of this one I'm not sure if it's just in the black model I got but it's a sandy rough texture.  The camera takes amazing pics and I love all the little features.  It's simple to use without even needing to go through the manual and takes amazing pictures!!Thanks Canon!"
20111201"
column823:
I was looking to replace my old Canon S80, I like the S80 and the great quality pics it produces but it is too bulky and it was becoming an inconvenience and the 300 HS is a quality camera packed into a sleek body that I can easily slip into any pocket.  I keep the S80 for the stadium and family get togethers, but the ELPH 300 will be my everyday and traveling camera.Most Canon cameras take great shots, but what is most impressive about this camera is its low-light capabilities. Indoor night shots without the flash come out amazingly crisp, the autofocus is quite impressive as it tracks faces in the frame, the menu functions are quite intuitive, and it's got plenty of preset shooting modes, and fast between shots for a Point and shoot.I also compared the 1080p video. The video quality is excellent with the 300 HS, low-light video is slightly grainy but good, in the daylight the video comes out great, and is easy to import into computer files.I did purchase an extra battery after reading battery life can be short. I've had the camera a since Cyber Monday ($129.00 w/4G SD card, case, and $10.00 gift card) and have used it daily without a need to recharge yet. One of the best days of my life.I'd recommend the black body as it has a lightly rough textured finish that makes holding this small camera much easier.Overall, considering the excellent quality of the camera, easy portability, and great price, this camera is worth every penny."
20111130"
column826:
I bought the ELPH 300 HS to replace my Nikon S3100 which developed a 'Lens Error' after only 3 months. So far I have been very happy with the Canon as it powers up quickly and takes pictures quickly as well. The only thing I liked better about the Nikon was the fit and finish. The black buttons are OK on the Canon, and everything functions just fine, the Nikon just looks sleeker. So far the picture quality is just as good, if not better than the Nikon. The camera is also the same size as the Nikon it replaced, so if fit nicely into the same compact case. Hopefully this one will last longer than 3 months!"
20111130"
column828: Great little camera for keeping with you all the time.
column829:
I bought it expecting to like it and I do.It has one minor point of irritation for me but I can live with it. Every time that you turn it on it resets the flash back to on. I like being able to tell my cameras when to use their flash. Its a minor annoyance but one I can live with.It has a very small profile.The image quality is top notch.The toy camera mode is fantastic."
20111130"
column831: Just recieved my Cannon PowerShot ELPH 300
column832:
I recieved my camera today and I was so happy with shipping & product that I had to rush here to write a review. The look and feel are awesome, the Picture quality and the video quality is amazing. The price makes this all the better! Ive only have about 5-6 poin and shoot cameras from nikon, sony, 3 kodaks (I love their cameras and software) but this time I wanted to try something else. I read some review and convinced that this was a good buy... it was! I dont think youll have any regret unless your a professional that is comparing their $1,000 picture quality camera to this."
20111129"
column835:
I'm a fan of Canon digital cameras in general. The new, larger LCD screen is great. The pictures are great quality for the price. Lately, the majority of my photography has been of my new (hyper) puppy. She does not sit still but I am still able to get great photos! My only complaint is the 'delete' function is not as easy (I think I have to press buttons at least 3 times and through 3 different 'screens' just to delete) as my last Canon."
20111129"
column837: Makes you fall in love with photography all over again
column838:
I have always updated my digital camera every couple years, but this is the first time in a long time that a device has made it 'fun' to shoot photos again.  The night time and low-light indoors quality is very good.Some great highlights on this camera:-Fantastic image quality at this size-Slow sync flash is a lot of fun, produces really interesting photos-Slow-motion mode is a ton of fun and is one feature people are always jealous of.-Has a low(er) cost waterproof kit available at around $60-Mini-HDMI support to replay movies or do slideshowsThe controls are easier to operate than previous cameras by Canon in this size class, and it just oozes quality.  Highly recommended."
20111129"
column841:
I usually shoot a Canon 5D Mark II so these images are soft and a bit noisier compared to my SLR. It is a nice and small point and shoot which is easy to use, takes excellent photos (up to 8x10) and is excellent in good light and pretty good in low light."
20111129"
column843: If you don't have a pocket camera yet, this is the one to get.
column844:
I've been a long time user of Canon cameras and this one doesn't disappoint. So compact you won't feel the difference between it or your cell phone in your pocket.  Also very quick and easy to use. My experience with other point and shoots is that they all are kind of slow to turn on, snap pictures/ record video. Canons have always excelled at speed.The main reason I purchased it though was so I can take advantage of the 1080p 24fps movie recording.  Amazing quality that you don't expect out of such a camera. Also the extra wide angle lens makes movies feel more like one of the bigger expensive cameras out there. Image stabilization makes it more user friendly than a t2i. Here is an example of what a 1080p movie can look like -[...]There are some gripes though. The lens protector seems a little flimsy. I dented mine inward and it would not close properly until I 'undented' it back. Night shots can be tricky. I would also prefer the old way of deleting pictures on the old Elphs. This one adds an unneeded extra step to delete a picture. Also the movie recording can sometimes get iffy with the focus.These are just little things though. The camera is packed with features, takes great pics AND great video. 24mm wide angle lens and 1080p at 24fps, what else do you need at this price range?Just get it. =)"
20111129"
column846: Made in China, top-notch performance & features
column847:
Just received a silver 300 HS ordered from Amazon, not a 3rd-party seller.  This one is made in China,but so far all seems to be well.  Some people have mentioned a rough textured surface, but my silver300 HS is smooth.Compared to my PowerShot SD 780 IS, the wider 24mm lens on the 300HS is nice, and the startup andshot-to-shot times seem much snappier.The new red movie mode button is convenient, and the 300 HS can zoom and change focus while in movie mode,something the SD 780 IS cannot do.An awesome little camera, at a great Amazon price!"
20111128"
column850:
This is an amazing camera!  Wonderful zoom, good ability to capture an image at sunrise or dusk without a flash, very nice viewing screen.  I am so happy with this camera!"
20111128"
column853:
I have been using canon camera's since long and this was my 2nd digicam as i lost the earlier one.this is a very good camera,sleek and handy easy to carry.Pictures are amazing. If you want a good camera within $200-250 go for this !!!I like the Auto and Program mode which can be easily shifted as needed.For taking pictures at night i keep the program mode ready by selecting night mode,while capturing pics in night mode be sure to wait untill the Busy bar gets finished. this is the one feature which i found a little annoying as after taking pic you have to keep camera in standby till the Busy bar is stopped, rest all features are good."
20111128"
column856:
I got the camera very fast. And it looks very nice, easy to use. And the picture is good.at all, it's good for me."
20111128"
column858: Great product at a great price!
column859:
I got the red finish for about $150 (on sale) and I love it!  You can't beat the price.  This is a point and shoot camera for sure, but it is so compact to carry around.  I have been capturing photos of my son around the house and took it to NY and DC.  I usually carry a DSLR, but with my toddler, it is very hard to manage. This camera is easy to carry and easy to whip out.  It takes fast, sharp pictures indoors and out.  I am really pleased with the video function as well.  I am still learning about it, but so far I would highly recommend it especially at this price point."
20111128"
column862:
This is the camera that will take the pictures.Small enough to take along without bulk.I really like this camera."
20111127"
column864: Good camera with a couple things to improve
column865:
This was an upgrade from a Canon Powershot that was dropped on the lens and stopped functioning.  The camera is very compact and if you are familiar with Canon cameras the functions are all very much the same.  We have used the camera for the last few weeks and overall it is great.  The photo quality is great, auto focus is as fast as any other point and shoot camera, the menus are easy to navigate and the video quality top notch.  The one button video recording is the best feature and one of the reasons the camera was purchased.  It makes capturing the moment a snap without having to change settings on the camera.  There are a couplrpe things that could be improved.  1) The flash is where you naturally put your finger so it blocks the flash and ruins the picture in lower light settings.  You just have to be a little careful how you hold the camera. 2)  The zoom in and out seems a little slower than other cameras I have used.  It is adequate but ther have been a couple instances where the slower zoom lead to a lost picture.  3) It is almost too small.  It is easy to stash in your pocket but also very easy to drop.  The good news is that the case is very durable.  It took a fall on to an asphalt driveway and survived with only a minor scratch on the corner."
20111127"
column868:
auto mode very inaccurate color and quite blurry. very inconsistent shooting the same subject under same lighting yielded different quality photos. do not recommend this at all"
20111127"
column870: The only camera a person needs (outside of pros)
column871:
I have to say this really is honestly the only camera youd really need unless you are a professional photographer.  It is small enough to carry around anywhere and not have any excuse not to bring it with you when you go places and it takes good quality pictures that dont look like they were taken with a cheap consumer camera right away if framed properly.  Not only that but the video quality of the camera is as good as if not better then most consumer HD camcorders out there.  Now at first you may think well such camera would be useless for good videos because it being so small there is no way to really keep the video steady. Thanks to optical image stabization the camera stays very steady even handheld.  Its image stabilization is actually superior to my Canon HD camcorder which i paid 3 times as much for.  This is wonderful as it means you can have one device thats small enough to take anywhere that can take good pictures and excellent video and the video is at 24 frames per second which is rare for a consumer small camera that is the same rate as film so you can get a nice cinematic look.The camera has a very nice wide angle lens that really stands out as you can get more stuff in the shot like people and enviroments (is also great for taking pictures of indoor things like rooms in your house or places you visit) compared to my mothers kodak easyshare camera the view that it capture is significantly more.  It also is great for video too as was the problem with my older camcorder i felt i had to back up most times to get things in the shot.I have used a Digital SLR and dedicated HD Camcoder (that used tape) and i must say this is a real joy to have. I had not been using my SLR and Camcorder that much as having an ipad now i just didnt feel like carrying them all around and switching back and forth.  (the Powershot also has better auto white balance then the SLR i used) for a pro you might want a more advanced camera but for the average user this is a wonderful camera to havethe only downside i saw is that sometimes apparently the battery cover may come off, but thankfully you just snap it back into place with no problem. Also battery life is a bit on the low side as if you are out on a trip or out and about for like a day and taking a lot of video and pictures the battery will not last all day , my suggetion would be to to get a spare battery from amazon and then have both so you are set!a 16 gig memory card will net you about 1 hour of HD video or about 6,000 photos (photos are only around 1 meg each ish so dont take up a ton of space which is nice)If this thing was out 6 years ago at the price it is now i would have gotten this instead of paying $2,000 for the camera and camcorder i got.  It really is a great little camera (it also does non-HD slow motion video which is a neat bonus too!)  the video quality is superb and picture quality is very good as well.a great camera expecally for around christmas.  Yeah most cell phones have cameras now days but most cell phone cameras are so so at best this wuold easily in my opinion beat any cell phone camera and the video expecally would beat any cell phone video (or even the iphone/ipad2 video)and this in my opinion also beats the flip video devices you can get. as this camera offers more steady shots (which in my opinion is absolutely essential with HD video the steadier the video the better it is)great product! Having it means theres no excuse not to capture great pictures or video!"
20111127"
column874:
This Canon has everything I needed and wanted in a point and shoot camera. It's simple to use, has an awesome viewing screen, takes great photos, and the menu options are wonderful if I want to do more than just point and shoot. Overall, I am very pleased with the camera and would recommend it to anyone in the market for a good, relatively inexpensive, and reliable camera."
20111126"
column877:
I've been a terrible photo shooter for decades. Not only does this camera take the voodoo out of taking pictures, the applications that can be used when preparing to save and print the photos will rescue you from any errors you may make when you've taken your shots. I take my Canon everywhere I go. Whether I intend to take pictures or not. You never know when a photo-op may arise."
20111126"
column879: A bad camera , a good camera recorder
column880:
THis is the worst camera I have had. Before this, I just returned a S95 because S95 only have 28mm wide-angle. I need a more wider camera for carried everyday' so I bought this for its 24mm wide-angle. However, the photo quality is really bad, I have to resize the 4000*3000 photo to 1200*900, then the picture looks better. I hate small CMOS sensor!!!If the photo quality of  DSLR is 100, S95 could be 80, and this one, I think just 40!!The only one thing makes me still keeping this, is this camera has amazing DV quality. The quality of HD movie generated by this ELPH300 is even better than many camera-recorders, but it is really small and easy to carry. So I decide  to keep it as a easy carried and wid-angle DV, but not a camera.Good: small, good movie quality.Bad: really bad photo quality. white balance is not accurate."
20111126"
column883:
I have a DSLR (Olympus E510) that I use for all my travel and really important events. I always take a 'back up' camera and I wanted something small.  I took my new Canon Elph to Germany, Austria and Prague last month and it captured some great pictures that I could not get with my DSLR or I didn't want to carry it).  I love this Canon!  My oldest daughter had it first and praised it (she has a Nikon D3000 DSLR) and now I have purchased another one for my youngest daughter.  It takes really great pictures and is awesome in low light.  I highly recommend this camera for any one.  Definitely buy a little protective case to avoid any problems (which should be obvious)."
20111125"
column885: Camera operates great, case feels flimsy
column886:
I've been a long time lover of Canon point and shoots, and this is my third.However, immediately out of the box - this camera just felt cheaper than my others (I'm replacing a Canon SD780 that I used for a couple of years). It feels more plastic-y, flimsy and the buttons less integrated. Trusting in Canon's reputation for quality I proceeded to unpackaging the rest of the accessories and charged up the battery.I at first bought the red case version after looking at the black version on display. I was disappointed that the red doesn't have the rubberized finish of the black.  And then was more disappointed that after just a few minutes of navigating menus and checking it out, I noticed a huge scratch on the camera. I don't recall bumping it, dropping it or doing anything that should produce such a huge scratch.  So I wrapped it up and took it back and got it exchanged for the black case version.  I'm hoping I just got a defective coating on that one, but do be cautious of the camera's finish if you opt for a colored one.I've been using the black case version since May 2011, and have been pretty happy with it. The wider angle lens as compared to my SD780 is definitely nice.  And I am able to get better shots in low light conditions. All and all tho, I consider this a transitional camera that I'll upgrade to something else soon enough. After just a few months of use, I feel ready for something better."
20111125"
column889:
I know there has been much talk about made in Japan vs China ones with regard to the zoom motor noise while recording video.  I ordered the silver one from Amazon (not a 3rd party seller) on 11/22/2011 and received it today and am pleased to see mine was made in Japan.  Now this may not be the case for everyone, but apparently they still have stock of the silver that is made in Japan.  Once I have time to play around with it I will update this with a real review of the product."
20111125"
column892:
I love this little camera, I had the Canon powershot sd 780 before, this camera is pretty much the same, with pretty much the only difference I saw was 1080 on the video and stereo sound. It has a black flat finish which is nice , you don't get the scratching on the body that I did on the old one. The pictures are great and the Video is fantastic. I was hoping the sound would have been a little better, I usually video some of the live bands , and was hoping for better audio, but was a little disappointed. Over all its a Canon, and you really cant go wrong with Canon, the price was good, and the shipping was fantastic, literally 1 1/2 days , and that was with free shipping. Bottom line is I love the Canon Powershots, so much, that I bought this one over my last one, strictly for the 1080."
20111125"
column895:
I've been checking this camera out for a few weeks now and it was $150 a while ago, jump back up to $179 and now back to $150. The only difference is that now, the 8gb class SD card and the HDMI cord is included. It is also tax-free(CA) and free shipping. I couldn't miss out on the offer so I had to get it. Now I gotta wait a week for it to come x]"
20111124"
column897: Not the smallest but the biggest in value
column898:
Canon's pronouncements for this camera practically holler out that it's the 'thinnest in the world!'  Sorry, but Canon's SD-780, which is now out of production but still selling on Amazon, takes honors as the company's smallest in height, width, and breadth.  So if bragging rights are important to you, be prepared to pony up twice as much for the SD-780 (which has become an 'appreciating asset').  I loved my 780 before I lost it but was not about to pay twice as much to replace it.  The Canon Elph 300 marks a return on the part of the company to the qualities that made their Canon SD 1000-1200 subcompacts as well as the SD-780 the runaway favorites, if not only choice, among 'casual' consumers looking for a convenient but capable point-and-shoot subcompact.To my eyes, the 300's photos are every bit as good as the SD-780's, while the 5X-power lens makes it more flexible and useful than the 3X-power lens of the SD-780, which didn't qualify as having either a wide-angle or a telephoto lens.  I see some reviewers expressing regret that the 300 doesn't boast even more megapixels than 12. But the enthusiasts and pros (or serious photographers who insist on a genuine SLR monster) are demanding fewer megapixels, not more.  16 mps won't necessarily get you better resolution or sharper pictures but it will eat up all the space on your memory card in a hurry, especially if you use the very good video capabilities of either of these cameras.  As a result, the higher-end 'bigger' cameras are now likely to compromise at 10 megapixels rather than chase a popular consumer market obsessed with higher numbers.The 300 has few manual over-rides and is unlikely to satisfy someone hoping to win top honors in a photo-shoot.  But it's a dependable yet versatile little thing (with 1080p video and a stereo mic!) that's user-friendly, intuitive, and a quick read (some of the manuals with the bigger cameras require months of studying).  If you need further assurance, pick up Consumer Reports Buying Guide for 2012.  Out of 139 sub-compact cameras, the Canon Elph 300 comes in 9th place.  (The Canon S95 places 2nd out of the 139, but it'll cost you at least twice the price of the Canon Elph 300.  On the other hand, the Leica V-Lux 20 will cost you more than 4 X more than the Canon 300, yet it's rated lower by CR, which places it in the 10th spot.)There are those who will pay these inflated premiums in order to claim that they own the world's smallest camera (the Elph 780) or that theirs is a, gasp, 'Leica'!  I'm happy to give them that advantage and simply enjoy the shots I'm getting from this pocket rocket (definitely superior to my wife's iPhone).  If you're a 'serious' photographer looking for a 'side-kick' accessory camera, or if you're looking for a camera that will last for a good while under adverse conditions, the Canon S95 subcompact may be the better choice if you can afford it.  It has a lens of 'only' 10 megapixels, and video resolution of 'only' 780 pixels.  But fastidious photographers know that those numbers are merely manufacturer's consumer 'bait.'  The S95 would definitely appear to be the better-built camera with more user-accessible, manual features than the fully automated, lightweight, slightly smaller 300.  There are copious examples of shots taken from both cameras on the web--dpreview, steves-digicams, cnet, etc.  I've studied them and frankly don't see consistently superior image quality from the S95 when comparing it to the 300. So the S95 represents an 'investment' in a more rugged, hobbyist camera, for someone who shoots RAW and fusses around in Photoshop.Since photography is no longer my main focus in life, I'm content with the performance of the 300 and am simply hoping it holds up as well as an S95.  As for the world's thinnest camera, the 300 is .8' thin; the discontinued SD-780 was/is .7' thin.  Not enough of a difference to motivate me to replace my prodigal, long-lost, once-lamented Elph 780.  The 300 has already erased lingering regrets over its absence."
20111123"
column901:
I have had many canon sd cameras before and was pretty happy with all of them. This camera is not really canon quality. It has a flimsy plastic-hinged door over its battery/memory card compartment - it is a matter of time when it breaks. The pictures come out very soft and there is a horrible lens noise when zooming in/out. The product I received is made in china. May be this has something to do with the quality. I am returning the camera - big disappointment. Please read other reviews of the camera before buying it. Good luck!"
20111123"
column904:
I really like this camera, it is very small and it takes great pictures and I mainly bought it for short video's and it does a great job too.  I recommend it if you need a good camera at a good price for pictures and videos."
20111122"
column907:
Bought this as an upgrade for a digital canon I had bought in 2005... LOVE IT. So many functions and very quick response time. I really like the size and weight of it, as well as the rough/textured surface- it keeps you from dropping it. I took it to Hawaii with me, and though I usually use my DSLR out there, this camera was perfect for my most recent trip. AWESOME picture quality.Buy it, it does not suck. :)"
20111121"
