column909: Great Burst Mode" for Action Shots"
column910:
Have had this camera for a month or two now from a previous purchase. But saw the great price just now and decided to get another. This camera meets all of the needs I have in taking photos of dogs at the local animal shelter to help get them adopted. What I needed was something great in low lighting without flash due to the shiny reflection off of dogs' eyes with flash, as well as a super fast burst mode to try to capture that just right pose when the dog smiles, but without having to guess when the dog will smile.  So I just start pressing and it takes like 8-10 shots in a second or so.  Fantastic!  And the HD video of course is great, which I use to make videos of the dogs playing with toys or with other dogs to show off they energy levels or socialability with other dogs of various personalities.Don't shop, adopt a shelter pet! :O)"
20111121"
column913:
I just love it,I'm canon fan and i think this is one of great point and shoot camera in this price range."
20111121"
column915: Yet another spectacular failure from Canon
column916:
I simply don't understand how this camera managed to get so many positive reviews.Yes it's compact, fast, pretty and inexpensive. But it fails where it matters most - producing quality images in auto mode.Pictures are coming out soft, non-contrast, underlighted. And wide angle lens added a new 'feature': if your picture features tall objects on the sides (trees, buildings), and is shot below horizontal optical center, they would be 'falling down' to the middle of the picture. Big way falling. Pisa tower falling. Get your cropping skills polished.I bought this camera as a replacement for SD1400, which had another big problem - 'soapy' corners on most pictures. So far I don't see how the new camera is better - it's still a lot of cropping, with even less contrast.I think, Canon got too carried away with adding new features and forgot about the most important thing - quality of the picture.The last reliable Elph I had was SD1200. With less pixels, less macros it was producing far better quality pictures than anything that came from Canon after it.Something tells me it's my last point-and-shoot from Canon. Very disappointed.Update 11/23/2011: returned to AmazonUpdate 12/02/2011: just got a Canon SX230 - what a difference! Such a quality pictures, minimal distortion on a wide shots, and 14x zoom is simply unbeatable for the size. Should have bought it from the beginning.Let me just re-iterate my findings: Canon 300 HS is simply a bad camera producing bad pictures, looks like Canon had cut a lot of corners while making it. Spend few bucks more and get yourself a real camera, not a cute toy."
20111121"
column918: AWESOME camera especially if you have kids!
column919:
We got this last week, and HOLY COW this is the most awesome camera! We have a 3.5 year old daughter who is very active, and a  baby boy on the way. We had a friend visiting with her 7 month old daughter, and using the high speed burst function I was able to get the most awesome pictures of the girls together. I can't wait to play with all the other settings, but I know the high speed burst will be my go to. The high speed burst function is an absolute must if you have kids! Point, hold down the shutter button, and it takes pictures continuously until you remove your finger. When perusing them on the computer you get a neat flip book effect too!Another awesome feature is the switch between auto and manual. When you turn off the camera, it automatically comes back to whatever setting you had it last. Even if you remove the battery, it still comes back to that feature! The screen is nice and large, and the slightly roughened texture of the camera makes it nice and secure so you won't drop it. This camera is fabulous!"
20111119"
column922:
I'm very satisfied with my new Canon PowerShot camera.  It's very easy to operate and I find the pictures sharp and the colours excellent. The camera is small and light and can easily be kept in my handbag."
20111119"
column924: Didn't like rough texture of body, unlike past Canon's
column925:
I have owned the Canon cameras for a while, upgrading every 2 yrs.  This one I returned.  I'm sure it's a nice camera, but the new anti-slip feel on the outside body of the camera feels like sandpaper - so not a nice experience holding the camera.  They probably did it to make it non-slip, but end result is a nasty sandpaper feel."
20111118"
column927: One of the best point of shoot I've ever had
column928:
I owned tens of pos in the last tens of years, i think this is one of the best pocket camera I've owned. I was considering about to have another camcorder to replace an old Sanyo. now I realize I can take this slim baby instead of taking the heavy 5D II and all lens or Pentax-7/X and camcorders. It does all general routing jobs. Image is quite crispy,and super wide range lens perform just wellafter playing a while, I immediately got another one for dad.highly recommended"
20111118"
column930: Moving metal broken in just 1 week
column931:
I just started using this Canon Power Shot ELPH 300 HS.  The metal clam shell that opens and closes every time you prepare to shoot stopped opening in the 1st week of actually using the camera.  It might have been due to the fact that I did not get the accessories package with it and get the case that comes with it.  It also did not come with a flash card so i could not start using it when I first received it, I did not see any mention about that when I bought it.  If they did say something it did not jump out at me.  Now I'm stuck on a 3 leg trip with only a cell phone camera.  I will replace it but I would not buy it new again.  Very disappointing!"
20111117"
column933: Did not live up to expectations...
column934:
I had this for a few months before I sold it.  Granted this is a P&S, but I expected this camera to take images at least as good as my 2008 Lumix FX500.  It does not.  I thought most of my images were out of focus but now I think it just takes very soft images.  It applies way too much noise reduction which I think leads to the softness, but also in some of my images the subjects, whether they be people, foliage, etc., appear fake and smooth-like.  The images also have a general feeling of haziness with the colors muted.  I really don't know what was going on and how Canon could make such a bad camera.  I tested all settings and experimented with the limited manual control and nothing made it better.  I am giving Canon another shot and since purchased an S100.  I immediately noticed the images were much better, albeit at a different price point."
20111117"
column936: Some are made in China, some in Japan
column937:
I really like this camera since upgrading from a Canon SD1100 IS.  Hd video is a much needed upgrade however if you do alot of video you would still be better off with a dedicated camcorder.  The HD quality is way better than on my SD1100 which was only low quality SD.The black color looks good and the gritty feeling on the paint job makes it less likely to slip out of your hand.  The red color is very slippery in comparison.  I ordered the black and red and found out I like the black better.  Red was too slippery and bright but thats just a personal preference.  I found out that both the black and red were made in China.  However I seen the same camera at a Target and Best Buy and both the black and red were made in Japan.  I would rather have Made in Japan.  My old SD1100 was also made in Japan. So unless you buy it from retail store you won't know for sure.  However, Amazon's price is usually better..There are many new settings for taking pictures and the menu and feature layout is very familiar to the SD1100.  The changes that were made I like better.  Overall satisfied with this camera so far except for being made in China. Maybe Amazon could start adding where the product is from or manufactured so customers can have one more piece of information before deciding to buy.  I think for the price and features this is a great camera for a good price."
20111115"
column939: BEWARE Made in China Version !! Get Made in Japan
column940:
Got the camera today but unfortunately I got MADE IN CHINA instead of MADE IN JAPAN ! There are different !Made in China, when you recording video and zooming, you will hear Zoom motor sound !Made in Japan, there is no noise or sound when you recording video and zooming. And of course Made in Japan last longer than Made in China.Other than that, the Camera produce good quality of picture. Better than my Canon SD 780 especially in low light.I'm returning mine and looking for 'Made in Japan'"
20111114"
column943:
I am getting to the point with point and shoots where I tire from losing shots because of the delay between shots but am not ready to put money out for a SLR camera. This camera is perfect for me."
20111114"
column946:
After all the good reviews we read, we finally decided on this one.  I've always had Canon's and love them.  We've been trying to replace our 6 year old Canon Powershot A620.  It's 7.1 Megapixel, the pictures are great, but it's a little slow and it's also bulky.  We tried a Lumix last year and even though it was a 12 megapixel camera, the shots were not coming out as sharp as our old Canon.  So we returned it.  We decided to give this Elph a try.  What we liked:  the small size, the quick shots, and lots of neat features.  What we didn't like...once again, the old Canon's shots were coming our sharper.  Hard to believe.  We did some more reading and found that these higher megapixels compacts don't always mean sharp shots.  Now we are returning this one too."
20111113"
column948: 7 yr. old Olympus 4MP camera has given me much much better results
column949:
As many others have pointed, I really don't understand why this camera is getting such high rating. Either people haven't seen better (I've a hard time believing this) or they have forgotten and got used to these days' low standards.I bought Olympus C4000 - 4 MP - camera in 2004 Apr. It has produced amazing results. Very rarely it used to let me down, if at all. It had no optical image stabilization either.Contrast that with Elph 300 with 3 times higher res. and optical IS. Out of my first 68 shots, only 2 or 3 turned out really crisp. I don't have time to debug why it didn't produce better results. Off it goes back to the vendor (note that I didn't buy it from Amazon).Really, really disappointed."
20111113"
column951: Compact and easy to use, not very good without flash
column952:
I had high hopes for this Canon considering I had previously owned one, but am disappointed in the functions and features it offers. While there is the basic automatic mode and there is a manual mode, the manual mode lacks sophisticated options. The zoom is pretty decent but trying to use the camera in manual mode with no flash leaves you with blurry pictures. If you are looking for a simple point and shoot then this is great camera for you, if you are looking for a camera with some customizations then I would go another route. I purchased this one because I was hoping to get the quality of a Canon and the simplicity of use for my husband's usage. I find myself retaking pictures quite frequently because I'm just not happy with the quality."
20111113"
column955:
My wife absolutely loves this camera. We have the older version which is great, but this one has a few more additions my wife had to have( better zoom, better megapixals, but most of the fishbowl effect)."
20120512"
column958:
This Canon Powershot ELPH 300 is a nice step-up from earlier versions of the same camera, retaining the handy small size while improving the mega pixel rating to 12.1 and while refining the operating system.  This reviewer used the Canon ELPH Powershot 10.1 mp version for years with good results, and found this updated version easy to master.The texture of the camera casing is roughened, a little like very fine industrial sandpaper, making the camera easier to hold under wet/cold conditions.  The kit includes the usual cables for downloading images and printing using a computer and/or a printer.  The digital camera software for image manipulation seems straightforward and intuitive to use.  For this reviewer, the Canon Powershot ELPH 300 is highly portable, a great camera for happy snaps, and good for general indoor/outdoor photography; highly recommended."
20120509"
column961:
I did a lot of research and I think I probably would have LOVED this camera except the texture of it is like sandpaper and it really bothers me. So much that its uncomfortable to hold. I think there are a lot of people who wouldn't be bothered by this, but for me its so unpleasant that I am returning it and buying the silver one instead, which I understand has a more normal texture/finish. I had the Canon S95 in the past and it had a faintly rough texture which I really liked, and this camera is totally different. If you are used to the texture of the S95 this one is not the same.Aside from the texture, the camera is great. I expect that I will like it just as much as the Canon S95 that I used previously. It does feel a bit small in your hand. I'm sure that after a short period of time, I would get used to that and appreciate the convenience of the small size."
20120507"
column964:
I purcchased this camera for my 84 year old mother. I wish it had a neck chain. I don't think she would lose it so often then!"
20120505"
column966: Great Point-&-Shoot, like all PowerShot Elphs
column967:
Great camera.  Produced great shot after great shot during a two week vacation.  Very slim and fits easily and unobtrusively in a pocket.Canon's DIGIC image processor does a fantastic job producing great pics.Hard to go wrong with Canon PowerShot Elphs."
20120503"
column969: Great pictures IF the camera worked!!!!!
column970:
I am returning my second Canon PowerShot Elph today.  Both had issues with the lense.  The first time, the lense cover would sometimes open all the way, and sometimes not.  We were in Europe and traveled with it and it had issues at about 3 weeks.  Luckily we were within the time frame to return it, so did.  I liked the pictures it took, and thought the lense issue was a fluke, so ordered another one.  This time we got a 'lense error' where the camera would just shut off.  Again, luckily this happened within the 30 day period, so I am returning it and NOT getting a new one.  Love the photos it takes, but if it doesn't work, than the photos do not matter.  DO NOT RECOMMEND!!!!!!!"
20120503"
column973:
I am also using this (with proper under water housing, and filter sold separately) for scuba diving as well. I get great photos and HD videos both on land and under water. I highly recommend it. PS: Matter of fact I bought another one for my spouse."
20120503"
column976:
I did some research before I bought this camera and it has paid off. I love this camera. It is very easy to use, is compact and easy to carry and have had no battery issues whatsoever. Highly recommend."
20120501"
column978: I haven't taken a bad picture yet!! Great camera
column979:
Image quality is top notch for such a compact camera.Fit perfectly in the palm of your hand.Very textured finish, but helpful for a good grip."
20120501"
column982:
Awesome camera.Canon makes a great product at an affordable price.Takes wonderful pictures, downloads easily, software interfaces well with Windows Photo Gallery.Durable, small, automatic feature great, just point and shoot."
20120429"
column984: Excellent for shooting on the go
column985:
Took this with me to California and I was able to get the feel of it relatively quick. The low-light setting was impressive and the features are easy to manipulate without fussing with a lot of menu options. Great idea with the sandpaper exterior - helps keep a tight hold on it.It's so small and compact that I'm sorry to say I've misplaced it...deciding whether or not to go with this again or the Canon PowerShot S95.For the price, this camera is a MUST-HAVE!"
20111113"
column987: PowerShot is a Powerful Little Camera, but....
column988:
Small, light, great purse or pocket camera to take along for spur of the moment snaps.Easy to use interface - great image quality.The star downgrade comes from the noticeable lag on the process time for the ELPH 300 - so if you need super fast pictures, you will definitely be frustrated. Even turning off image preview does not speed it up enough.Love the camera, but find the gap of time from snap to being able to snap again significant."
20111112"
column991:
I have been purchasing Canon Powershots since 2004. By now I have owned a dozen of different models. So far, this is the best Elph yet. Last year I have purchased SD4000 when it just came out. At $350 I was expecting solid performance. Well, I returned it in one week and decided that the then current lineup did not offer anything to meet my expectations. Now, at under one fifty, this 300HS is everything that I wanted and more.What I like:1. Full HD2. Stereo recording3. AF and optical zoom in movie mode!4. 24mm W I D E and bright f2.7 lens5. Slim, really slim6. Black color has sand-paper finish, great for secure grip7. Dedicated record button8. Plenty of cool features (slow-motion, photo effects)9. Lowered MPixels, no more ridiculous MP race!10. Low light performance11. My old 4GB class 4 SD card was sufficient for full HD videos, no need for expensive fast cardsNot so great:1. Short flash range (but flash is tiny so ok)2. No time-lapse (but Canon has systematically removed this feature from most models; why!?)3. Some optical zoom vibration at far end of the zoom, visible in videos4. Analog AV cable included. That's so 90's!!! Throw in mini HDMI worth 50 cents!5. Display resolution could be better to compete with AMOLEDFor the ongoing price of under one fifty, you can't find a better performer."
20111112"
column993: A compact photographic marvel to have in your pocket daily or night out,...portable, intelligent - it delivers.
column994:
Amazing performance & value for point & shoot category - a particular bonus is its low light white balance feature & HD video, previously available in higher end models only.Purchased this recently for my 84yo mum who decided she wanted a camera to take some photos for her scenic cruise.This fits the bill perfectly. It you don't want to have to think or tinker too much with the camera, this little marvel will do all the work for you surprisingly well.+s==It's simplicity - ease of use is a key consideration for beginnersSUPER intelligent auto sensors ensure consistent quality images are achieved each time for a wide range of scenarios.AMAZING low light performance - allows quality evening/ concert/ nightlife shots - the biggest plusAn 24mm ultra wide angle lens for scenery capture is another big plusReasonably fast capture (scenery & poses) though can't compare with the DSLRs (better for candid ppl shots)Optical stabilizer alleviates any shakeSlim, lightweight portability ideal for travelHD video recording for capturing time-s==Ironically though, its slim build and the smoothness of the Silver finish lacks grip, hence some ppl with stiff fingers may find it slippery & encounter problems gripping & operating it. Esp so for large knobby hands.Plastic shutter button not as definitive in feel - esp during pre-shot focusing - however not a dealbreakerSome hv reported the problem of some shaking during video zoom between 3.8-4.8x but I doubt mum will be using that feature! [Update: Ive just seen the video clip on 'the shake' - be good to fix this though it is not as bad as I had envisaged, probably forgivable for beginners, as the audience will probably think it's the cameraman and not the camera.For most ppl, this camera will have more than enough.  Which explains why it tops the charts.An additional consideration:  If grip is important, then the black textured finish may be a better option. However I have also read that the textured finish tends to pick up lint along the way and may be difficult to keep clean, plus tends to get snared in one's pockets (the good out of this is that it doesn't drop out nor gets pick-pocketed as easily).  It is interesting that colour choice could have such large implications. Perhaps the product description should state the textural differences as I'm sure it was intentionally different to provide choice in taste & functionality.I, OTOH buy most things in silver, in this case I was beginning to wonder if I had made the right choice as I had bought it for an elderly person with a little arthritis - she had found it rather slippery and I had subsequently read about the black casing providing better grip.  Well ... at least this clears it up. I would loathe having to try and remove lint from its sandpaperish surface.  Hopefully over time, grip could come with a little practice."
20111111"
column997:
The problem with this, and other Canon cameras that use this video format (.mov), is that it is only compatible with the Mac, not PC/Windows.  No amount of updating QuickTime, codecs, or other software, would allow the video to play smoothly, and be edited with a PC/Windows machine.While the photos were excellent, the video was useless.  Returned for refund."

Plus the quality of the picture are very good for the price. this is my 3 canon so far my second one I droped it and is all put together with tape and still works."
20111111"
column1002: SMART, EXPENSIVE, EXCELLENT DESIGN & PHOTOS & EASE OF USE....
column1003:
I am a fan of Canon products I had been using Canon since I started clicking photos. I always have bought and recommended canon to anyone from an expert to a newbee to the photography. The product didn't come with memory card to buy any size over 4GB and makes sure class 10 for sure. The product has everything else that you need in the box.Let's begin with Quality of Product coz a lot say it look cheap and blah blah blah.... I bought Silver color of this Model. I opened the box and It was well packed in a foam bag. I slide it out.... and WOOOOWWWW!!!! I took a deep breath and wanted to yell. It had AMAZINGLY UNBELIVEBLY EXCELLENT FINISHING. The camera looked really good and great. In no way/aspect it looks cheaper. The size is so compact and thin. My friend was with me when I opened it and she was like WOW so cute small camera. She also bought it. So imagine if a person can just buy the camera looking at it, it's got to look great and good finishing.Now let's go to the photography part: I clubbed it with my Transcend 8GB class 10 memory which I bought separately with it. I have to say the memory is sufficient and photos that I took and transferred were great. The ZOOOOOOOOOOOOOOM is like I have written. You can see clear things from a distance without any distortion (but don't try to shoot moon from this camera). Anyways the Video part wow I was spell bounded by the stability feature no pixilation of any part and yes FULL HD 1080p. I connected it to see it on a projector through an HDMI cable. I saw it on 105 inch screen and then in my conference hall HD projector and no pixilation anywhere. It comes with Video zoom to good and stabilized level with a great video output. The camera offers a zoom of 5X and if you push further it offers 20X zoom and NO PIXILATION at all. Stabilty factor remains true and yes I can read and see everything clearly.So I would say forget this camera looking Cheap or plastic. It looks CLEAN, EXCELLENT, EXPENSIVE AND GREAT VALUE.The usage of menu is very easy and simple just like previous canons. Has been updated and looks better and easy to move and select options. No messing around and getting confused with the touch options. I have tried touching camera menu on different camera and believing me every time clicked something else so this is good with buttons to press and manage. Only I wish it had Panoramic Photo click ability.Comes with feature rich in it I didn't even have had time to use all but wanted to write this review to make sure if someone is planning to buy this and drops out thinking looks cheap may be give it another thought. I have silver and don't look cheap at all. Something about my taste I don't like cheap anything either. So I would say take my chance on Silver color.I would recommend if you are looking for Value for money product and GREAT AND FULL RICH EXPERIENCE OF HD POCKET CAMERA!!!"
20111111"
column1006:
My expectation of a point and shoot camera had dwindled over time, but the vivid colors and quality of the pictures that come out of this camera impressed me.  For the price this camera is offered it is a great bargain"
20111110"
column1009:
You say you want a user-friendly, small digital camera that you can pull out of your pocket and get greats shots on the spur of the moment? You're looking at the right camera. The end of Dec 2010 I purchased a Nikon digital (with manual options) for between $300 and $400 and in the few months I tried to use it never got a really good shot of anything or anyone. In June of 2011 I purchased this Canon Elph 300 and as soon as I opened it, I knew I had the right camera. I have had SLR's so I'm not ignorant about camera operation, but the Canon is so much more 'user-friendly' than the Nikon it's not funny. I know it's all in what you want - and in someone else's hands, good photos could probably be taken with my Nikon - but if you want a no fuss, easy to use camera - this is THE ONE!!!  S Sergent"
20111110"
column1012:
I bought the Elph 300 HS after much research and deliberation, as a replacement for another Canon camera I had owned for years, and broke through my own carelessness. I've had good experiences with Canon quality before, so I was already leaning in that direction. I also didn't want to spend more than $200.This camera has exceeded all my expectations. It is truly lightweight, I have no problem taking it with me on everyday excursions, just in case I see something I think would be worth shooting (my camera phone is woefully inadequate). It is also VERY durable. I have dropped this camera twice (not in its case), both times from about four feet above the ground. Once it landed on concrete, the other time on a wood floor. As a result, the black casing is slightly scuffed up now, although it's not hugely noticeable. AND, the camera has continued to work perfectly. Considering we live in an age where so many things are made withough much regard to quality, since it is expected that we'll re-buy/upgrade our possessions constantly, I am truly gratified to see that Canon obviously made this camera intending for it to last.As to image quality, I am an amatuer, not really even at enthusiast level yet, but I think the image quality is really great. I also appreciate all the different scene modes and filters, and it's been so interesting working with them, that this camera actually inspired me to pursue photography again more seriously. I have a Nikon DSLR, but it was too much to lug everywhere, so I kind of just abandoned photography in general. But the Elph 300 has been so much fun to use, it inspired me to buy another digicam with shutter and aperture priority modes, so I can get back to exploring photography more fully yet still conveniently (and maybe even put my Nikon to full use someday).Speaking of manual controls, that's really the only thing this camera lacks (it does have Program mode, so you do have a bit of control over white balance and ISO). The Elph 500 does have the manual controls the 300 lacks, but I despised the touch screen, which I found was not nearly as responsive as, for example, an iPhone. But, keep in mind, this camera was never intended to be targeted to people who want full manual control. It's a small, take anywhere point and shoot that takes great pictures without you having to fiddle with it or think much about it. And as I said, there is some increased flexibility with the filters and scene modes provided (and there are quite a few of them).There may be a learning curve with the menu system for non-Canon users, but nothing that a little bit of time and the manual (in PDF form, it's not printed) wouldn't take care of. Current Canon owners will find it very familiar and easy to use.I would recommend this camera whole-heartedly for anyone who wants a lightweight P&S with great image quality, that's also simple to use and still provides a good number of creative options. This would be a wonderful intro camera to those completely new to digital photography. I gave this camera 5 stars because, for the audience it's intended for, it's an oustanding choice, and one which I can't find any fault with. People who want full manual controls will need to look elsewhere (e.g. higher-end digicams and DSLRs), but for a well-built, no-fuss camera you can take anywhere and have a lot of fun with, this is an excellent choice."
20111110"
column1014: Excellent camera for a very low price

In point-and-shoot terms, this is one of the best out there. Good sensor quality, impressive shutter delay and vast array of options. The camera feels solid in your hands as if it would stand a beating without a hitch."

Several months ago, I found myself looking for a new 'point & shoot' and decided upon a Nikon Coolpix 3000 since I think so highly of my Nikon D40 SLR. What a mistake. column1023: This camera worked flawlessly with the AAXA P4 Pico Projector
column1024:
I take pictures all the time and need to share them in class with everyone. For a point and shoot camera this camera has great potential to take fast decent quality shots. I can then connect it to my P4 and show the class examples of how to take quick pictures. This works for me, because we often go around the campus and I can project anywhere on the white walls. I can also show the students the view I am seeing through the camera and the angles I need in order to make it work because of the projector. This is a battery intensive process and the Canon PowerShot ELPH doesn't die on me even though I virtually have it on and projecting the entire time. Would recommend."

column1074: Nothing amazing here... just ok image quality
column1075:
Either people have lower expectations in terms of image quality or I got a lemon. I'm comparing mine to Canon S410 that I also own.Issues with this camera:1. Camera keeps switching 'scenes' in Auto mode and it's often choosing incorrectly:  a) It tries to do tracking when no tracking is required  b) It often fails to detect macro mode2. Focusing algorithm in Auto mode often refuses to choose a subject that I'm actually interested in. Example: it would often ignore people in the foreground and focus on some background instead.=> 1 and 2 make Auto mode unusable for me...3. Focus is soft most of the time (S410 didn't have this problem). Focus is especially soft in image corners. Changing 'Sharpness' in Custom Colors in Program mode does help a bit.4. In macro mode it's often impossible to make it focus on the feature you want even using Program mode with center focusing with small frame size (S410 didn't have this problem). It would either not focus at all or claim it focused producing an image that is visibly out of focus. I had many flowers that 300 HS would refuse to focus on while S410 focused just fine.5. Noticeable chromatic aberrations in high contrast photos: anything bright will have an aura around it.6. Noticeable barrel distortion at widest angle: don't photograph people unless they are in the center of the shot.7. It tends to overexpose outdoor pictures.8. It likes to set aperture to f/8.0 (and sometimes above) instead of staying at f/2.7. This adds to image softness.What I do like:1. It's small and light.2. It shoots surprisingly good movies.3. It performs reasonably well under low light conditions (CMOS sensor vs. CCD in S410).I use mine in Program mode only, center focus, with sharpness tuned all the way up."
20111024"
column1078:
I bought this on Amazon because I read a bunch of reviews on other websites (cnet, ect.) and they all recommend it. I've had many digital cameras, fujifilm 4800 (from 2001),  this is my 3rd canon elph. the first was a 6mp 630s (sold long ago) and it was very good. I then bought the canon 790IS which is very good too (still have it), I then bought a samsung NV24 because it was basically the first point and shoot with HD video (720p), Then I got this last week and played around and I've come to the conclusion this is an AMAZING tiny camera. The picture quality for a small camera is incredible (12.1 MP). I have to say the outdoor pictures can almost rival my Canon 40D and Rebel T2i at low ISO. Video is very good too. The 1080p is excellent (even though it is only 24 fps) This is the point and shoot to get if you want the best out there for under $200."
20111024"
column1081:
I love this camera the video 1080p is really good the quality of the pictures is excellent very good camera for this price"
20111024"
column1083: decent camera but I would not recommend it, especially for the money!
column1084:
LIKES:  1) Good image quality, very neutral color and smooth, records HD video with zoom.  2) Extremely compact.  3) User friendly and logically placed controls - such as the quick 1-touch video and the slide lever to switch the program/auto mode.  4) Brisk, quick operation such as the start up and shot-to-shot times.  5) Bright LCD visible even under the bright sunlight.  6) Decent battery life.DISLIKES:  1) The LCD is very low in resolution, looks like it's from 2003. Many pictures looked sharp on the LCD even when zoomed in, but they were blurry on the computer screen.  I do not have this problem with my similarly priced Sony WX9 which has a super high resolution LCD.  2) Rounded, curved, bubbly design maybe cute but it is slippery in the hand, increasing the chance of you dropping it. Also it will not stand upright easily, it is very tippy.  Which means if you set it on top of something to snap a timed picture or a night shot, there is good chance it will tip over, drop, and get heavily damaged.  3) All images are VERY SOFT even at the finest compression setting. There is no way to crank up the sharpness inside the camera. Expect to use software to crank up the sharpness on EVERY image  you decide to keep, which is a tedious and time-consuming task.  4) The HD video is limited to only 10 minutes which is stupid and just short enough to piss you off. On the Sony WX9 recording time is limited as well, but at 29 minutes, it is decent and just  long enough to be satisfying because usually the battery will expire before the cut off time. It also gobbles up a HUGE amount of memory as well!  5) Battery cover looks and feels EXTREMELY flimsy. Opening the cover shuts off the camera, which means hot swapping memory cards is not possible. It takes quite a bit of force with your thumb  to close the slippery cover, and it feels very unrefined, coarse and cheap with no positive tactile sensation at all. It also feels like it's going to break any minute which is annoying."

column1113: Video is a downgrade from older models
column1114:
This is my fourth Canon point and shoot camera, and the first time I am disappointed. One of the reasons I use my camera is to shoot some short videos at concerts. Each generation of Canon camera has been better than the previous one, until now.The biggest failure is that video is handled via a button, and not a setting. That means focusing is no longer an option. In a concert setting, with flashing lights and so much movement, the camera does a poor job of auto-focusing, leaving you with bad results.On top of that, the microphone seems to be of worse quality than previous models.Yes, we can zoom in now (a welcome feature) but if the video starts out blurry, zooming makes things worse. You need to stop filming and try again.And finally, the location of the button is hard to push, so most video start out shaky, because pushing the button moves the camera.Aside from the video mode, there has been a bad change in the camera mode. 'Micro' is not handled the same as it was before, and especially in Auto mode, this camera always defaults to Micro before focusing on what's actually happening. So if you want to quickly pull out the camera and take a shot...don't. It will be in micro mode for whatever reason and takes a second to realize that you're trying to take a landscape picture."
20111017"
column1117:
Well I bought one of these on sale at Staples since they had a 20% off all Canon non-DSLRs. I wanted this to replace my old Canon SD 1300 that someone stole. This Elph 300 HS looks really nice, great feel, nice LCD in the back and takes great photos outside during the day. However, indoors it's just a mess. I took this to a birthday party, set it to AUTO and took pics but the people's faces looked really yellowish/orange and weird. Its like the camera didn't know what type of light I was shooting in. My old one did just fine and it was an older model. If I started tweaking in the P-mode and set the lighting and the ISO and a bunch of settings then the photos came out almost normal. I shouldn't have to do all that. I just want a camera to take decent pictures and not make people's faces orange in AUTO mode. It also has a hard time focusing. Seriously, your pictures will mostly look blurry indoors. Which is weird since this is supposed to be a low light camera. It can't even focus right. Look at all the great reviews this has.....from OUTDOOR pictures. You'll be surprised when you start taking pics with this and it sucks. I ended up taking the camera back. Now I'm looking for the older models since they appear to take better pictures but don't do HD video. That's okay though because I want a camera for the pictures!! I hope this will help you avoid making a big mistake thinking newer is better."
20111016"
column1120:
I thought I'd write this review for those of you who were considering either of these cameras. I did a lot of research as I always do when considering purchasing anything and this was no exception. After selling my Canon 40d, I wanted a simpler camera that I could take everywhere. I boiled it down between the 300, 310 and 510. I pretty much crossed off the 510 after seeing it had only an f3.4 lens coupled with the potential short battery life with the touch screen and the fact that someone said 'this is not like your iPhone screen'. So it was between the 300 and 310. I bought the black 300 that a major yellow tag big box store had in a package with an battery, case and card for a great price. After getting it home and doing a little follow up research regarding possible issues of these that were made in China, I found that mine was made in China so I went back and bought a red one made in Japan. So far so good. And I love the red over the black. I couldn't get used to the texture on the black one plus after seeing how bad the floor model look of the black one, I could just imagine how bad mine would be after continued use.So after using it for a week and loving it, I had the chance to check out the 310 in person when it arrived in the stores and decide if I should return the 300 or not and get the 310. The screen was bigger on the 310 and of slightly better quality but what made the final decision for me on which camera to keep was the placement and moreover the size of the menu and auto/program buttons on the side. Why they did this I have NO idea. If you have fingers bigger than that of a 5 year old then good luck manipulating the switches; especially the top one (I think it's the auto mode one). That alone sealed the deal. As I mentioned in a comment to one of the reviews on the 310, I would have to carry a paper clip or toothpick with me at all times to flip that switch--and I have narrow fingers. So all in all I am VERY happy with the 300 and love the many features it has. I was too much of a pixel peeper and that's why I bought the 40d but after hardly using it and taking so-so photos because I was not too savvy with it, I just gave up and sold it. I wanted a pocket camera that took good pictures that was easy enough for my wife to use and small enough to take anywhere. I found it in the Canon 300HS. No regrets!"

column1170: Great camera with a slight quirk
column1171:
Bought this camera for a recent vacation trip, and it worked quite well.  Found that some pictures taken without the flash in low light conditions actually came out a great deal better than when using the flash.  Not sure how it works that way, but definitely a plus.  Less use of the flash means more battery time.  The fully charged Canon battery would last for about 250 pictures before needing replacing.For those who have had problems with the lens shutters not closing completely, here is your probable problem and solution, as I encountered the same issue.  The metal that covers the lens shutter assembly is very thin, and very easily bent.  If the camera is set face down on a non-flat surface, or pushed up against something, it could easily tweak the metal lens cover.  When the lens shutters on my camera suddenly stopped closing completely, I took a closer look at the camera.  With the camera on, and looking down at the lens from the top of the camera, I could see that the metal covering the lens shutter assembly was slightly pushed in.  This was causing the lens shutters to catch, and not close completely.What I did was to grab a miniature flathead screwdriver, and carefully slide it between the lens and the metal cover.  Do not slide the screwdriver head across the lens, as this could scratch the lens.  With a minimal amount of upward pressure, I was able to straighten out the bent section of the metal.  Do NOT leverage the screwdriver against the lens, as this could scratch it as well.  Just gently lift the screwdriver with a slight pressure applied.  Since doing this quick and easy fix, I have had absolutely no problem with the lens shutters, and both repeatedly close completely.It took a few minutes to get used to how the camera functions were laid out in the menu, but once accustomed, making changes is quick and easy.  Pictures came out great, focusing happens quite quickly.  If Canon would use a slightly thicker metal over the lens assembly, I think that that would resolve many of the lens shutter issues, and they would have many more happy customers.In spite of this one quirk, I am very happy with this camera, and would not hesitate to recommend it to my friends and family."

20110923"
column1230: This an excellent little, inexpensive camera that is good at almost everything
column1231:
UPDATE AT BOTTOM...This is an excellent little camera in reference to what it is, a very small point and shoot, with very good picture, and HD video capabilities.  I am not comparing this to a 2700.00 Canon 5D Mark II, and neither should you.I have another inexpensive, HD video camera, the Sanyo CG20( a dedicated video camera) and the Canon blows it away in both High Def video, and still photography.You can consider me a semi pro, in reference to still photography, and I can tell you the still images that this little camera produces, are quite good.  Again, not comparing it to a DSLR.The camera is very small and light, and will make an excellent backpacking camera.  I haven't been taking a lot of still images, because I didn't want to pack one of my DSLRs, and carry an extra 5 or 6 lbs, plus the hassle of trying to fit it into an already over stuffed pack(40lbs), and then unpack it quickly, when a deer, or bear or something steps across the trail.Sound:This camera has two little stereo microphones, and the audio quality is quite good when it is in your hand. I haven't tried it on a tripod yet, and will update this review when I do.  After recording a video, and upon playback you can barely hear the audio in the field, but don't worry, it sounds fine when you play it back on your computer.Video Quality:Excellent for the cost and size of this camera, and quite good in general.  Good color balance, good exposure(when using Exposure Compensation) and good definition, and detailPhoto Quality:Again very good in the point and shoot realm, and good in general across the board, taking all camera styles into account.  I have 2 DSLRs for reference, and taking those into account, this is very good for what it is.Controls:Very good for a point and shoot.  It has a dedicated video recording button that works well, with the exception that when you push it upon stopping video, you will get a little shimey in the very last segment of your video.  Not a big deal, just trim it out.Advanced video, and Photo control:There are only two things this camera is missing as far as advanced controls.  One is manual focus capabilities, and the other is manual shutter capabilities for still photos.  With those two added, or even manual focus added, this would blow me away.Shutter Lag:From the reviews I read before hand, if you prefocus(push the shutter button down half way) it is one of the fastest point and shoot cameras, if you don't(and just push the button when you want to take a picture) it is one of the slowest...  .1 second if you prefocus, and .49 seconds if you don't.  In my experience, the camera definitely has some lag, but I expected this, and it isn't an issue for me.  It is MUCH faster than my mother in-laws older Sony, which has lag to a point that it is an issue.  I think advanced focusing algorithms slow the process down. I recommend that if you have the camera, try prefocusing, while you are waiting for the shot.Important outputs:Of course, USB to download to the computer, and a mini HDMI port to play directly on your High Def television.The not so nice:As I said, lack of manual focus, a slight tendency to overexpose(easily fixed with exposure compensation through the dedicated button), and you can barely hear the sound track when you play back videos in the field.For the cost, I bet this is one of the very best!  I am very pleased!For samples of video, and still pictures, go to my website at markdfellows. c o m and look at the very bottom of the 'Mark's Hiking page' link.A great camera!UPDATE AT OF OCTOBER 7TH, 2011:I wrote Canon an email and despite what the manual says about 'Exposure Shift' in movie mode, there is no manual settings for this.  Must be something the camera does internally.I found out that putting the camera in 'Aquarium, or Underwater mode'(the mode with a fish)gives you really vibrant, well saturated colors with good highlights, so try using that mode, for vibrant videos.  Be warned though, it can trash skin tones.I have just started playing around with aspect ratios, which you can set in this camera from 1:1 to 16:9(wide screen) which should give me hours of enjoyment.  I think I am going to try shooting in 16:9 mode.  I like the look.I definitely recommend you experiment with all the modes, it gives you some nice options, and in my case, led to me finding out that if I use that mode with the fish as the indicator, you will have well saturated colors and better highlights.  I have also tried a low light video with just a campfire that I am pretty pleased with the results.More videos are available by going to youtube, and typing in 'themarkfellows2' in the search field.  I hope this helps!  Good luck!"
20110921"
column1234:
I have a Nikon DSLR system for well over a decade now and thought I'd pick this up as a convenient camera to carry around.Picture quality is amazing for outdoor use. It struggles a little in low light.I do have some issues with the camera trying to shoot wide open.But overall it does a good job."
20110919"
column1236: Small and takes great pictures but doesn't last more than a week
column1237:
I had to exchange the camera twice and finally gave up and just returned it. Both times I had it, it broke within a week of using it. I love Canon cameras and was really disappointed with the quality of this one. The first time, the screen was black, and the second time, the lens got stuck in the out position and wouldn't take pictures. I definitely wouldn't recommend this camera to anyone."
20110919"
column1239: Great upgrade from our old Digital Camers
column1240:
Takes great photos & videos.  We'd recently brought a new puppy home with us who moves faster than we can get a picture of her that's not blurred.  The video & software that come with this model are outstanding.  I can now take a video of her and with the software that came with the camera freeze frames, save individual frames, print them out, email, download to our ipod, etc.  Gave it only 3 stars on Design layout ... the lower right corner on the back of the camera has so many setting buttons that I continue to accidentally touch while pointing & shooting to take a picture.  It's annoying, but since everything else is a 5 STAR I can learn to live with it.Over the weekend I used this camera to take photos of an art exhibit ... it was hosted in a showroom of a blown glass business that specializes in high-end hand blown glass pendants lights, so needless to say the setting although it was an evening event & had no natural light, the photos turned out wonderful. Colors were true to the artwork and none of them were washed out.I wanted a point-and-shoot camera that took really good photos and that's what I got."
20110918"
column1243:
For someone who is looking for a decent p&s, this camera is wonderful.  I bought it for my mother, and she loves the quality of the pictures, the ease of uploading it to her computer, and also the size of it.  We've had digital cameras before, but she just can't stop talking about this one.  Great camera, I highly recommend."
20110917"
column1246:
This is a great little unit and we have been fans of the elph line for a while.  However,  the lens cover has failed twice on this camera!  Canon should formally address this issue and create an official post on this product on Amazon.  Looks like many reviewers have had the same problem since June 2011.  I am getting my money back and will be buying something else...."
20110917"
column1249:
This camera replaced a Canon 1400sd with more megapixels, but seems to take even better pictures.  The Zoom travels a little to fast to control well.  The video is excellent.  Still some shutter lag as is common with these type cameras, but better than previous models.  Would definitely recommend it."
20110916"
column1252:
I have owned Canon powershot cameras for the last 6-7 years and have always been happy with photo and buid quality. After owning Canon SD870 for 5 years, carrying it to beaches, hiking, etc. I found it to be a bit bulky and wanted something that can shoot HD video for my trip to South America and also something smaller. I was really happy with the picture quality and videos, carried the camera in my pocket (in a case) all the time. Suddenly I saw that the shutter cover is not opening any more and I had to use my hand to open/close it for the whole duration of my trip (it was damaged maybe 10 days into my trip, no obvious hit that I felt that could damage the camera). After I returned, Canon estimated the damage to be $170. Needles, to say, I am not having it repaired and I seriously doubt I will continue buying Canon powershot cameras due to poor build quality. I treated it with care, but having a small portable camera that you have to put in a big protective case in order to avoid damage due to normal handling beats the purpose of the small form factor."
20110916"
column1255:
Shortly after I bought the ELPH 300HS, the lens cover wouldn't close. I had to push it closed with my finger. so, I sent it back and they quickly sent me a refurbished one. After using that one time, the lens cover broke again. This time I had to push the lens cover open with my finger because half of it stayed shut when I turned on the camera. So, I sent that back again for another factory reconditioned camera which I ended up selling it 50 dollars less then I originally paid. I've owned two other Canon SD/Elph model cameras and never had any problems with those.The photo quality was pretty good. not much improvement over their previous models. the best thing about this camera is the size and user interface. very fun and easy to use. too bad about the lens thing."
20110915"
column1258:
this camera is awesome, i wish it was a little easier to navigate the programmed settings (like on an older version elph), since they're all in one folder, but this camera rules.  really happy with it.  maybe my best canon yet."

I took this camera with me to Greece this summer and it was amazing.  The HS makes it good in low light and the different shooting modes help tremendously.  There is a night mode for handheld that takes 3 pictures then merges them into one good shot.  There is a sport mode that takes crazy fast (for a compact camera) shots at 3MP each.  The auto is awesome too. I have always used Canon and will continue to after my great experiences with this camera. You won't be sorry!!"

column1264:
Pros: I love taking pictures with this camera. The quality is really great. It is very compact.Cons: the color gets scratched off easily, camera needs a few seconds before you can take another picture."

column1267:

We purchased this camera for my mother. It took some reading to get to know how to use some of the features, but it is still much simpler to use than many cameras. It is very small, but produces excellent results. The video was equal to, or possibly even better, than the same video I took on my digital camcorder. I personally have an older small digital camera, an SLR digital camera, and a digital camcorder. However, I am seriously considering getting one of these to replace those in most situations."

column1273:
I bought this camera back in april and again today.  2 weeks ago my family was on vacation and when walking down to the lake, I began to fall.  I had to let something go and my options were: my daughter or this camera.  So I let the camera go...flying into the lake. :( luckily, I was able to retrieve all the photos off the card but the camera was dead.  Note: water and sand do NOT mix well with this camera. :)~Anyway, this is my 3rd canon and I will never buy another brand for my point-n-shoot.  It is the best for low light (indoors) and moving subjects (my kids).  Add in the new HD video and the slow motion (son playing t-ball for the first time; daughter walking for the first time) and this camera is THE camera for parents!!  You just can't get everything canon gives you for this price.I almost upgraded to the 500 this round...but $50 wasn't quite worth it to me for the touch-screen (though that sounds like a great feature...the way our phones are now).  The new video feature that takes 4 seconds around each of your photos and creates an automatic 'day' slideshow for you sounds pretty cool but I'm already running low on space on my card since I don't instantly transfer pics to my computer.Also, the battery length was getting listed as 'con' for that camera (I'm assuming because of the touch screen) and that is one thing I love about this camera.  I can take photos on and off all day for over a week before I am reminded 'oh ya, remember to charge the battery before our trip this weekend.'  But I have never had a fully-charged battery fail me on an entire weekend long trip.This is one amazing camera in the tiniest package yet.  And if you get the black one, the exterior has a nice, rugged texture.I would recommend this for any family member or friend...and you know I love it when I spend another $200 for the exact same camera less than 5 months later.  It just can't be beat!"

A real disappointment, and our family owns four Canons.  This one, seemingly the most sophisticated, is thrown by tricky light situations.  My son and I have both tried various options, from adjusting the white balance to the ISO level to shifting between auto and program.  Too many pictures are simply washed out.  My wife's simpler Canon never fails in low light conditions, but mine does.  It always involves experimentation, and grandchildren don't have that much patience.  Movies seem great.  I've had some problems with the lens cover too.  Sadly, I've ended up going back to my four-year old Lumix."

I was in need of replacing my point and shoot. I have been well-pleased with Canon products. This camera is a good value for the quality and price. I don't have much specific to review. On my old Canon, I would have to manually set it to the macro setting to get close-up shots, but this one does it automatically. I recommend :)"
20120425"
column1282:
This camera is proving to be perfect for my needs.  Those needs are for a small, relatively inexpensive camera that I can take with me in the car on the bicycle, motorcycle, kayak- you get the idea.  I have a great Nikon DSLR and a drawer full  of lens but it is too ackward to pack everywhere not to mention the concerns of dunking two grand plus in camera and lens..  But this little camera is more than just portable, it takes some excellent shots.  It has about 200 test shots on it now of panoramas, wildlife and some semi macro shots.  I must admit my camera elitism is suffering as this little thing has taken amazing shots.  As with any of these small sensor and lens cameras it does suffer in the extremes of its capabilities like fast movement and low light.  Even in those conditions it is surprisingly sharp and certainly acceptable for the price.  One thing I always do with cameras is mess with the controls before I read the manual to see how intuitive they are.  This is the easiest to operate camera I can recall.  The controls and menus just make sense.  I would think even without much photography background you could master these quickly.  Latter reading the manual in detail I was pleasantly surprised to see a lack of overly sophisticated controls on a simple camera.  Just enough flexibility to let you use the camera to its limits.I don't take many flash shots or use the video feature other than to test them out.  Both seemed very good but again that is not my area of expertise.Minor thing of note.  This camera is not small it is tiny.  If you have large fingers the controls can be a little tough to avoid hitting multiple controls at once but no big deal.Additional plus-  my black one has a textured, rough finish.  I love this.  Much easier to grip and none of that hockey puck problem on slick services.In summary- for the $149 I paid this is a great second camera, outdoor camera or even a first camera if you don't have extreme demands."

column1284: Awful for what I use it for

I bought this camera due to its ability to work in low light, and it's AP Tracking feature. I use this camera to take pictures of my pets, mostly reptiles. I can't stand that even in program mode, the F stop is fully automatic from what I can tell. This has been a problem with canon powershot cameras for years. That auto F-stop always gets it wrong, if you want a side-view of whatever you're shooting, expect it to be blurry. Sad to say, I much preferred the Powershot A560 to this.UPDATE: I have returned the camera. It seems mine was defective, the lens had discolored spots and looked foggy on the inside as if humidity got to it. Seeing as I took excellent care of the camera while I had it (and I live in a very dry area,) it seems it was done before I received it. I will not try purchasing this camera again. Maybe I will try Panasonic Lumix series cameras from now on."

Excellent little camera. I keep it in my shoulder bag, it is so easy to use, with excellent photos. Easy to carry about and quick to use."

I bought it on October 3, 2011, however, it broken April 9 2012. It can not work because of the lens error. Even then, I contact the Canon surport, they let me send it to their company, and I should pay the mail fee!!!!! So I think please consider my situation before you buy it."

I bought this camera to take on my recent trip to Key West. I had previously been using a Sony Cybershot (which is nice too) but I wanted to upgrade to more MP's and I was looking for a sleeker, smaller camera. i just got this from best buy a couple days ago but i would not buy a camera off of amazon reason why it would be a pain in the ass to return it if i wanted to but i just desided to make a review i used to be on 720p but when i got them camera im all at 1080p now I love it so i can make my youtube videos in full hd its a great camera so far and its small and can travle any ware easy i got a hard case for it it fits it my pocket find so make sure if you dont have that much monney but want to get a great camera get this cannon :)[...]"
20120415"
column1299: LCD Image Brightness and Flash Too Bright
column1300:
After reading most of the reviews, I decided that this would be a great gift for my sisters birthday. The price was affordable and there did not seem to be much of a huge difference upgrading to the newer models. In addition, I was looking for a simple point and shoot camera that would take quick shots, to avoid that 'oh please take that damn shot' moment, as you wait. The specs state 1.5 seconds, which is very respectable... until you use the flash. More on this below.This camera is very compact and easy to store in your pocket. The video is pretty clear and easy to record. The buttons are located in good locations and the color Red was very well received, making it easy to locate.Now for the problems:1) IMAGE BRIGHTNESS ON LCD SCREEN: The major problem, at least with the camera we received, is that the image brightness displayed on the screen does not match to those you will see on your computer. Of course, this is not a surprise, since the lcd on the camera only shows a small amount of pixels but the problem is not the clarity or color, but that of brightness. Photo's taken in low light situations with no flash will look bright enough on the camera's display but once you transfer to your computer, they are very completely dark and extremely grainy. Likewise, photo's taken with a flash look washed out on the screen but once transferred, look not as bright. Decreasing the screen brightness on the camera did nothing to elevate this issue. Defective screen?2) FLASH TOO BRIGHT:The flash is too bright and not controllable in either automatic or manual modes. This results in photo's that look too flash exposed and too many highlights in the face. Luckily, if the ISO setting is low enough, the photo's can be corrected in any photo editing software.3) AUTO ISO TOO HIGH & GRAINY: Although automatic mode is indeed handy for people who do not want to or know how to adjust settings. The flaw here is that the Auto mode decides which ISO setting to use, which in most situations is exceptionally high (i.e ISO 400 with Flash, ISO 1600 without). The higher the ISO the more grainy the images will be and the less pixel brightness information you have for photo retouching or correcting.The fix for this is to use manual mode and change the auto ISO to a value of 100 or 200. Make sure that your flash is set to auto or OFF, and this should result in a much better quality looking image with no pixel grain. When the flash goes off, you might get an overexposed image that is too bright, but since you have a lot of pixel information, you will most likely be able to adjust that in any photo editing software.4) TOO SLOW WITH FLASH: Although photo's taken without a flash are taken at an impressive 1.5 seconds, once you include the flash, that time dramatically increases to 3-4 seconds, where your models have to wait patiently with there frozen smiles that turn to grins.IMPROVEMENTS NEEDED (likely by purchasing another model):1) ISO Max, this way you can guarantee that the camera won't select such a high setting of ISO 1600. ISO 400 should really be the high limit.2) Flash brightness control. This would eliminate the need to correct for this in a photo editor. Auto Flash brightness based on ISO would be ideal.3) Ability to reuse last auto setting for next photo. This way, the camera does not need to recalculate focus, red eye, settings, etc all over again.4) An LCD that displays correct brightness of photo's taken (if my camera is not a defect).NOTE: In my defense, I should have been more aware that taking photo's in low lighting would result in a high AUTO ISO setting of 1600. I actually didn't notice that ISO until the day after. However, when I viewed this through the camera's lcd screen, they looked quite bright (even the darks were bright enough) and overexposed when using a Flash. Being very impressed with the low lighting photo's, I decided to avoid using the flash for more than half the photo's..... BIG MISTAKE."
20120415"
column1303:
We have had our camera for about 5 months.  I have been getting an error 32 message for at least 2 months.  The camera shuts down and needs to be restarted.  Also, the camera cannot be recognized on my iMac which is running OS 10.4.11 (Tiger).  I need to upgrade to at least 10.5 (which means I'll lose Photoshop 7).  The camera did work with iPhoto, but does not appear on the computer's desktop, just in iPhoto's window.  However, it recently quit working with iPhoto.  The photos seem good, but I have had so many problems with just getting the photos off the camera, it is hard to say.  Will update the review after I contact Canon about the error message."
20110911"
column1305: would not buy it for myself
column1306:
I bought this camera as a gift, as a gift this camera might be ok, but I would not buy it for myself. I realize that this camera is only $200 dollars but image sharpness is a huge problem for this camera. image color quality is OK, nothing to be excited about.  Most things about this camera i can tolerate because this camera is so cheap, but I did like video quality. of course this is not a camcorder so zooming and moving with the camera is not advisable but i thought that this camera produces better video than photos."
20110909"
column1309:
The video recording is stunning; better than expected. The wide lens is wonderful, the size and weight are great. The controls are simple, the battery life, screen, and zoom are all good. The speed of the camera, especially when taking multiple shots consecutively, keeps up with fast, demanding subjects. The tracking AF is clever, as is the face detection AiAF.The paint chips easily (normal, I'll guess), but that's not a real issue. The issue for me is the macro mode Ai.  Canon's AF intelligence flies out the window when switched to macro. Shots can still be composed manually by focussing the macro subject in the center of the frame, then framing the shot before pressing the shutter down the rest of the way. That's not the way my past Canon Powershots have worked, and it's enough to make sure I sent this one right back.If you don't use macro: get this camera. It's wonderful in almost every other way. If you do use macro: look at other cameras. I've owned several other PowerShots and will still swear by them."
20110909"
column1311: Good things come in small packages
column1312:
The picture quality is better than my other bigger and pricier camera. The size is unbeatable making it very portable and convenient. It fits easily in the pocket, very easy to use and did I mention the picture quality? All in all, Fabulous!! I would definitely recommend this to others."
20110909"
column1314: small, lightweight, easy point and shoot camera
column1315:
Like advertised and some other reviews say, this camera is very easy to use in its automatic mode.  I have gone from taking landscape pictures to portraits to closeup of flowers and they all turn out great without ever pressing any buttons.  Just aim, focus, and shoot.  If it focuses on the wrong thing, just try again and it usually gets what I'm trying to focus on for the shot.  The movies it makes are really nice compared to my last camera (5 years old).  Plays great on my new laptop.Some negative points: I can't figure out how to force the flash yet (had it one month).  People on the edge of the photo are distorted (slight horizontal stretch of the image).  I'm not sure why that should be.  All my other cameras didn't have that issue.  The movies don't play well on older computers - although I have the movie setting on highest quality full HD, so that is understandable.  These are fairly minor negatives in my opinion.Other than that, nice basic versatile camera that goes along almost anywhere.  Good deal for $230."
20110909"
column1318:
This is a great camera for your pocket or purse. Smaller than a phone camera with 10 times the picture quality. Case has an anti-slip surface which makes handling a camera this small much safer. I still use the camera wrist strap. Build quality is outstanding, as it is made in Japan like the high-end Canon cameras. See CNET for their review, they are the experts in electronics."
20110908"
column1320: No need to trade in your SD780.
column1321:
Although the Elph 300 claims to be 'the world's thinnest camera,' that's now, not a couple of years ago when Canon released the SD780.  The latter camera is thinner, narrower, shallower in all its exterior dimensions and marginally lighter in weight.  It's also boasts a 12.1 mp lens and HD video.On the plus side, the new Elph has a wider-angle lens and stereo sound (of questionable superiority over monaural sound when the recording mic is necessarily squeezed onto a sound stage this small).In short, unless your 780 is broken, it would seem pointless to replace it with this point and shoot.  Should you plan to pick up an Elph 300, you may wish to wait until the end of the month.  One of Amazon's competitors is promising to reduce its price for the camera, so it remains to be seen how Amazon will respond."
20110907"
column1324:
This is an amazing little camera. It is a power house in a small package. Low light performance is simply amazing. Regretfully I had a few sequences of pictures which were very dark in situations which should have been perfect. In discussing the problem with Canon, I was encouraged to send the camera back for evaluation. Later, I received recall notice from Amazon saying that the memory card manufacturer was experiencing problems with their product storing large files. Even though my memory card was not in the affected serial number sequence, I suspect the problem with the Elph 300 may be caused by something associated with the memory card. This is a great little camera and I am confident Canon will resolve the issue I experienced."
20110906"

If you're looking for the technical comparison of this versus other cameras, go to cnet.com for the review.I like that this camera is so sleek, nice and sturdy feeling. I had a Canon for a while that I ended up breaking by dropping. The shutter stopped working. So, then I got a Sony, which is having problems with the controls. For some reason I never really got into the Sony, not that there was any wrong with it. I guess I just liked my first camera. So, I'm back and reunited with a newer and better version of my first love, the Canon."

But then thats expected from a camera of this size. Video is exceptional. Zoom while recording a video happens slowly... thus giving a gradual zooming in effect to the video. It is ok... as is the case with many point and shoots. But these are very minor hiccups.I recommend this camera to anyone who is looking for a camera to carry all the time and take great pics.amazon service is anyway unparalleled."

This is my first pocket camera and I could not be happier.  So easy to take along and the pictures and video are better than I could have hoped for."

The image quality can be a little sub par at times but nothing to turn me away from this camera. It's a wonderful wide lensed point and shoot camera for a reasonable price."
20110903"
column1348:
