20110903"
column1351:
It's a very nice little camera, seems intuitive to use, takes very good pictures. My wife and I are both very happy with it to this point."
20110903"
column1354:
Great little camera.  Photo quality exceptional.  I wish this one, like all point and shoot cameras, was a little quicker to recycle on indoor flash assisted shots.  Other than that, I would totally recommend it to a friend.  Very happy that I bought it!"
20110902"
column1357:
Not a high end camera, not the best-of-the-best... mediocore at best...  camera looks better than photos come out1) Slow focus times  - If you press click too quickly, the image is blurred2) Poor sunset/sunrise captures  - Photos are washed out even when NOT taking a photo of the sun.  Was at Grand Canyon and Sedona this past weekend.. a trip of life time.. and downloaded photos to computer.. and out of the 300 taken -- using various settings --- only perhaps 5 are frameable.  The rest are washed out, blurry, grainy, what have you (used a tripod for some of them even)3) Poor low-light photo capture -- worse than my prior Canons4) Flash will wash out subjects often5) video playback stalls/is choppy.  It as if the camera cannot handle playing back the videos it takes.6) No way to turn off flash in automatic mode.. must go to manual mode.. which means manual mode cant be left for a night-time shot etc. as you constantly move it around.I am going to replace this camera although it was purchased new.Suggest doing more research before buying.  Not the digital camera to bring onto a $4,000 trip to Europe or South America etc."
20110902"
column1360:
I really don't understand why people seem to rave about this camera. I bought this and returned it a couple weeks later; I found the image quality to not be very good, images (even taken outside in good light) were noisy, washed out looking, bad colors, not sharp. It would really be great to be able to buy a compact, pocketable camera that takes good photos; you can't expect dSLR quality, but hopefully decent, acceptable quality. Unfortunately, I don't think this is possible. Basically, from my investigations, the key ingredient to getting good photo quality is to have a large sensor (e.g. read here: [...]). And in considering previous cameras I have owned and liked the photo quality of (e.g. Kodak V1073, Kodak C875, HP PhotoSmart 945), they all had larger than average sensors (not dSLR sized, but bigger than the 1/2'3 that is used on this camera and many other compact cameras and it made a noticeable difference in quality to me). Anyway, I still don't really want to have to buy a huge dSLR and have to lug it around. There are some intermediate level cameras that have large sensors but aren't so big as dSLRS (but bigger than compacts like this one). For example, the Sony NEX line looks promising. Also, the Samsung NX100 looks good too (and seems very reasonably priced). You can easily find the image sensor size of cameras at the web site dpreview.Another, separate gripe I had about this camera is that, while you can take panoramic photos (i.e. take multiple snapshots and have them stitched together into a larger panorama photo), the stitching is NOT done in the camera --- you have to upload the separate photos to your computer and use an external piece of software to do the stitching. What a hassle! Digicams have been doing in-camera stitching of panoramas for years, why can't this camera?Also note that while you can take full HD video with this, it is only 24 frames per second and you are limited to about a max of 10 minutes per clip. By contrast the Sony DSC-WX9 (which I also was considering) can take 60 frames per second full HD video and there is no time limit. If you must have a pocketable camera like this, I would recommend the Sony DSC-WX9 over this one."
20110901"
column1362: Excellent, small camera; great value. Zooms in video.
column1363:
This is a very well-designed camera. Received the packaged promptly as described by Amazon.com.The camera has a mild 'gritty' feel to it (to aid in grip); this is well-documented by fellow reviewers on this page.The picture quality is top-notch. The video quality is fascinating, especially when viewing with HDMI cable on our LED TV (the side port has a mini-HDMI out, as well as the mini-USB for communication w/ your computer). You are also able to zoom while in video mode, which sets the 300hs apart from it's friend the 100hs.The LCD and buttons in the rear-panel are intuitive, as is the selection menu for the various aspects of camera control.The menu and features are similar to other Canon camera products.The camera is small and neatly packed; My hands are above-average sized and the camera's size is about 1/3 of my hand. Therefore, it takes a a few shots to get used to not getting your fingers in the way of the flash, lens and microphone.  The microphone is located on the top panel, with two small holes.One strategy of getting to know the camera prior to your purchase is to go to a local electronics store and seeing the camera (or a similar one) first hand.As with any camera or electronic purchase, it's best to find one that fits your needs.Remember this camera will take high-quality pictures and videos, which will translate to increased power consumption (consider one or two back-up batteries (size/type: NB-4L) and mandate high-capacity memory cards.Our fellow reviewers have gone into much greater depth and all have done a fantastic job at thorough explanation.I hope this review serves as a validation to the quality and value of the Canon ELPH 300hs. Enjoy your continued market research, I hope you find the camera you desire."
20110901"
column1366:
Purchased this for my 11-year old daughter who is into taking & editing video.  She's found iteasy to use with excellent video quality.  And of course, it takes great photos, too!"
20110901"
column1369:
Prior to ordering this camera, I was using a Canon Powershot SD850 IS. I had no problems with this camera but the weight of it plus the carrying case it was in..made me not want to take it anywhere. The Canon Powershot ELPH 300 is lightweight and thin. It takes a little while to get used to the settings but I guess that's what the manual's for. Overall, I like the new camera and I'm glad I purchased it."
20110831"
column1372:
This is the BEST point & shoot I've had! The pictures are very crisp & clear! Every picture I take comes out great!  It has really neat settings like color swap & accent, toy camera mode, mini mode, & the high burst mode is pretty sweet! The high burst mode only takes pics that are 3mp but its still clear enuf for a good pic!  The HD movie mode is very awesome! everything is very crisp n clear! even at night!  The movie has its own button for convience which is pretty handy so i dont have to keep pressing buttons trying to find it.  The only thing ive had problems with is the macro mode.  Sometimes it doesnt focus very good, but i think its bc im too close to the subject.  Other than that i havent had any  problems yet, ive had it for about a month now.  I read somewhere that the camera is made in China & Japan, but the one from China breaks more, not for sure about that but i got the one from Japan!  I also got a steal on this camera! $199 when amazon was having a sale! I took some pics n put them in with the other pics to give u an idea of how much this little camera has to offer.  Sometimes if ur taking a video the battery will blink but wen u stop recording & switch to camera mode it says u have 2 bars left, found that kinda weird, but the batt can die on u.  The only flaw is the new cameras dont have a view finder! So when ur out in the bright sun the screen is useless & ur basically flying blind when taking a pic! I was debating on this one or the 100 hs, but i got this one cuz the navigation buttons seems easier than the 100, the 100 didnt have the separate video button.  Overall great camera for the money! very satisfied! =)"
20110829"
column1374: Excellent slim compact for when the SLR is not with you.
column1375:
I enjoy my Canon 40D SLR, but wanted something that is never far from me for the shots I'd otherwise miss.My key requirements:1. Something to fit in the pocket, good build and reliable brand.2. Good quality pictures, for a compact, but didn't need to compete with SLR quality. Not keen on supersaturation or over-sharpening.3. At least 28mm wide angle, with zoom of 4x or more. f2.8 or better is also good.4. Flash available, but lower-light capability is a plus and something I generally prefer.5. Prepared to go without RAW, aperture/speed priority in order to keep the cost and size down. Exposure compensation is needed though.6. Video capability, with zoom and continuous focus available while shooting.7. The ergonomics need to be good. Core functionality done well trumps number of features.So after much reading and some handling, the Canon ELPH 300HS seemed to be the sweet spot and I bought one in June. Two months later, and 1,200 photos have confirmed that it meets these criteria without excessive expense. I like the 24mm wide angle and 5x zoom, and it has better than expected capability in low light - presumably helped by them keeping to 12MP - a good move. Videos are very nice to watch, surprisingly good really, and it's a great fit for the pocket.I like the coarser feel of the black model rather than the smooth metal silver version - it's a personal preference but I feel less likely to drop it as I don't have a strap attached. The screen is good, even at 2.7' and with mediocre eyes.The battery lasts a reasonable time, but unfortunately seems to give only a dozen or so shots warning before it stops. Have a spare available.I bought a small soft rooCASE Neoprene Sleeve (Grey) Carrying Case for it and its very satisfactory. It has a side pocket for the spare battery but that does make it a bit bulkier so I now leave it out. Bit of a shame but want to keep things slim so I do carry it.Yes, I could spend more and get a larger sensor, a bigger zoom, RAW, more control, etc., but size starts increasing and the whole idea was to have it with me without having to think about bulk play-offs every time you go out. It can't match my SLR's quality, but the pictures sure beat opportunities missed by having no camera (or just phone camera) there at all. It's not perfect, but quality and feel are good, it's well set out, and I expect this will do as my little camera for a good number of years."
20110828"
column1378:
I'm a vlogger on Youtube and needed a high quality hd camera to carry around with me at all times. This camera was perfect and the quality is perfect."
20110827"
column1381:
I bought this camera to replace a Fujifilm f100 finepix camera that I loved after doing a lot of comparison reading on different models.I seldom ever give any credence to people who write a review after only having the camera for a couple of days, especially when they actually admit in writing that they haven't even read the user's manual yet, so I waited to write my review after using the camera for about a month, and approximately 300 pictures taken in different circumstances.All in all, I am very happy with the camera, its features as advertised, the feel of the camera, the ease of using it in quick situations since I use it mostly while I'm in Tijuana, so at times, I have to be quick and quiet when I take pictures, or else things can go from bad to worse in a tick of a second.The only complaint that I have is that the little protective shutter that covers the lens when the camera is shut off, now does not fully open when I turn on the camera, so what I now have to do is to GENTLY touch the little retractable protective shutters to get them to fully open when the unit is powered up, or to fully close when I shut the unit off.I'll send it back for warranty work as soon as I get the information back from Canon on where they want me to send it, but for the price of the camera, and what it does with the many features that it has, I am happy with the camera with no regrets in buying it since this is my first Canon digital camera.Would I buy another Canon point and shoot camera over a Fujifilm camera?Well the jury is still out on that one at this time, but depending on how Canon takes care of the warranty repair (time, speed of getting the camera back to me, etc) on getting my camera back to working like it is designed to do, will go a long way on either making me a loyal Canon customer or chalking it up to experience and going back to Fujifilm where the finepix f550 EXR is looking really good to me."
20110827"
column1383: Quickly became my favorite camera/pocket camcorder.
column1384:
I purchased this camera about 6 months ago to take pictures and video of my 2 little girls.  I have a glutton of point-and-shoot cameras and pocket camcorders, however, this camera quickly became my favorite.  In fact I hardly use anything else and have gotten rid of all my pocket camcorders (flip mino, kodak Zi8 and playsport).  I would characterize myself as an amateur photographer and take mostly family pictures and videos.  To my eyes, the picture quality is very good and close to the quality of my Canon S95 (auto mode).  I actually prefer this camera to my S95 because it is more portable and a lot faster.  The S95 takes longer to start up and the lag between shots are longer, which is not advantages when you are trying to take pictures of kids.  It also has a dedicated video button making it as convenient as any pocket camcorder.  The features I enjoy most about the 300HS sre the wide angle lens and the HD video mode.  It captures great video with stereo sound.  The quality is definitely better than my Kodaks and Flip.  I also like the fact that with the wide angle lens I am able to capture more the action which comes in handy when filming clips of my daughters.Now for the cons: 1) Price.  At retail price it cost more than most point-and-shoots but I would say it is still a good value. If you are like me and like to take pictures and videos, it is worth the cost not to have to manage the battery, the memory and carry around multiple devices.  2) Heat. It does get a bit hot after 10 minutes of recording videos. I do take a lot of video clips so I am a bit concern about whether this will shorten the life of the camera.  3) Battery life.  It is decent if you are just taking pictures but if you are taking videos, you have to remember to charge it after each outing.I would recommend this camera for the casual photographer who is also likes to take short video clips."
20110827"
column1387:
I have not used the camera extensively but so far I think its a very nicely designed camera and takes very good pictures. I am often surprised how many times the auto flash does not chose to use a flash, when I would think it should, and the picture comes out great. Some nice touches, the sandy feeling of the paint, the record button for video (no having to switch to video mode), many cool picture modes, its just very easy to use. The thin size is just great. My only (minor) complaints are that the switching of modes is all done via a menu, which can be a bit of a pain. Instead of having some sort of dial with some of the modes you might want to bring up quickly (like high speed mode). And I have found that the digital zoom is hard to focus when you get toward the higher zoom. I realize that digital zooms are not historically great so I can't say its an issue, but have to mention, neither complaint I think warrants the dropping of any stars so I am sticking with 5. Overall I am very happy so far."
20110826"
column1390:
Great camera! I got the black one and I like the rough exterior, and it's not very heavy. On the right mode the pictures come out very crisp, and the vividity of color of all the pictures (not just in vivid mode) is nice."
20110826"
column1393:
The image quality is outstanding!  let me list some of the things i love the most about this camera:- Low light pictures without a flash look INCREDIBLE- Start-up time before able to take a picture is almost instant- Picture to picture shot time is so fast its like using a DSLR- the lighting in pictures look outstanding, and i get asked frequently 'What kind of camera do you have?!'- Its so tiny it fits in my pocket and doesn't look like i'm excited to meet youIts an amazing camera for $200 and gives the Canon S90 a run for its money! I would recommend this camera to anyone considering a point and shoot.  Every review i read said the same, and i can't urge you more to truly consider this as your next camera!"
20110825"
column1396:
Camera takes reasonably good photos even in low light conditions and excellent photos in normal/bright light conditions. Color rendition is very good.  Manual buttons / camera controls are simple and easy to use.  Finish of camera is nice and almost a nonslip texture."
20110824"
column1398: very good camera for the price
column1399:
This camera is too good. The image quality is really good and there are lot of photo options. The only drawback would be it optical zoom but Canon has released a new version of the same one with higher zoom.Also, this product weighs very less, which is an added bonus. The sand paper texture give good grip during photo/video capture."
20110823"
column1401: Be careful if you are planning on putting it in your pocket (doesn't everybody?)
column1402:
I really like this camera and love the texture on the black color. I would definately give this camera a 5-star rating if it wasn't for one problem... A few days after receiving this camera I placed it in my pocket and a few hours later took it out again to find the cover for the lens was not opening and closing properly when turned on. I quickly figured out that the metal housing around the lens was all bent up and dented. The metal around the lens (area where 'CANON ZOOM LENS 5x IS' is printed) and subsequent metal rings are made of very thin metal and are easily damaged if put into your pocket. I have been able to bend the metal back out so that the lens now opens and closes properly, but still looks all dented up. I previously owned the Canon Powershot 870 and always used to put it in my pocket (isn't that what these cameras are for?) and never had one problem with anything being damaged."
20110823"
column1405:
I did a pretty extensive review before buying a new camera. We looked for a point and shoot without all the buttons to make it confusing.  We have shot about 300 pictures with this camera and are amazed by the picture quality!!!!  It is small, light and in the AUTO mode a truely point and shoot camera. It has a 5X zoom but will actually zoom to 20X, you just have to press the button down to let it focus longer (the picture quality isn't as good) but still allows you to get that long shot.  I purchased a logic case and extra battery for it for about $10 (well worth it). The fuctions for reviewing the photos, deleting are extremely easy to use.  VERY VERY HAPPY WITH PURCHASE !!!"
20110822"
column1408:
This is my third PowerShot and it is the best I've ever owned.  Canon continues to have one of the easiest to use interfaces on the market.  What sets this camera apart is that it takes brilliant photos.  It especially thrives in low-light situations.  The zoom is impressive.  Just putting the whole thing on auto and shooting away produces excellent results.  I wish the battery lasted a little longer (shooting video seems to deplete it very quickly), but that's my only complaint for what is on the whole the best point-and-shoot camera I've ever owned."
20110822"
column1411:
I am a huge fan of Canon, but am completely disappointed with this little camera.Pros:The Elph 300HS is very small, which makes it easy to take with you just about anywhere you go. The matte black finish is stylish and makes holding the camera very comfortable. As always, the menus on the Canon cameras are easy to navigate and get in and out of. The HD video capability of the camera is fantastic--it blows my HD Flip camera out of the water. It is a nice looking, easy to use camera.Cons:The auto-focus AI on this camera is the worst I have ever used, and is the reason for the 2 star rating. Even in full sunlight, with center-focus selected as the focus mode, the camera will rarely produce a crisp, well-focused image. The intelligent focusing modes are even worse, rarely detecting faces or relevant focal points. The battery life is also very poor. A fully charged battery will last about a day of hiking and photo taking. If you are traveling, don't forget your charger. Low expectations are a given for a point and shoot camera, but it should at least be able to focus properly.I have had several point and shoot digital cameras over the last decade or so, and this is bar far the least satisfying of them all."
20110822"
column1414:
Purchased this camera to replace an older Sony point-and-shoot. Own two Canon D-SLR cameras (500D and T2i) and have been impressed with the pictures from both cameras.Heard good things about Canon's ELPH 300 HS, liked the size and thought it would work out. Unfortunately the flash has a way of overpowering almost everything in a picture; even when forcing the flash for backlit situations, the resulting images look unnatural. Flash output is so bright, and there's no nuance just like (unlike both the older Sony and the newer T2i).We ended up sending this one back and opting instead for an SX230HS at almost 50% higher price point.[...][...]"
20110821"
column1416: Found the best with custom setting
column1417:
Canon 300 hs is a delight to use.  After reading several user forums, I have found a setting that works best for most of my needs.  Pictures come out best with 'P' mode.  Set it to Vivid or Positive Film - I prefer the latter.  Positive Film only makes red, blue, green more attractive; whereas Vivid makes yellow too pronounced for me.  A user also commented that you can set exposure to -2/3.  I am trying -1/3 for now.  Having used the camera for ten days I am happy to give the camera a five-star."
20110821"
column1420:
Compact and esay to use. Very nice pictures and it is easy to carry and the design is for any photographer."
20110820"
column1422: Excellent for art and casual photography
column1423:
This camera is beyond satisfactory for use as an art student and a casual photographer. I bought the camera primarily as a method of gathering photos for research and image references for art projects, but also as an everyday camera for taking pictures of friends and family. The camera's automatic settings will take excellent quality photographs in most conditions, and it has enough adjustable settings for more knowledgeable photographers to enhance the existing quality. The camera's small size makes it easy to transport anywhere. It also has lots of fun settings to play around with. My younger brother especially loves messing around with the 'super slow motion' video mode. All in all, a great product that delivers a lot of punch for the relatively low price."
20110820"
column1426:
small easy to use; takes great flash pictures, battery lasts a long time and picture quality is excellent.  very pleased with this purchase, would buy again!"
20110820"
column1429:
Purchased the camera for a trip to China.  I have owned a number of compact cameras and spent a lot of time researching and trying cameras before I purchased.  This camera is incredible.  For me, the most important feature is the end result - it's a point and shoot so how do the photos turn out on point and shoot mode?  Excellent.  Great color, great light balance and crisp focus.  Low light photos are particularly good.  It is easy to use, light weight and the battery lasts a phenomenally long time.  As a side note, the recharge on the battery is fast - less than 1/2 hour.  Great zoom and 'manual' features are intuitive and easy to use.  Here's the kicker I didn't expect.  The videos are fantastic. I never expected the quality out of this camera that you get.  I am selling my Sony HD handicam as a result.  I would recommend buying the largest and fastest SD card.  You will probably never fill it up, however, once you start using the video capabilities you will probably start taking more videos that you have before.  The only issue, if you could even call it that, is that the flash sits where your finger can sometimes get in the way.  Once you block it a couple of times, you learn and slide your finger back 1/4 inch.  The issue is only when you give your camera to someone else to shoot a photo.  Sometimes they block it.  Easy fix, mention it when you hand it to them.  Not a big deal."
20110818"
column1431: No more competitive advantage to know the configuration rules!
column1432:
For me, this 300HS camera comes as an upgrade from SD1000, which in turn was an upgrade from SD300.  From my prior recollection, I was not all that impressed with SD1000 iteration, but this one seems to be a very nice upgrade.First thing you notice, is that there's no longer any shortcuts to change ISO levels or use the micro mode.  That's because there's no need!  Now micro focus is activated automagically, and ISO can go quite high automatically as well, without any HIGH ISO options as was the case with SD1000.Night vision of the sensor seems very impressive, too; I'm totally sold on this BI CMOS!  The contrast as it appears in the viewfinder is often better than what you see with your own eyes as is, and you don't even have to change any settings from AUTO!  Impressive.  The only thing that appears to still be missing is HDR, I guess. :-)A nice thing in my upgrade path, from SD300 (Dig!c II processor) to SD1000 (Dig!c III) to 300HS (Dig!c 4), is that the battery format remains the same, and all the batteries are still compatible, in cameras of entirely different generations!However, I came across a few annoyances (I'll update this list as I go on):* it is not possible to use digital zoom at all if you change the aspect ratio from the default of 4:3, only optical zoom is available.  This is especially annoying if you like to reduce the size at which the pictures are saved, and use digital zoom to specifically crop only the objects in which you're explicitly interested in."
20110817"
column1435:
This camera doesn't have shutter or aperture control. There is no excuse for this, canon could easily have given it a manual setting along with aperture and shutter priority, but they didn't. If you don't know what shutter and aperture are, then go ahead and buy the camera, its a fantastic point and shoot. But shutter and aperture are the very basics of how a camera works, why anyone would make a camera that doesn't let you control these is beyond me.It does have presets which gives you a vague kind of control over shutter and aperture. You can also manually control the ISO, but thats it. I think I'll be getting the 500 elph instead."
20110817"
column1438:
We gave this to our nephew as a graduation gift and he loved it. He took it overseas on a trip and the pictures turned out great.  One thing to keep in mind though (found this out the hard way since I've never purchased a camera), the memory card is not included."
20110814"
column1440: Small camera, great pictures,the red is gorgeous!
column1441:
This was kind of an impusle buy for me to replace my Canon Elph S110.  It has served me well for almost a decade, but the 2MP was limiting, and the batteries wore out and the aftermarket ones were only OK, and it had a max memory of 2GB as it used FAT.  It worked for 10 years (and still does), so I was sold on another Canon.Back in 2001, I had thought the S110 was impossibly small, but this is half the thickness.  There aren't many comments on the red model, but I think it's very sharp-looking and definitely not feminine.  I saw the black at Best Buy, and I don't think it felt all that nice...seems there's a reason the silver and red cost more; they put more money into the finish it seems.The pictures this takes are very nice, resolution is up to 4000*3000, or 12MP.  I thought my ancient S110 took good pics, but this is great.  Also, when I had bought this I thought the video would be a gimmick...but it does a GREAT job at that, too.I gave the menu a 3, because...I dunno.  It's not really easy to navigate and not too hard, but it's also a digital camera.  It is better than my S110, though.  It uses SD cards, but I chose to instead use MicroSD-in-the-adapter as it can be used in far more devices...SD-only devices are quite rare now. And to think SD was impossibly small 10 years ago!As for the camera, the screen is huge, and very nice.  I would advise putting a protective film on it, though...I had spare PDA screen protectors and I cut one to fit.  The camera is made of metal, just like my S110.  I'm not sure on the battery life, but it's probably sufficient.  I got a spare for use on day trips where I would take lots of pictures.  I find it amazing that the camera could be half the thickness of the (state of the art in 2001) S110, but the screen is 4 times larger, and the lens is also much larger.  The camera is Japanese-made, which is probably a good thing, considering most everything is made in China now.  US-made would be nice, but this is a Japanese company.I have not explored what the camera can do with manual settings, but the Auto settings work very well.  I'm not a photography-buff, and wanted something that would work well, and this delivered!"
20110814"
column1444:
Just got this as a replacement for an old sony cybershot.  I do a ton of research before I purchase and this was the best thing I could find in the price range.  The closest thing to it is the *panasonic* DMC-FH27 but I decided on this after looking at the interfaces and menus at the store.  The canon simply is much more straight forward and I was willing to sacrifice some zoom power and megapixels for something that didn't require hours with a manual and training session for my spouse.  Additionally, people have posted some youtube samples of the kind of video this takes and it is far superior to anything in its price range. This is important for me because we can't afford to go out and buy a specialized video camera and this will do a great job.Menu layout is intuitive.  The scene modes are AWESOME.  Very well done and despite being an amatuer I feel like this thing actually improves the quality of pictures I take. I have three picky critiques:1.  If you are going through the preview function to look at old pictures there is a quirky thing about getting back to taking pictures.  If you haven't done it long enough so that the lens retracts, you can hit the preview button again and it goes back to camera mode.  If you do it so long that the lens retracts, if you hit the preview button, the camera turns off.  This was very confusing for the first day and half of ownership.  It took a while to figure out exactly why hitting the same button would not do the same thing all the time.  So, if the lens retracts, you have to hit the capture button toget back to camera mode.  This was the only part about the interface that I thought was extremely dumb and not user friendly.2.  I was disappointed that some scenes and features in the manual set up could not be combines.  For example, you cannot do sepia and the miniatures scene simultaneously.  There are some sub functions as well that are not as intuitive as I would like.  For example, in the color highlight scene (takes black and white pic with one color retained), I have no idea how to choose which color I would like to keep and I'm not sure if I even can.  I tried this scene the other day and it chose what it felt was appropriate but it was not what I wanted.  I have yet to check the manual on that but it would be nice if it were self explanatory.3.  Battery life is a little short but recharge is only about 2 hrs. which is a third of the time it took on my last camera.  It looks like this camera would accept a power cord but it would require an adapter to put into the battery slot.4.  HD video is limited to 10 minute segments.  I know I have seen it said some places that this is to prevent the CMOS sensor from overheating.  But riddle me this Batman, if that is the case why does the camera allow me to immediately start another 10 minute HD video right after I have recorded for 10 minutes.  Would this not also overheat the CMOS sensor?  If the answer to that is yes, then canon failed to put an additional safety feature requiring you to wait for the sensor to cool down before recording in HD again.  Either way you slice it, there is an error in their design.Overall, however, this is a great and versitile camera and amatuer photographers will have little to no complaints.  BEST BUT IN ITS PRICE RANGE.Did I mention this thing is small?  Love it..."
20110813"
column1447:
I recently purchased this camera after doing lots of research and reading all the various reviews online and I've been very happy with it.  It is very small and easy to carry around.  I got the black version with the 'sandpaper' finish on it and although i was a bit leery about it I have really grown to like it.  I've read some of the other reviews on here regarding picture quality, etc and for what you are buying it takes great pictures...the flash goes quick and the shutter speed is more then fast enough.  If you are buying this and comparing to DSLR camera quality you'll never be able to hope to compare picture quality...but remember if you want that extra bit of quality then buy a DSLR and not this.  For point and shoot cameras it is quite nice.  The functions are easy to understand and operate, although the little manual you get with the camera doesn't go over some of the more manual functions.  But you can easily go online to Cannon and get the full manual version.If you are looking for a higher quality point and shoot camera that is above the basic $100 base version type then you will like this."
20110812"
column1450:
I bought this camera in April, as a birthday gift for my hubby. He love to take pictures, but doesn't like to play around with the camera. Months later, I tried taking videos. It only takes 10 minutes videos! I then, refer back to the manual's book,' Shooting time for a 4gb is 14 min. 34 sec., and for a 16gb is 59 min. 40 sec., maximum clip length is 10 min.' I was confused, and call cannon customer support. Everything was clear now, but regret buying this camera. I should have pay more for a good cell phone that does everything."
20110811"
column1453:
You get some much to play with in this camera! This is the best consumer digital camera upgrade I've ever made. Canon is head & shoulders above the competition in this price range & size. I live in NYC and wanted a small camera I could carry around in my pocket to take pictures or video whenever I find anything cool instead of using my phone and this camera does the trick nicely.The HD video quality in a camera so small is amazing, but of course the sound quality is lacking, so I usually combine video with my Zoom recorder for better audio. Nothing beats this camera and I tried many of them before settling on this one! The software that come with the camera is pretty cool, too. I also love that it's small and feels sturdy!  **The only issue with the black camera is the buttons can make it difficult to review photos in very low light , so maybe they could focus on making it more ergonomic in that way. Ya know, give the 'FUNC.SET' group of buttons some texture or something, so you can feel them in low light conditions. I'm thinking canon could add to budget to have the text raised to give the buttons some relief with the profit they are making on this great camera. Also flash photos you will sometimes have a lightly darker area in the lower right corner of the frame. Move the flash to the right side of the camera please!**That's my 2 cents!"
20110811"
column1456:
I take a lot of indoor snapshots. This camera takes better indoor shots without a flash than my five year old Sony with a flash."
20110811"
column1459:
I have several cameras ranging from this small camera that I bought to replace a damaged IS300 to D30 SLR.  I must say that I purchased the small camera to bring with me when I go on trips, the SLR was for everything else as the image quality was much better.  This new camera changed all that for me.  After trying some of the cheaper small cameras that produced horrible images, I got this and never looked back.  The images are so good that I find myself not using my DSLR much at all.  The camera even does great evening/night shots.  I was amazed.  The video is simply amazing as well.  To be able to take 10 minutes of HD video that is optically stabilized is simply unreal from something this small.Anyway, If I had known it would be this good, I would have happily paid much more, especially after trying several cheaper ones.I could not recommend a camera more that I recommend this one.  Buy it, enjoy it."
20110809"
column1461: LOUD zoom... DO NOT zoom while recording
column1462:
I did my research for weeks on this bad boy versus the SX230. Finally decided on this guy based on size and features (and I'm not sure I need a travel zoom). I took a few impressive pictures, even pointed the thing at my family photo wall and noticed it did a great job picking faces out of the pictures... I noticed the zoom was pretty loud, but I figure it's okay.Then I recorded a video. AMAZING 1080p24 quality picture... the loud zoom sound was RECORDED. This was mentioned in one other review and verified by some people on youtube. Some cameras have the issue, some don't. Mine does, and it's going back ASAP. May be my last canon based on poor quality control."
20110809"
column1464: Pictures in bright light are BAD
column1465:
I bought this camera for 'AUTO' mode only. I am great fan of Canon and have several Digital camera/ Video cameras. I have used this camera over 3 months.When I take pictures in bright sun light in 'AUTO' mode, the pictures are so bright, they look bad. I am not an expert but it seems that either it has over-exposure or higher ISO problem. I wouldn't recommend this camera.One odd thing to note is although pictures are not good but video quality is excellent in this camera which is surprising as it should have better picture quality than video!!My five year old cameras give better pictures than this. Don't buy this camera."
20110809"
column1468:
This camera replaced an old Casio.  It does everything much better, from the easy menu, to the great movies (with good sound), to excellent photos.  I know there are some reviewers who say the image chip isn't as high quality as the Leica or Panasonic, but i would bet the price of a Leica that no one could tell the difference in a 4x6 snapshot.  If you want higher resolution for enlargements get a bigger camera, but for carrying around in a pocket, this one is hard to beat."
20110808"
column1470: WOW This camera is awesome! I love it!
column1471:
This camera for the price cannot be beat.This camera is perfect for the beginner, novice, or experienced pro. It is so easy to use and setup.Charge the battery, throw in your SD card and go shot photos. Auto mode is so easy to use.It takes beautiful pictures in any mode. 1080p video is cool too! Shutter speed is great and No LAG!Love the button layout, construction of the camera, and options. The camera is also Made in JAPAN! WOW, really it is.Buy this camera and you will not be disappointed."
20110808"
column1474:
The battery on this camera is a disaster. You cannot leave it in the camera. It lasts just a few hours. You have to take it out and store it separately from the camera or it will drain out in a matter of hours. The owners manual also says not to leave it in the charger for long periods of time or it will reduce battery life as if that matters on a battery that barely makes it through a dance recital! Cannot believe I wasted over $200 on this camera. Absolute waste of money."
20110807"
column1477:
Great camera for the money!  You can take some great pictures with this model. Plus it does HD video! My only complaint is because the lens has such a wide angle, objects/people are distorted on the far right and left of picture if you aren't careful. The solution? Zoom in a little. It is small and somewhat delicate camera, so make sure to make use of the wrist strap. If you have big hands, this might not be the camera for you."
20110806"
column1480:
I should start by saying I never write reviews, but I felt this camera deserved some praise. The Powershot 300 HS has surpassed my expectations. My other camera is a 7D and have a nice collection of flashes and lenses, but I got tired of lugging it around everywhere. With my son being born I knew I would be taking lots of photos but wanted to be able to take pictures at a moments notice and not have to set a bunch of equipment up all the time. Well this was the answer to all my needs. Being an intermediate/advanced level photographer I couldn't settle to have some cheap little point and shoot. So I researched and went with the top of the line canon. In a nutshell this thing is a pocket sized version of my 7D, no lens changing of course. It lets you set up everything manually if you want to, or it will do everything for you! I was very impressed to see the addition of 1080p at 24fps video as I didnt think these things had that capability. It also can do 240fps at 320x240 and 120fps at 640x480 which is a blast to play with. There are so many features in this thing its ridiculous, there's more then the websites will even tell you. It has lots of cool creative modes, some of my favorites are 1.Panorama Assist - which guides you in taking the pictures and will stitch them together with the packaged software when you load it to your computer. 2. color isolation mode - Lets you select a color and grey every other color out. 3. Smart Shutter Detection - You can set it to take a picture when it detects a smile, wink, or when a new face enters the frame. 4. High Speed Video mode - as mentioned earlier. 5. Miniature Mode - Maybe the most fun to play with, lets you pick your area of focus and blur the rest. Also lets you record movies that play back at fast speed (smaller video size but small file size too!). Other great features you'll notice right away are its slim design (wont even know its in your pocket), fast start up speed - ready to go in under about 1 second (just disable start up screen, and incredibly easy menu navigation. The greatest part of this camera is that I dont have miss another photo opportunity because I either didn't lug my camera with or couldn't get it out in time. This thing is always on me and ready to go. Being ready for the moment is half the battle:) Don't waste your money on some cheap camera, this thing will do you proud. So many features I didn't even talk about. Just get it!"
20110806"
column1483:
Very good camera. Highly recommended. Used it in Austral Grand Cannon and Colorado river ia and it worked great. Pictures are very good, and the camera has all the flexibility needed. The camera was durable enough to survive my vacations!"
20110805"
column1486:
I have only used this a while, but it appears to be a great little camera. Seems to take very good pictures and good video. I like the ability to zoom while shooting video. Much handier than my Canon Powershot G5, which is admittedly dated and not a fair comparison. I suspect many of the modern cameras are as good as this one, but one feature I was really looking for was the zoom while shooting video, which seems to be rare among today's cameras. This unit is very small, which is great for a pocket or purse."
20110803"
column1489:
My little brother was very excited to get this camera. The pictures and videos he's produced with this camera look pretty amazing. Very vibrant and sharp. A great canon camera!"
20110802"
column1492:
This camera took a little getting used to because you have to hold the button down longer for the picture to take than my previous camera.  I debated getting this camera or a more expensive SLR.  My niece had a lower and older model and it took such good pictures I decided to get this one.  I am really happy with the low light pictures.  For the price I think this is a great camera."
20110802"
column1495:
I only shoot using my DSLR, however, I got this for my wife after reading some pretty good reviews.  I LOVE shooting with this camera - though the texture of the camera takes a little getting used to (its a little rough), it always amazes me with the color and clarity through this point and shoot lens.  The battery life has been excellent - and we have no complaints.  This is a great point and shoot camera that you will love."
20110730"
column1498:
I have a Canon SD1100is and was very pleased with the picture quality.  I then purchased a Panasonic Lumix DMCZS7 and was blown away by the quality and picture clarity.  But I missed having a small camera like the SD1100 to take to parties etc.  I wanted something to just slip in my pocket, and I wanted a wide angle lens that the SD1100 did not possess.  The ELF300 is a perfect size for tucking in your shirt pocket or pant pocket. However it does not take nearly as clear pictures as my old SD1100.I have played around with the camera for a few weeks and found that it does not focus exactly where it should. I am stumped because I have never had that problem with either of my two other cameras.  At first I felt like I was doing something wrong.  I tried each focusing format and it never came out as clear as the SD1100.I am really disappointed in this from Canon.  I will keep it for the times I just want a handy camera in my pocket."
20110729"
column1501:
Purchased as an adjunct to my Canon Rebel XSI for times when I don't want to take the larger camera, or just want snapshots.  Still new, so haven't discovered everything it offers yet, but appears to be just what I was looking for.  Obviously doesn't take the same quality pictures as my Rebel, but don't expect or need it to.  A lot in a little package for the money."
20110728"
column1504:
Many excellent reviews already posted by experienced photographers.  So I'll keep it brief and mention a few things I've found.  I found the black model at Walmart and thought the texture (like sandpaper) was terrible and if that was all they had, they could keep it.  On line I found the red and gray, and they are smooth textured, much better.  I ordered the red from another retailer as they had a free case with purchase.Very nice, well built camera, made in Japan which usually indicates more quality.  Auto is great for quick shots and most use, many settings also available for more experienced photographers.  The auto focus can focus on something other than what you want, if that happens, switch the button on the back from auto down to the camera icon, choose P mode and set the focus to Center (check owner's manual for full instructions).  It will stay that way so anytime you want to better control focus all you'll have to do is switch the button down.Nice clear, colorful pictures.  Good low light ability so you don't have to blast the flash all the time. I don't use it for movies so can't comment on that.Personally, I'd stay away from the sandpaper black edition if buying this camera."
20110727"
column1506: Why to get the silver one instead of the black one
column1507:
I've always been a proponent of function over form, but this is one of the rare cases I've run into where there is such a huge difference in satisfaction with one over the other that I felt it my duty to share with fellow consumers almost immediately.  Keep in mind that this review is only to help those of you out there who have already decided that the functionality of this camera satisfies you, but you are struggling with which color to get, as I was.Long story short, I've had both a black one and a silver one in my hand over the course of the last week (black returned due to a manufacturing problem that Amazon, as always, handled in an A+ manner - I chose to replace with the silver).  Now I'm the type of guy that always gets everything in black - clothes, furniture, and especially gadgets, so naturally I gravitated toward the black model.  That being said, get the silver one - period.  The black one does look cool, but the sandpaper texture, while providing good grip, absolutely detracts from the overall value of this camera. It makes it a pain to pull out of your pocket, picks up dirt and lint like a magnet, and just has an overall cheap feel to it.  I couldn't even wipe the screen off with a microfiber cloth without it catching and nearly tearing on the housing.  When I received the silver one, the first thing I thought when I opened it was, 'You've got to be kidding me. How can a color change alone constitute such a vast difference in satisfaction?'  The answer is because I now feel like I have a quality camera I can actually use instead of something I have to constantly worry about catching on things and wiping lint off of.  Everything about the silver one blows the black out of the water; smooth finish feels very nice, looks nice, doesn't act like a lint brush, and the entire camera has a much sturdier, more solid feel to it in general.  In fact, one of the first huge things I noticed was the quality of the battery door.  I've owned many Canon P&S cameras over the years, and when I first saw the door to the black camera, it immediately struck me as something way more low budget than I'm accustomed to seeing with Canon cameras.  When I received the silver one, instantly noticed the quality was back up to par.One final consideration that always manifests apprehension in the back of my mind when considering black cameras is that black, as everyone knows, absorbs sunlight, while lighter colors reflect it.  if you're going to use it mainly indoors or at night then no problem, but if you plan on using it the sun a lot like at the beach, on vacations, heavy daylight use in general, then it only makes sense to me that black cameras in these cases would be more prone to overheating and/or accelerated mechanical wear and tear.  If it's really enough to make a significant difference in the life cycle of the product is questionable, but that's just one of those things that, unlike with phones, handheld video game systems, etc, keeps me from automatically defaulting to the black model.In summary, great camera no matter what color you get, but for the price I just feel like the silver one gives me so much more value.  I can't speak of the red one as I've not seen it, but I've heard the texture is the same as the silver, and with regards to the advantages over the black one, most of the above would still apply.  Red is more of a girly color than silver though, so please keep that in mind if you're a guy."
20110726"
column1509: Simple Camera That Takes Good Pictures
column1510:
I bought this camera about a month ago to replace an aging Olympus Point-and-shoot, and so far I've been pretty happy with it. It takes pretty nice pictures and it's really small and light so it's easy to take everywhere.Pros:Very small and lightHas a nice grippy texture so it's not so easy to drop itHas a lot of different built in modes that make it easy to get good pictures in any situation.Shoots Full HD video that looks pretty goodHas a nice wide angle lens.Cons:It has no manual modes available to control things like aperture, shutter speed or focus (this is a personal preference; you may not mind)The super slow motion movie mode (which is pretty cool) has low resolution (320x240 @ 240 fps or 640x480 @ 160 fps)The buttons are kind of small if you have big fingers- I frequently push buttons i didn't mean toThe on-camera menus are kind of confusing.All in all it's a great little camera, and it takes great pictures indoor and out. I think that, as of this writing, it's definitely the best all around compact camera in the price range and you won't be disappointed in it."
20110726"
column1513:
Love this camera. I've been using it for two months. The camera can gather light from surroundings, so it's easy to just point and shoot without worrying much about the light condition. I can take natural indoors images without using flash. The design is classic and the compact size makes it easy to carry around."
20110725"
column1516:
I am a total believer in Canon over many years and though not buying this camera from amazon, I thought of adding this review as many look for the reviews on amazon no mater where they buy the product. Despite intense love for canon I like to mark this product as a potential problem. Quality of still picture and size of camera is excellent but mine in its 4th month of use is gone dead due to 'Lens Error' message that appears on display, immediately after turning camera on. In a second camera turns off automatically and not responding anymore. Lens is stuck out and not moving. In my research I see this as a common problem of this model and if you run a search for eg on ebay, you see many are sold for part for the same reason. I am not sure if this is the result of camera's sensitivity to fall or minor hit on the lens side or a defect of model but this is not something expected from a Canon Built. I wish Canon could address the issue and finds a remedy for the users specially those left without warranty and in any case you need to be very careful with handling of this camera or better, look for some other model."
20110725"
column1518: BEWARE THE FULL HD VIDEO!  LOOK HERE BEFORE YOU BUY!
column1519:
I have been a CANON fanatic for many years.  The macro lens features of the DIGITAL ELPH series alone are like no other.  The cameras themselves are, over-all, outstanding.  They are very compact, very user-friendly and professional in results.  BUT!  READ!  Newer isn't always better.  YOU NEED TO KNOW that when you are looking for an HD video camera... and this new model is FULL-HD, UNLIKE ALL OF THE PREVIOUS CANON ELPH MODELS, this new 'upgraded version', with all it's bells and whistles and upgrades, DOES NOT ALLOW YOU TO CONTROL THE HD MOVIE FEATURES!  IT FORCES YOU TO STAY IN A STUBBORN AUTOMATIC MODE, which causes footage to ALWAYS be over-exposed and washed-out.  Furthermore, during filming, the camera 'flares' the video results from one extreme to another IN EVEN THE SLIGHTEST LIGHT VARIATION!  Each and every video comes out in WAVES of bright to dark if the camera isn't in completely stable light conditions.... and you have absoultely no control over it.  HOW IRRITATING TO WATCH!  I HAVE TO ASK:  WHY EVEN BOTHER TO UPGRADE THE DIGITAL ELPH TO FULL HD CAPABILITY AND THEN NOT BE ABLE TO MANUALLY CORRECT YOUR PREFERENCES FOR LIGHT, CONTRAST, COLOR, ETC before filming??  It was unbelievable to me that something so new and upgraded was so generic in it's HD functions.  It is, in fact, so disappointing, I must now return this camera with a sad face.  LONG LIVE CANON, but absolutely skip this model if you are looking for stability of the HD VIDEO mode.  NOTE:  The previous CANON POWERSHOT SD 1400 IS is the model that correctly allows for user-options with HD.  Although not FULL HD, it is still HD."
20110725"
column1522:
This camera is a great deal if you are looking for a compact camera for travelling. It takes quality shots and has an amazing battery life."
20110725"
column1524: Good, true pocket size, stylish, and well priced camera
column1525:
This camera replaced a Canon PowerShot S500 digital elph, both used mostly by my wife (I usually use an SLR).It is smaller, actually about half as thick as the old one, making it truly pocket size (it very easily fits in a shirt pocket). The LCD is not the largest available in point and shoots today, but it is pretty large for the camera size, and is much larger, and of better display quality than the old one. There is no optical view finder, which I think is a big minus, but this seems to be the case now with all point and shoots, and my wife seems to have gotten used to that. Picture quality is good, but unlike the old camera that supported ISO 50, this starts at ISO 100. There are more shooting modes than with the old one, and in general more controls and a better, though not great, optical zoom (x5). I never consider digtal zoom.It is more stylish than the old one, but not as sturdy.It was not my first choice, but since my wife will use it more than I, I asked her to choose between 2 cameras ( the other was the S95 which supports RAW) She thought this was more stylish and she didn't care for RAW support (no matter how hard I tried to sell it)The bottom line is: if you are looking for a pocket size stylish camera that produces good pictures, and which can be totally autmatic but still offers reasonable amount of customization, and you don't care for RAW support, then this is a very good and well priced choice."
20110725"
column1527: A great point and shoot camera
column1528:
I purchased this camera for a 3 week trip overseas.  The size is great and makes this camera very portable! The 5X zoom with the extra wide angle also makes this camera very versatile. Image quality is fantastic. There are a ton of different shooting modes and the HD video looks great.  The super slow motion video (240 FPS) is a bit grainy and its image quality isn't too hot but it works for small, hobbyist applications (Max. resolution in super slow motion is not very high, something like 340x240).  The body is made out of metal so it's very durable, however the only thing I see as a negative with this camera is that there's no fully manual shooting mode and the black finish.  I've only had my camera for 2 weeks and the finish is starting to come off in several places. Other than that, I highly recommend this camera!!!  It's a lot easier than hauling around my DSLR w/ 4 Lenses..."
20110724"
column1531:
Having owned Canon compact cameras in the past, I had high expectations for this camera.  It hasn't let me down!  The size and weight and battery life are all acceptable.  I liked the fact they used the same battery which allows me to use my old battery as a backup.The LCD screen is crystal clear and the menu navigation is very similar to older models.  The picture quality is amazing and the HD video is fantastic.  The sound quality isn't great for video, but that is due to the small mic and where it is placed.  Not a big deal for me.The only downside is the camera is a bit light, doesn't feel sturdy.  That is probably due to the compact size.  I dropped our last one which is my I had to buy a new one.  This one would probably end up the same way if dropped.  Also, the wrist string can't be tightened like on older models, that is odd.  The camera write strap can easily fall off your wrist without the tightener.I use this camera with a 32 Gig Class 10 memory card and it exceeds all my needs/expectations.  I'm not a professional by any means, if you are similar and wanting a great compact camera, this is the way to go.  For the price, it gives you the best picture and video quality in my opinion."
20110724"
column1534:
Nice little camera that generally does all that is supposed to do.  A big negative is it makes movies in the quicktime/mov format that does not work well Windows Media Player, Windows Movie Maker etc.  I think Canon made a very poor choice in using this format. I will not return the camera but would advise against buying for anyone wanting to work with movies and Windows products."
20110724"
column1537:
This little camera is marvelous to take on vacation. Slip it into your pocket or purse and you are ready to take that spur of the moment picture. Don't dislike anything about it!"
20110723"
column1540:
the shutter lens would not open/close after a week, I had to send it back.  Amazon was very good about return."
20110722"
column1543:
Black finish is too grainy.  Suggest the Silver.  Good picture quality in low light.  Not as good as S95."
20110722"
column1545: I'm sharing not-so-common notes about this camera.
column1546:
- I was debating between this camera and the sony cybershot wx9 for an average joe like me. Both are great options and besides price, nearly identical so you can't go wrong with either one. My decision to go with the 300HS came down to a few things that might help others choose a camera.- The sony wx9 captures 1080i AVCHD video @60fps which looks great...until I read that that file format is difficult to edit. I planned on making a lot of videos for youtube/facebook and didn't want to hassle with having tons of videos in a difficult file format to edit and share. To test this, I downloaded several AVCHD videos from torrents and sure enough, it took me a while to find a video player that would consistently play it smoothly without crashing. The canon 300HS uses .mov files which are easy to edit with just about any video editing software. This was the biggest deal breaker for me.- Although the canon 300HS's video quality is 24fps and not 60, for my non-professional use, I think it looks fantastic! I have recorded videos @ 1080i, uploaded them to youtube, and watched them through an internet connected TV at a best buy store that has 120hz or 240hz motion plus enabled and the video is EVEN BETTER! Smooth as butter! That made me realize I didn't need 60fps. Go to youtube and search for 'canon 300HS test video' and see for yourself. Then watch the same video on high end TV or monitor. You see? You don't REALLY need the extra FPS and bigger file size for your boring video :)- I was worried that limited maximum video length would be annoying, but honestly, I never record anything longer than 10 minutes. Moreover, stopping recording, and starting to record a new video takes 3 seconds. After buying the camera, missing 3 seconds is not a deal breaker as I once thought it would be.- About the camera and windows XP: My only gripe is that when I have the camera connected to XP, I can't browse the content of the memory card through 'My Computer'. I have to browse through it via the canon software. However, using the canon software is FASTER than through windows XP! If I have a folder with hundreds of pictures and hundreds of .mov files, the canon software FLIES while browsing it and it even shows thumbnails of videos. XP only shows a generic icon. Finding a video and switching between one video and the next is INSTANT in the canon software, but takes AGES thru XP! My PC is no slouch either.- About the canon software: I honestly had zero expectations. I thought it would be slow, bloated, sluggish, featureless, and painful to use, but I was actually impressed! I found it to have everything I needed to handle hundreds of pictures and videos, browse, sort, delete, rename, and have them ready to share with friends without pulling my hair out. In fact, the built-in option to upload straight to youtube was a nice surprise, because that's what I intended to do A LOT and made me glad I made this purchase. Sidenote, there is no option to upload to facebook or twitter with the canon software. I didn't read this in other reviews.- Here's my biggest retrospective point and lesson learned. I obsessed over which camera to buy based on specs and reviews and sample images and recordings. It got to the point where I was scared to buy ANYTHING. In the end, I realized, I just needed a simple point and shoot camera to take pictures of my friends and I hanging out and occasional video that only WE would care about. This camera met and exceeded my expectations. I am 100% satisfied with my purchase and I get compliments about my camera and my pictures all the time and I don't even try. The camera does all the work for me!- Canon sells a waterproof cover for this camera on their website. I have not tried or tested it. Canon does not make these housings for all their models. I did not read this is in other reviews.- I bought a $10 plastic shield for the LCD screen like the types you would put on an iPhone and used a blade to trim to size. Now I'm not afraid to put the camera down on the LCD side on rough surfaces like rocks or wooden picnic tables. I didn't think of this for a while when I first bought it, but glad I did before I incurred any damage to the screen. Did not read this in other reviews either lol.- You can edit your videos straight from the camera! Trim the begging, trim the end, or both, then save the slimmed down video as a NEW file straight to your camera, or overwrite the existing file! This is an AWESOME time saver when you are on the go! It frees up memory too! I use this ALL THE TIME and didn't think about looking for it as an option in a camera. I'm glad its there!- The automatic panoramic picture mode in Sony's camera is impressive and EASY to use. You just shoot and turn the camera and you're done. With the canon camera, you have to go through a confusing and complex set of steps that its faster and less stressful just to take sequential pictures yourself than to try and use the canon's menu system. I honestly couldn't figure out how to take panoramic pictures with this camera. It's very confusing, but I don't care. I never take panoramic pictures.- When I plug in my camera with an HDMI cable to my TV, I can use my TV remote to control the camera menu on my TV! I can browse, edit videos, and more sitting on my couch across the room! Did not read this in other reviews and an AWESOME way to share videos and pictures at your friend's house. I don't know if only certain TVs let you do this, but for what its worth, I have a Samsung LED TV from 2010. Way cool! Wish I figured this out sooner hehe!- Battery life: Kinda sucks if you take a lot of video (because you forget how many times you re-watch it and fail to take that into account). However, lots of my friends have canon cameras and they (not all) have the exact same battery so I often borrow theirs instead of buying a spare. Like asking around for a phone charger in a clutch. Whodathunk? Not me, until I realized tons of ppl have canon cameras. :)- I love the slow-mo capture mode! The quality is crappy but the effect is always fun! My friends always want to play with this! I wasn't expecting to use this as much as I do! Kind of an unexpected ROI!- Cliff notes: Excellent camera for daily use!! You and your friends will be impressed!!"
20110721"
column1549:
I bought this camera on sort of an impulse buy. I researched it for a couple weeks and was deciding between this one and the Canon PowerShot S90.I chose this model because I wanted the 1080 recording functionality, the slim size, and the ability to take pictures in a dark-ish setting.I tried this camera out in a local park for three hours and never lost a bar of battery, and my pictures are all crisp, clear, and gorgeous. I am in love with the colors of this camera. Great for beginners.The only con I see with it, is that I wish it were a touch screen.I will continue to use it, and will update if any problems or major mind-blowing features are discovered."
20110721"
column1551: Great Camera, Lots of Features, good HD Video, but bad software
column1552:
I love this little camera! The pictures it takes are spectacular, and it literally fits in your shirt pocket. The main reason I bought it was to replace my bulky HD Camcorder, and I am very happy with the video quality and sound, even in relatively low light. On a 16 GB SDHC Card, it can fit about 1 hour of 1080P HD Video. It also has image stabilization, and a slow zoom (which is a good thing). The caveat is that the maximum length of each clip is about 15 minutes. Another caveat is that while you can zoom while taking video, the zooming motor sound can be heard in the  video. The one thing I did not like is the Software that came with the Camera. I replaced my old Canon software with this one, and this software is hard to use, and does not even have the features the old software used to have. But the Camera itself is excellent, and I highly recommended it."
20110720"
column1554: Great Camera, but why is there an error with my new SD card
column1555:
Overall great camera. I keep coming back to Canon for the same quality that I've trusted over the years.I am not sure if I made a blunder on my part, but I keep getting an error when I try to use my 8 GB SDHC card. It will not allow me to take any pictures. I have to use my old 1 GB card which works without any problems. Has anyone else run into this problem?"
20110718"
column1558:
I wanted to replace my 10 year old Canon sd 450 which still works great; but wanted to get a newer one.  I researched, I read all the reviews, and finally came to the conclusion that for my needs, the Elph 300 would serve me best.And I was correct.  I got it about a month ago, & took it on our vacation and it took great photos, and videos.  I would have gone for the elph 500 but the only draw back was that it is a bigger camera, and doesn't easily fit in a pocket.That's the reason I selected the elph 300, because it does a lot, does it well; and is small enough to carry around on vacation.I would highly recommend it."
20110718"
column1560: Good camera - don't buy the black one!
column1561:
This is my 3rd canon digital elph, and hopefully not my last one (I'm only replacing the previous model because American Airlines shattered it).  Amazon was out of the silver model when I bought it, so I got the black one.  That was a mistake.  It's got some sort of texture to it that just makes it horrible to handle.  It's rough, it feels bad coming in an out of your pocket, a case, whatever.  Cleaning the screen is almost impossible because the 'texture' grabs hold of most soft cloths that you would use.  I could easily see this snagging a sweater, etc.  The only thing I could imagine this texture would be for is improved grip, but honestly, I don't think that's ever been a problem for anyone.  These things are so light that it takes almost no effort to hold on to them.  The texture also collects any dirt or other particles around it.  After 5 minutes in my pocket (this is a pocket camera, after all) with what appeared to be a completely clean/empty hard candy wrapper, the camera came out covered in pink mess.  Also, the wrist strap on this model wasn't soft and flexible, but instead very stiff.  If I wasn't wearing it, but just grabbed the camera for a quick snapshot, I had to be very careful that the strap didn't stick straight out into the picture.  That should never be a problem one has to worry about.The picture quality on this camera isn't quite as good as it was on my previous model (SD770IS).  The quality isn't quite as sharp, the colors aren't quite as good, etc.  I can only hope that my particular camera was a fluke, both in the quality of the pictures and the roughness of the textures.  Come to think of it, I may pick up a different model instead of another one of these - maybe the SD4000IS or SD4500IS."
20110717"

column1603:
Recently purchased this camera elsewhere...Amazon you need to reduce your prices a lot more..I got the red one for even cheaper than the price of your  black one.Anyway, previously had an Olympus Fe340, 8MP, great little camera with excellent photo quality, unfortunately one day it just stopped working so I needed a new one. My first digital was Canon and still going strong so I figured I'd return to Canon...after reading reviews here and elsewhere I decided on this one. I've only used it a little bit as I also bought a Samsung Galaxy S2 smartphone...I should have listened to those around me, camera wasn't necessary..the picture quality of this camera is only slightly better than my phone..I expected sharper images with 12MP, instead pictures are comparable to my 8MP phone. The camera is very light,compact and easy to use..didn't need to read manual to get going with it...just pop in battery (needs charging as only little juice when out of box)memory card and off you go. I wanted a reasonably priced camera to take landscape shots for printing purposes..not sure this fill my needs...bummer."
20120411"
column1606:
I bought this as a Christmas gift for my wife.  It is small enough to carry everywhere and the pictures seem nice."
20120409"
column1609:
I had high hopes for this camera, after reading so many glowing reviews.  I was looking for a small and light camera that I could take anywhere.  While my old powershot A620 still takes great pictures, I wanted a camera with newer features such as hd video and better low light performance.  My experience with the elph 300 hs has disappointed me in several ways.  Compared with my trusty A620, pictures taken with the elph 300 hs do not look nearly as crisp - almost soft, especially toward the corners and edges. I've played with settings and typically use P mode.  I just cannot seem to get decent pictures with this camera.  Other complaints I have are the autofocus speed, barrel distortion with wide angle, inconsistent exposure, weak flash, and horrible lens flare.  The bottom line is that the image quality simply isn't there with this camera.  While I would love to have a camera I can slip in a pocket, I am not willing to compromise image quality enough to use this camera when I want to take halfway decent pictures.  I will grab my A620 every time - even if it doesn't fit in a pocket. Of course, I am not expecting dslr performance from this little camera.  My basis for comparison is my experience with my A620, my kid's A590is, and my dad's sd1100is. This little camera has many features in a very small package & might be a fun little toy for someone who isn't picky about image quality.Pros:small, yet comfortable to hold and operateexcellent battery lifemany featuresexcellent burst modebuild qualityCons:image quality / softness, even when sharpness setting is adjustedblurring of corners and edgeslens flare - much worse than other point & shoot cameras I have used, makes pictures look washed out (vs. attractive flare)autofocus speedflash - weak and inconsistent (and easy to block with finger at first)inconsistent metering, compared with other cameras I have usedbarrel distortion at wide angle"
20120409"
column1612:
Very cool features and very easy to use. Fits in my pocket nicely. I use a smartphone slip cover to keep it clean in my pocket."
20120409"
column1615:
I got this one from Amazon last year for a trip to China. My wife used it primarily and I used for a few times since my main camera is a DSLR.If you are serious about image quality, this one would NOT work for you. It can only serve as a travel camera that has better pictures than cellphones.My very first Canon digital camera was also purchased from Amazon. It was way back in 2004 and the model was S500. Unfortunately, my mother-in-law broke it four years ago. If my memory serves right, the old one gave better picture quality than this new one.Pro1. compact2. battery lasts a whole day with full charge (600 pictures, some flashes, a couple videos)4. cosmetically pleasing5. enough picture quality for web sharing and 4x6 printsCon1. really soft images (focusing problem?)2. clear distortion at wide (24mm) and tele focal length3. video not true HD quality and taking humongous space comparing to any digital camcorder4. the advertised high-ISO sensitivity was achievable but at expense of very soft focus and blur (slow shutter speed)5. could have been more useful if aperture/speed/manual program was avaiableIn short, this camera did not meet my expectation. It was not much better than my old Canon compact. If you want to upgrade from your cellphone pictures, this could be it. If you are custom to any DSLR, this one will fail your expectation instantly."
20120407"

Delivery was excellent less than a week and was well packaged. I love the camera for point and shoot an am still figuring out how to use. My bad because I don't read manuals. Pictures are excellent though!Only dissapointment was I found same camera at Wal Mart 3 days after I received it for $40 less.Generally get better deals on Amazon than that.Definitely but the extra battery and of course the memory card."

column1621:
I purchased this camera after having used a Panasonic Lumina camera for the last couple of years. The panasonic was nothing nut trouble. I had most of my pictures come out blurry. The canon appears to be much better."
20110706"
column1623: Good all-in-one device, Pictures a tad disappointing
column1624:
I bought this camera to replace our Canon Powershot SD1100 IS.  I liked having a single device that took good photos and video, but I wanted to start recording home videos in HD.  I also didn't like a couple limitations of the SD1100's video recording (no zoom, fixed focal length).  I considered an upgrade to the SD1400, but it doesn't support full HD and still has the same basic video limitations (focal length is fixed for duration of recording although digital zoom is enabled).  The 10 minute limit on video files doesn't bother me much because most of our home movies are recorded in small increments.After watching some sample videos other users posted online, we decided to step up to the 300 HS.  I bought 2 16 GB memory cards and took the camera on our trip to Orlando.  We recorded about 45 minutes of full HD video and about 250 pictures on a single 16 GB card.  The battery life was OK, but we certainly needed to recharge several times on the trip.  After getting home, I took a look at what we got.  The video is very good.  The image and sound are both very clear.  I don't hear any camera noises in any of the video although there was plenty of ambient sound which could have covered it up.  Occassionaly the video has a tendency to 'jump' when the camera is panning or zooming but it wasn't frequent (panning/zooming slowly seems to help).  I'm so glad we swtiched to this camera for the sake of the improved video quality we got.As for the pictures, I'm a tad disappointed.  I thought the images from my SD1100 were great (images were sharp, well exposed, and had good color).  For the most part, the pictures from my 300 HS looked good.  They're very sharp and bright.  On the negative side, many of the pictures had very oversatured colors.  In particular, green grass and pink skirts looked unnaturally bright.  Fortunately, I could tone them down a little with picture editing software.  I'm assuming the switch from a CCD to a CMOS sensor is partly to blame.My other minor nitpick with the camera is the tendency of the LCD to scratch easily.  This was a problem on our SD1100 too.  I'd recommend a scratch protection film.Otherwise, I'm quite happy.  I'd gladly recommend the camera to friends and family."
20110705"
column1627:
Canon PowerShot ELPH 300 HS 12 MP CMOS Digital Camera with Full 1080p HD Video (Black) by Canon is another camera with great image quality and image processing and it shoots excellent videos for it's compact size. I have had Canon 'point and shoot' cameras for years and find them reliable. Daily use often either doesn't warrant a rather bulky SLR system."

It is not much worse than my Canon XSi with the standard lens that come with the camera.  The only thing is that there is no manual adjustment. column1651:
This camera is small/compact that fits into pocket. Good photo quality and night time shots without tripod. Battery life is good, too. Recharge in about 2~3 days of use. Overall, I love this camera!"
20110628"
column1654:
I purchased this item through Amazon and received it yesterday from Ace Photo Digital, and I am very happy with my purchase so far. The camera arrived quickly (at the early end of the expected delivery window) and was carefully packaged. I charged up the battery and 45 minutes later got to work.I got the black finish option.
