It isn't a smooth finish, but a little rough, like fine-grit sandpaper. I really like it because the camera is quite small in stature, and the finish allows for a sure grip at all times. After a brief initial set-up (set date/time and select language) I started snapping some shots in auto-mode. Wow, what a clean picture. I came from a 6 mega-pixel point and shoot, so 12 mega-pixel unit is a healthy upgrade. Pictures are sharp, balanced and vibrant, even in the low lighting around my place. I stepped outside and snapped a few more in the sunlight and found more of the same.Having mastered auto-mode (and who can't really?) I opened up the menu and started playing with some of the features. I've seen some reviews complain that putting the camera into a particular mode is too cumbersome, and I have a couple thoughts on that. Number one, the menu is optimally set up, easy to read and navigate. Icons illustrate the various modes, with text alongside to explain what each mode is and what it does. Selecting a mode was simple. Number two, as far as selecting a mode on the fly, any pro photographer will tell you one of the secrets to taking great pictures is planning ahead. I really don't know what Canon could do to make it any faster, other than assigning individual buttons on the camera for each mode, and that's not exactly feasible. Several features are included, so unleash your creativity! Video mode is nice as well, easy to use and shoots great video.Only two negatives I can think of for this purchase is something that plagues too many electronics when buying online. I want to know exactly what's in the box, and I couldn't find that anywhere in the product description. I ordered an SD card along with my purchase and I'm glad I did, because one is not included with the camera (that may very well be standard procedures these days, but I'm pretty sure my old Canon came with a card). So I will tell you what IS in the box: camera, manuals, cd-rom, RCA cable to connect with a tv, USB cable, one battery, and one wall-charger. The second drawback is that the LCD display screen is a bit exposed. In this small package space is a premium and it seems like the screen is pushed outward a little to compensate. I'm looking forward to the arrival of my protective case.Overall, I'm very happy with this purchase. Tons of features, easy to use, excellent pictures and a great price. Highly recommended."
20110626"
column1657:
Feature-wise, this camera is exactly what I wanted.  It takes decent pictures and video and the zoom feature works while taking video. I bought this as an upgrade for the Canon SD730IS which I have used a lot over the last few years. I would simply carry it around in my pocket and even on my bike rides.  I even dropped the 780IS once while on the bike and, while it got scratched up a bit, it still works to this day.  There are some scratches on the back...However, the 300HS (Black) has really soft metal on the front face as part of the lens structure -- those 3 outer rings you see which are part of the mechanism that allows the lens to extend outward.  After one short trip where I put this camera in my pocket along with my Droid Incredible phone, the camera now has a bunch of dents in these surfaces.  The lens still extends outward as needed, but I'm sickened to see it all messed up so quickly. It looks as it has been badly abused.  The front face of my 780IS is still in tact with several places of missing paint on the rear side.So, I'm NOT a happy camper here. Beware of this camera.  Don't put it in your pocket or purse, or let it make contact with anything. It needs a case which, IMO, takes away the advantage of its small size.  For my intended use, that makes the camera almost useless.Edit: As of December 2011, this camera no longer works.  The lens gets stuck while extending. It has barely been used. This was a total waste of money."
20110625"
column1660:
I am a horse racing photographer.  I was needing a camera to have in my pocket, just in case.  I shoot with Canon equipment.  I trust Canon.  I love the little thing.  Fits perfectly for what I need.  Not as great as my bid DSLR camera,  but quick and handy.  Works super, photos sharp, amazes me."
20110623"
column1663:
I get tired of lugging around the big DSLR and purchased this on a whim, it is truly a great camera and really takes incredible shots.  Much, much better shots that you can get on a camera phone.  Even in quick shots, in tough lighting conditions--it produces great shots.  Could be the perfect 'point and shoot'.  Enough advanced settings for special occasions, but, honestly, even in some bizarre situations, still comes out with great pictures, so, why do you need all the extra settings?  Quickly becoming my favorite camera.  The external case does have an odd 'sandpaper' type feel, but, I suspect this will smooth out and it does keep it from feeling 'slick'."
20110623"
column1665: Be careful about the image quality
column1666:
Except the image quality, I feel I like this camera especially the size, the building quality. However, the image quality is the most thing people cared about for a camera, right?After reading the reviews, I make my decision to give it a try since I never expect the image quality comparable with DSLR. But I am so disappointed because the pictures are almost not useful at all and much worse than my 4 years old cannon SD450/470. Also, by reading other camera reviews, it seems very normally happened to most of the latest compact cameras regardless which brand is. I really don't understand how the technology is developed cross the whole camara industrial. Without customers' satisfition, maximum the profit from a single product doesn't make them rich.The camera is back to where it came from and I have to thank Amazon for their best custom service."
20110621"
column1669:
I consider myself a avid photographer and although I mainly work with DSLRS, I've had my fair share of point-n-shoots as well.This is the best point-n-shoot camera I've ever owned. Like most Canon cameras, it is well-designed and very reliable.Pros -Speed - When you push the button, the shutter moves. It still has the half-press for AF but, it shoots when you want it to, instead of lagging with flash, etcImage Quality - Comes with a CMOS sensor and shoots full HD video.Design - The black one (the one I bought) strays away from the glossy finish that attracts fingerprints. It features a sandpapery feel that allows for better grip and the 'feel' of durability. I actually prefer it to the glossy finish.Cons -Modes - There are way too many. I presume it is for today's experimental photographers. Don't get me wrong, they have some pretty cool modes ,such as 'miniature.' But the rest can be simply applied with photoshop or should never be used for the sake of photography."
20110619"
column1672:
I was upgrading form a A590 IS 8MP, and I really had high hopes for this camera seeing all the positive reviews. This camera has very noticeable fringing or chromatic Aberration problem cased by poor lens engineering. My old A590 had virtually no fringing issues..  Most people probably would overlook this but if you are a person who loves photography with a keen eye and want crisp clean pics, this issue will drive you nuts. I couldn't tolerate it so returned mine.. Everything else is fine but I still wouldn't recommend this camera for photography enthusiasts or for anyone considering it is a premium class camera with a serious problem. Imaging-resource dot com/PRODS/300HS/300HSA.htm did a pretty good review of it, if you want to see what I mean... the fringing is best noticeable between high contrast areas in bright lighting conditions."
20110618"
column1674: Canon 300 HS - A Good, but not Great, P&S
column1675:
This is a good, but not great P&S.  If you have realistic expectations, you'll probably be happy with it.  If you think you are getting a DSLR type photo quality in this package, you should think again.We bought this camera when we had lost our Canon SD 800 IS, which, at the time it came out was one of Canon's top of the line cameras.  Because we had a graduation, I went to a store with a reasonable return policy (in case we found the SD 800, which we did later).  I ended up taking about 200 pictures with this camera.  Here are some thoughts:Size - this camera is incredible small.  About the size of a Blackberry phone.  Easily pocketable.Zoom - one of the most useful zoom ranges in any pocket camera 24-120 is a sweet sweet zoom spot.Grip - we had the black with the textured feel.  I liked it, but my wife didn't much care for it.  Try before you buy.Photo quality - while the pictures were generally pretty good, I thought that this camera would blow away the 7 MP SD 800s photos, but for the most part, it did not.The amazing thing about this camera is that on Auto mode, which is how most people would use it, there were a couple of outside shots that were unbelievably amazing and remained sharp no matter how much I blew them up.  There were about 2 such pictures out of 100.  The lens needs alot of light to be at its best, and I really could not duplicate the sharpness on Auto no matter what I did.  I guess sometimes the camera's IQ is good, and sometimes, it isn't as good.Indoor shots are okay, but there was marginal, if any improvement from SD 800 indoor pictures and that camera came out about 6 years ago, that's two sensor generations and one lens generation (although I think the quality of Canon's glass was better then and the sensors are better now).  As I mentioned above, we actually found the SD 800 after the graduation and I took a couple of test shots to make a comparison (because I was thinking of keeping the 300 HS).  Generally speaking, there was not that big a difference in the pictures to bother with the upgrade.Thus, for a P&S it is a good camera, but will not blow you away with the results.  However, if you are buying it just to print out 4x6, which is what we do with our SD 800, you likely will be satisfied, but if you are thinking of upgrading from a prior generation Canon P&S the difference in photo quality may not be enough to make the switch worthwhile.Best of luck in your purchasing decision!"
20110618"
column1677: Good things come in small packages
column1678:
Lost this camera in the airport a few days ago.  I've enjoyed it SO much that I ordered the same camera again.  I have a Nikon D70s that I rarely use anymore, simply because this Canon is so easy to carry around.  I also have an older model, the Canon PowerShot SD1400 IS which pales in comparison.  I am extremely pleased with this product."
20110617"
column1681:
My trusty Canon SD630 starting to get a little worn so I decided to upgrade to a similar sub-compact point and shoot. The Elph 300Hs is almost identical in size to the older SD630 with a few more rounded edges.  Right away it felt a little slippery in my hands but I liked the fact I could use the same case, battery charger, and battery as my old camera.  The menu system has been revised from older Canons but all things considered if felt pretty familiar.My first use was in a trip in the mountains.  The outdoor shots in Auto mode were just ok and frankly I was a little disappointed with the sharpness and detail. Everything had a washed out appearance (which I recognized as overexposure later) The real problems started when I took the camera to my son's wedding. The auto mode produced horrible pictures. Overexposure (noted by some reviews) was present in almost all shots. In some cases I took shots within a second of each other with the same scene and the Auto setting drastically changed.  ISO, aperture, speed was all over the place.  I ended up switching to program settings to fix the ISO at 100, keep the flash on, changed to vivid, and fiddled with the exposure.  This helped a little but I still was not happy, especially since I expect a point and shoot to work well in Auto. I then tried some more fixed settings with higher ISO and no flash to take advantage of the sensitivity.  I can honestly say the results were worse than my cell phone camera.  Giving up I switched back to Auto for the rest of the wedding and ended up taking many bad pictures with motion artifacts, overexposure, out of focus, you name it.This camera may have been defective but I don't think so. After doing some more research it seems that these CMOS sensors my not quite be ready for prime time.  I sent the camera back and upgraded to the Canon S95. I could not be happier!  The S95 takes amazing pictures in auto mode and is a lot of fun to try out some of the manual options.Do not get fooled by all the positive 300HS reviews. This camera is not worth the high price.  You would be much better off going more high end with the S95 or just buying a cheaper point and shoot and saving some money."
20110615"
column1683: Canon is the best camera ever made
column1684:
I had a canon power shot camera before this one and i had it for over 4 years until i dropped it. I went on line an looked at about 20-40 cameras, different brands but i stuck with CANON.. WHY? you ask. lol well this camera is FANTASTIC, EASY and I LOVE IT.. it takes great picture and the zoom is awsome and they print out sooooooooo clear.. CANON I WILL NEVER LEAVE YOU....."
20110613"
column1687:
So compact that it takes only little space in the pocket - very high quality pictures that only second to those taken from larger SLRs"
20110611"
column1689: A Sweet Point And Shoot Camera
column1690:
Based partly on the reviews here, I bought the Elph 300HS Silver, and played with it for several hours, initially shooting about 150 stills and about 10 minutes of video.  I settled on the Elph 300HS because I wanted a reliable and solid point and shoot camera, where the Auto feature would do all the work.  I admit I'm no photography pro, and I certainly don't have the time, patience, or inclination to fiddle with all the interminable and esoteric photographic settings, nor did I want a bulky camera to lug around.The video looks very good, especially on a hi-def monitor but tends to blur very slightly when zooming in too fast.  And I have to admit that having a zoom feature on hi-def video was a strong selling point for me.  The tiny stereo microphone works fine, and like all other similar cameras, picks up the ubiquitous wind sounds.  You should also be aware that these hi-def videos take up a lot more file space on your SD cards than 'mere' DVD quality.I compared one or two pics on the Elph to the same shots taken at the same time on my older Canon Powershot A710IS (12 vs. 7 megapixels) and there was a slight discernable increase in the quality of the still shots.  I had hoped that the Elph photos would be much sharper and clearer because of the newer technology and the additional 5 megapixels, but the increase in quality, while noticeable, was minimal.  In all fairness, however, I did not print the photos, I only viewed them on my hi-def monitor.  With the price of ink cartridges these days, I'm very selective about printing color photos on my printer, but I am certain that the Elph photos, if printed, would look much better than those of my older camera.As claimed, the Elph does indeed take great shots in lower light, but the tradeoff for this is that the resulting photos seem to be a little softer than the shots taken in normal light.Another slight disappointment, as pointed out in another review, is that the videos are saved as .mov files rather than .avi or .wmv files.  Windows Movie Player will play them, but only by expanding the file types to 'any file'.  Fortunately, there are several programs out there which will convert these .mov files.  The one I use, Prism Video File Converter, can convert these .mov files to .wmv files (among others), and the .mov file sizes are reduced by an astonishing factor of one fifth, without a noticeable decrease in quality.  If you plan to edit or combine your Elph videos by using Windows Movie Maker, it will happily handle .wmv files, but not .mov files.The really surprising thing about the Elph is its very tiny size, a worthy example of the art and science of miniaturization.  Yet, it still feels quite heavy in the hand, no doubt due to all the electronic components packed into its tiny but solid metal frame which provide all its many features.  Bottom line?  It ain't perfect, but it's one hell of a sweet point and shoot camera."
20110611"
column1692: photo happy, owns SLR and old canon 890 both superior quality to this in regard to photo compression
column1693:
FirstMuch like the Canon PowerShot SD890 IS the build is GREAT!!!!!  Better in my opinion ( this from someone who has repaired her 890 after dropping to get it to take photos again, ya OPENED and it works perfectly :)  )it is smaller and thinner then previous PowerShots and even some of the 3000 and 4000 range which I tested and returned  the same day due to a similar issue that this model has.  LACK OF DETAIL in laments terms and for others the compression and more so I feel the digic 4 processor makes the camera for those who will need to take photos and edit USELESS.  HOWEVER, if you want a simple point and shoot and will never edit your photos then get it.  If you want something that allows you to lets say take shot where someone has closed their eyes and edit their eyes from another photo where they are open THIS IS NOT THE CAMERA FOR YOU!  (or me as I have done this with my Canon PowerShot 890 IS for a photo from a bridal shower of a friend)The video zoom is great, grainy but better then my 890IS my SLR does not have video which makes me peeved but the fact that it has a digic III processor every photo comes out fantastic.I want to keep this camera because the build is great and it does take web posting worthiness photos when there is good lighting aka indoors in a kitchen but with the lights on and natural light from outside HOWEVER the loss of detail is there on zoom and not suitable for large prints or editing only for 'as is' shots etc.I am a Canon user/fan for years and upgraded and upgraded from one Canon to the next and after trying theCanon PowerShot Elph 1400 and SD1300 and now this model....I think I am going to have to abandon a brand I loved for over a decade.  I am so sad that despite consistent complaints that canon has not rectified the compression issue.  My 10 megapixel old Canon PowerShot takes better photos then this and the other aforementioned NEW models then there is a problem.  I had my Peterbald sit in his bed in low light conditions using flash and full auto on both this model the 300 and my old model the 890 and the loss of detail on this model was abysmal compared to my 890 using same subject same lighting conditions and same distance and same sd card.So I am back on the hunt for replacement still and every camera that has the digic 4 and regardless of cmos or ccd because they have such a high pixel count the cameras just do not cut the mustard and this issue is I need a point and shoot that has video for when I am taking pictures of my Peterbalds or my baby cousins or anything to have to lug my slr and my video cam (which is a canon btw which is great) is ridiculous.signed really ticked and hoping Canon comes out with something better...:("
20110609"
column1695: I wanted to love it but...
column1696:
I feel like Canon has been putting out products that aren't as well-made as before.  I'm going to start with the design.  I was glad they've added black in their color variation, but on this particular model the black is dull.  Not sure if it's matte black, but there's a texture on it that I don't quite like.  It feels alright when you've got slippery hands but the texture attracts dust like a moth to a flame.  I wish Canon would adopt some design ideas from Sony or Samsung.  The LCD screen feels like it's not secure, and if you look closely you can see the spaces between the lcd and the camera.  The bottom right of the screen kind of pops up and i dont really feel good about it.  I actually got a replacement because I thought the first one i had was a bad one, but the second one is just the same.  I'm in the process of returning the replacement for a refund.What I liked about this camera was the ease of use and how fast it operated.  The new HS system is really nice indeed.  I don't think i liked the CMOS sensor though.  It caused overexposure often, and colors were off and flat looking.  I always had to use Vivid color mode which on my previous Canon Powershot was extremely vivid and saturated but on the 300 HS it's normal colors.  I own a Canon T2i and a Panasonic LX3, i've tried numerous cameras in the past so I can say i know a thing or two about IQ. I am by no means a 'pro' photog. I don't do 'portraits' or those studio-like pictures but I am into still life and street photography.  The Elph 300 HS is good for snapshots.  Clear images with very minimal to no noise at all.  It does smear a bit but isn't as bad.  I wouldn't go above ISO800 though.  And the i-Contrast is just horrible, don't use it you wont need it.  The HD video is AMAZING, though the mic is super sensitive to wind so it's a little downside.  I don't record video anyway.  Most people who are getting this probably want it for low-light pictures.  I'd have to say the low light performance is better than a regular Canon Powershot SD but don't expect wonders because it still has a small sensor and an aperture that isnt wide enough. If you want anything close to dSLR quality images, you'll be better with any of the advanced p&s like the Canon S95, Panasonic LX5, Olympus XZ1, Samsung EX1 etc.  All of those have a sensor of 1/1.7' or bigger, and the Oly and Samsung have an aperture of 1.8!  Another thing i want to bring up is the inconsistency of the images.  The focus on this camera doesn't seem to be as effective as older models, so trying to shoot macro is a little bothersome because it takes several times for it to find the subject.  I think for the price, it should perform a little better.  My advice is to get the 100 HS and save $50, or spend a little more and get the SX210.  If you're looking for best image quality as an alternative to a dSLR then  you might want to get the advanced p&s that i mentioned.  if you just want a camera to take snapshots and want decent IQ, you would be fine with any of the Canon A series, even the SD1300 and SD1400."
20110609"
column1698: Wonderful Little Camera, but watch out for the black shadow
column1699:
This camera works best in Program Mode. Like others have said, images appear better in ISO 100. When using the flash, my only concern is the black shadow in the bottom right corner of images. I've discovered a new way to avoid the infamous black shadow. Remember: 'Keep the light on the right.' If you have a light source, keep it on the right of your shooting frame. I took several photos and noticed that if i moved the bottom right corner of the frame into a light source, the black shadow disappears. You could also Zoom to avoid the black shadow. Anyway, it's best not to use the flash if you don't have to. Canon could have avoided this issue by moving the flash to the right side. Other than that, this camera is wonderful!Make sure to buy a spare Canon battery and camera case!"
20110609"
column1701: great camera, with a few caveats
column1702:
Quickly:  very pleased with this camera, good for indoor kid shots and such.Longer (much!) version for those interested...Background  We've been looking for a replacement for our dear SD870IS which died of the dreaded lens error.  We've been using a SD4000IS in the interim, which is acceptable, but hasn't quite lived up to the 870's shooting performance or image quality.  We've been through (and returned) countless P&S's from various mfr's, and this 300HS is the closest we've come to an adequate replacement.(Aside:  I found it interesting that I'm not the only SD870IS user that has ended up here, see other reviews -- pretty sure we're all seeking something similar.  I'd have bought another 870, but they're now going for 2X original price, yikes, and I know from trying some refurbs hands-on that it's a big gamble on whether it ever fully recovers from the surgery)The particular niche that we're in, and is one that I think this camera suits, is indoor shooting, kids and such, without flash.  For us, a camera either does a good job in that situation or it's a failure.  This is a job best left for our DSLR, of course, but when away from home (birthday parties, etc) we want a P&S that can at least come close.  I'd say my expectations are high, but not unreasonable - the SD870IS met our needs.So this review is targeted in that direction.  Outdoor shots in full sun aren't nearly as challenging, and this camera does a fine job at those, so it's not worth much comment from me.  Instead I'll focus solely on the 'is it good for indoors' aspects.Short answer:  Yes!  (but, see 'But...' below)The sensor is quite sensitive.  The lens is (can be) quite fast.  The autofocus is (can be) quite responsive.We're about 1000 shots into this camera.  Maybe 100 of those are 'careful' shots, and another 900 or so that were taken haphazardly just playing with the camera in various ways.  The vast majority of careful shots were 'keepers', and quite a number of the haphazard shots turned out as well.  (By 'careful' I mean that, at the very least, time was taken to frame and half-press prefocus in anticipation of the right moment;  by 'haphazard' I mean just point and full-press, cross fingers, and hope something interesting happens when the shutter opens)Images are of low noise, not overly softened, and (for the most part) have proper tone/balance/color/etc, JPG artifacts seem minimal (using best setting), etc - overall quite pleased with image quality.BTW, I'm not a megapixel junky, 12 is plenty, don't fall for the hype.  Canon is (partially) headed in the right direction by (partially) reversing this trend.  I say (partially) because they have other models that are still chasing that megapixel marketing monster with 1/2.3' CCD sensors, which seems ridiculous to me.  The A3300IS, for example, would not at all be appropriate _for me_.Heck, I'd be fine if this had been a 10Mpx sensor in the hopes of getting yet one more stop of sensitivity.  That's a tradeoff I'd gladly make.  (SD870IS is only 8, SD4000IS is only 10, both are adequate for our use)  I say this only so you get a sense of where I'm coming from, what's important to me in this review - maybe it is/isn't important to you.  That tiny sensor DOES appear to have enough sensitivity to support (most of) Canon's HS hype at 12Mpx.The 24-105mm f2.7-5.9 is very nearly same as 870's 28-205 f2.8-5.8 on paper.  Just a tiny smidge wider and faster at full wide.  Though my sense is that the 870 might have had a bit better glass overall.But... to get the most out of the low light sensitivity of this camera you'll have to live within it's sweet spot.  It's not AS fast, with just ANY settings.Some caveats:  The lens is only fast at it's widest setting, and gets noticeably slower quite rapidly with any amount of zoom.  That's fine for our use, as we zoom with our feet, and in fact I just treat it as a 28mm prime lens.  (if you're outdoors in sun, f5.9 at full tele is plenty fast, so full range of lens is usable)  Problem with wide angle is (as mentioned by others) the flash is too close to lens and bottom-right will be shadowed.  Again, that's fine for our use, as I despise flash, and force it off.  I'd rather have an underexposed picture in natural light than a properly exposed picture using any P&S-caliber flash, so I'm willing to ignore this flaw.  Auto mode isn't always that smart, and it does seem to slow down shooting performance noticeably.  Some of this is apparently the continuous AF, which, while would be a handy feature, seems to be a performance penalty rather than benefit, and is only available in Auto mode.  The remainder is probably the 'scene detector', you can often witness it 'change its mind' as to what it thinks you're shooting if there activity in the scene.  Program mode, even with everything left at defaults, is far better, and is definately my favored mode of operation.  Auto white balance can be fooled, though it's more often ok than not.  A small gripe, and is the case with most P&S's, so I'm not overly faulting this camera.  Again, though, if you're inside and can set it to tungsten (or as appropriate, or manual) specifically, you'll get better consistency.  (and tho I can't confirm it rigorously, i have the feeling that this too, like auto-scene detect, makes the camera ever-so-slightly less responsive in full auto mode - so set it yourself and solve two problems at once)  BTW, if you can accept the reduced resolution, the 3Mpx modes (high speed burst & low light) offer opportunities to capture some photos that I'd never expect a camera of this size to get.  I've tried similar modes on current Nikon/Sony/etc, though none were as effective imo.  For the most part, I don't intend this review to cover the other 'effect' modes, as I myself will never use them, but these two modes seemed worth mentioning.Other issues:  I do miss the 3' screen of the 870IS.  I sort of wish there were a '400HS' model that used the (nice) screen from the Sx230HS.  (am personally NOT a fan of 500HS's touchscreen)  Of course it'd have to be a bit bigger, but that's ok, it's so tiny right now there's some room to grow and still be pocketable, and they could probably then fix the flash location too.  My dream imaginary '400HS' would also have the remaining PSAM modes (shutter/aperature/manual missing here) of the Sx230HS.  I'd particularly like to have a shutter priority mode (or at least a 'sports' type scene mode that strongly favors fast shutter in its overall solution).  But I don't need the 230's GPS, don't like it's flash, don't need all that zoom, don't like the lens speed tradeoff you make for that zoom, autofocus seems a bit laggier with that lens, etc -- in short, the Sx230HS wasn't a good fit for me overall, so that extra bit of control was something I had to gave up to get a better overall fit with the 300.A note on the texture of the black model:  It's subtle, and I personally like it, makes it feel like a camera.  No, it's not sleek like your cell phone, but you can get the red or silver model if you'd rather have a camera that's more likely to slip out of your hands.Summary:  If you're doing well-lit shots, then no problem recommending this camera, it's as good if not better than others in this price range.  If you're doing poorly lit shots, particularly if you don't need zoom, then I'd highly recommend this camera, as it's currently better than any other that I'm aware of in this price range.  Same for all the current 'HS' line (Elph 100/300/500 HS, Sx20HS), I've tried all of them, though this is the one that best suited me, so I know it best -- check out the other model specs and see which best suits you.  I'd give this camera 4.5 stars if I could - as I more than 'like it', but fall short of 'loving it'.  It's really just about as good as it can be for what it is and what it costs, but Amazon calls their stars 'like/love', so 4 is more appropriate.  I'd have to reserve 5 stars for the ficticious '400HS' as described above - come on Canon, build it!! :D"
20110609"
column1705:
I LOVE IT!!!!!  Exceeded all my expectations!  Just be prepared for how VERY tiny IT IS.  A good thing, but it's REALLY small!  Check out Mike Perlman's review on youtube, inFoSync, dated February 10, 2011.  It's an excellent and very comprehensive review.  I'm extremely pleased with my purchase!!"
20110607"
column1708:
I've always lugged around my heavy 5DMkII (with a battery grip) camera whenever I go out even if just a simple event like a get together with friends (as I'm always assigned to take pictures). Lately, its just my red IXUS 220 HS (or ELPH 300) that I bring along everywhere. It's simply amazing what this small gadget can do and I haven't even explored half of its features yet. Though, I'm used to shooting in RAW (which this camera doesn't have), it's JPEG output is great. In fact, some of my shots look so professional that my colleagues couldn't distinguish some of my shots taken with this camera compared to my pictures taken with my 5DMkII. Together with my iPad and an SD adapter, I can easily show my pictures and video in a bigger screen in a jiffy. I'll probably get a Eye-Fi X2 card for this camera so that I can wirelessly upload the pictures to my iPad since this camera is very compatible with the Eye-Fi technology or as what the manual says. Simply a must for photo enthusiasts!!"
20110606"
column1711:
A lot of people have done a good job covering the camera.  I am highly pleased with it.  I do have one caution.  The tiny lens cover that covers the lens when it is powered down is subject to being damaged easily.  I noticed something on my lens recently when I was out taking pictures.  After having cleaned the lens, I powered the camera off and noticed that thin cover did not close properly.Recommendation:  do not put it in your pocket without a case covering the lens.  I believe that something in my pocket caused the problem with the lens cover.  This problem did not affect the funcion, just won't close properly at this time"
20110605"
column1713: Liked it more when started shooting under P mode!!
column1714:
I like the size of this cam.. Under Auto skin looks like manikin.. reason was ISO > 400, I started shooting under P mode with ISO of 100 and things started to look much better.Video is VERY nice!!Not the best camera under AUTO mode 'My old Canon SD870 dose a much better job with good light and full auto 'Very nice low light performance, tripod might be needed sometimes if slow flash synch is being used ' very nicely lit background can be achieved with this mode 'One more thing, when using flash, it cause black shadow ' the lens shadow ' in the right lower corner of the picture, when shooting wide angle, add some telephoto to the lens or position yourself with the light source to your right to avoid it!!Conclusion: Although I will still shoot mostly with my 60D, I am keeping this camera just in case I want a little pocket cam :-)"
20110604"
column1717:
This is a fantastic camera.  I love its compact size.  It easily fits in my pocket.  I bought this camera so I could take both still images and hi-def movies.  The camera is easy to operate, and has an automatic mode for true worry free 'point and shoot', that gives you the perfect setting for any environment, or you can play with different settings yourself.  I was impressed with the movie quality.  The full 1080 movies look fantastic when you plug the camera directly in to an HDTV via the HDMI port.  It's almost like watching a blu-ray.  The only draw back is the movie image gets a little fuzzy if you zoom in too far.  Also, the stereo mics are prone to picking up wind noise.  Otherwise, the audio quality is quite good.  Overall, this is a fantastic camera for the money.  I'm very happy."
20110604"
column1719: Love the camera cause it's very compact but...
column1720:
Okay, the first camera I had sent back due to the fact that the lens would not retract back inside. Was replaced by amazon without any hassle.  The second camera the screen cracked within a month which was sad since now I am using a camera with a cracked screen. However, despite these mishaps, I have many reasons to really like the camera. First, the size is great as it is very small and easily fits into my pockets to carry around with me wherever I go. Second, the pictures are quite good despite the small size, low price and basic features. Are they the best pictures I have seen, absolutely not, but for a daily use camera that you toss in your pocket, they are fantastic, clear and vibrant.  Highly recommend despite having to return the first and the LCD screen cracking within a month. By the way, I called Canon support, the guy was friendly enough and he told me to send it in for repair and gave the the mailing address of some place in VA.  Surprisingly, the customer service guy couldn't tell me weather it was covered under warranty or not which I found kind of confusing. I may just take the gamble and send it in and hope they fix it or send me a new camera free of charge. I like Canon products so I am hoping they do the right thing. In the meantime, I am snapping photos almost every day and loving this little teeny tiny itty-bitty camera."
20110603"
column1722: Robust features packed into a petite package.
column1723:
Like many customers for things like this, I absorbed dozens of Amazon customer reviews and sought out video reviews of  the camera as well. So, I anticipated going in that this is a great little camera and have not been disappointed since it arrived about a month ago. About a day after receiving the camera, I mounted it to my helmet and took it on a favorite mountain biking trail here in southern California. Here's a short video the camera captured on that ride. The video I took is 720 HD, but this youtube video was bumped way down in resolution for ease of playback. Note, the last two clips of a water crossing are slow-motion, which is just as it was shot by the camera, which also shoots nice slow-motion (but, by design, the slo-mo it shoots is much lower resolution, which you'll notice). Oh, and the music is composed and played by my son! :)[...]I won't get technical, here, because lots of surrounding reviews do that nicely. This camera is loaded with features, many of which I'll likely never use. Things I like most: I can easily tailor it to my needs with a very intuitive onscreen menu, it'll shoot with or without a flash, it takes amazing photos, it's SILENT, so can be used on location for production stills during television shoots, it's SMALL, which makes it very easy to take along on any excursion, and it's easy to use. I have a Canon Rebel xti for special occasions, but I seldom use it. This little gem is just too proficient to leave home.  Hope this helps"
20110601"
column1725: I expected more from a Canon
column1726:
I got this camera a week ago and have been disappointed.  I decided on Canon because I had one years ago and really liked it.  The quality seems to have gone downhill. The best feature is the compact size.  I find the 'smart auto' not to be so smart.  The images are usually over-exposed and at times out of focus.  It's as if the camera can't figure out what I want to photograph and instead picks some detail I'm not interested in.  The menus are not obvious and I have to keep running to the computer to read the manual, which is not very handy if I'm away from the computer.  I got this to replace an old HP digital camera that took great photos.  The image quality of the Canon is much worse.  I suspect that the HP had a much better quality lens.  The battery needs to be recharged after about 170 photos.  I haven't tried the video yet, but I suspect that will shorten the battery life even more.  I was used to taking 250-300 photos with my previous camera before changing the battery.  I read some reviews that said not to even bother with the smart auto mode and I think they are right.  I need to experiment with the 'P' mode to see if I can get some decent photos with this camera.  I had considered getting a cheaper model of the Canon powershot camera but opted for this more expensive one because of the extra feature.  I think the extra money was not well spent since the Canon ELPH 300 performs about as well as a camera costing half as much.  To be fair, I've only had the camera a week and there is a steep learning curve.  If things improve over the next few weeks, I'll add an update and may give this camera a higher rating.  At this time I'm feeling disappointed.Addendum (6/5/11): I've now had several more days to play with the camera and after trying all kinds of settings the picture quality is not much better.  I finally made some videos, which looked nice, but the microphones picked up a lot of extraneous noise even indoors in a quiet room and introduced a kind of background hum into the audio.  If the quality of sound doesn't matter to you, the videos are quite nice.  I've decided to keep the camera because it's so compact and I plan to take it on trips.  The photos are passable but nothing spectacular.  The problems with focusing and overexposure have continued.  I think the lens is just not as good quality as in previous cameras I've owned, including an old Canon.  Maybe the fault lies in me since I'm not an expert on photography. A friend who is a serious photographer offered to go over the camera with me, so after we get together I'll have a better idea.Addendum (6/24/11):  I had this camera for over 3 weeks now and have taken hundreds of photos with it.  My original impression has not changed.  It takes decent photos in general.  The AUTO feature is useless and needs to be avoided outdoors because it totally over-exposes the photos.  It's kind of ludicrous that you can't use the AUTO feature outdoors on a point and shoot camera.  Indoors the AUTO function is acceptable.  The Programable mode does a better job, and it's all that I use now.  Generally I'm disappointed with the quality of the images and It think this has to do with the cheap lens this camera uses.  As I said previously, it is nowhere near the quality of previous Canon cameras I have owned.  The best feature is the small size of the camera, so I will be keeping it and using it on vacations because it is so portable."
20110601"
column1729:
I love this camera. I have owned a few Canon cameras and this one rates among the best. Great low light and night shots!"
20110531"
column1732:
Bought this item to replace an older, heavier Cannon PowerShot.  We LOVE this product - excellent pictures, very high quality case, really good zoom level, very light and slim, and absolutely rock solid picture quality! Flash can be a little over-bright at very short distances, and this camera isn't fantastic for taking super-close ups of busy items (especially flowers/plants), but it has a really great face finder, and even manages to capture animal and bird faces.  Focus is very quick, and the camera turns on very quickly, which is great for capturing quick shots.  High level of pixels means you will have to crop or adjust to load to web, but these quality snaps are going to look great.We are big fans of the Cannon PowerShot series, and this is yet another fantastic product in their line."
20110530"
column1735:
This camera does what it is supposed to. It produces very good quality photos in a small, somewhat rugged package. The video quality and stability are great. The pictures I've taken all over Hawaii have come out fantastic. Settings are limited, but it's a point and shoot camera. I am very happy with mine.I don't like that most of those that knocked this camera start off by saying what other more expensive camera they have. It doesn't fine tune this or that the best, blah, blah, blah. If you're a photography snob or perfectionist then use your expensive camera and be done it."
20110527"
column1738:
I own a Canon EOS 7D (DSLR) and an old SD400.  The SD400 is nearing its end, so I wanted a new small point and shoot to replace it.  I would never expect a new P&S to even approximate the quality of my 7D, but I'd certainly expect more out of a couple generations of PowerShots.Unfortunately, I'm disappointed and will be sending the ELPH 300 back.The good: It's very small, sturdy, and constructed well.  The handling is quite nice with a powder-coated metal frame.  It powers on quickly and the menus are fairly easy to navigate.  The video modes are nice, too, with the 120fps 640x480 mode and 240fps 320x240 mode.  I'd probably never use them, but they're cool.  The newer PowerShots also support SDHC, so they work great with my 8GB Eye-Fi SD card.  The SD400, unfortunately, doesn't support over 2GB.The bad: A new camera isn't worth it if it doesn't exceed the quality of my old 5Mpixel SD400 and this one doesn't.  The auto white balance is poor and doesn't compare the SD400 in either flash or no-flash modes.  With my EOS 7D, I'll shoot in RAW and do post processing in Lightroom, but the point of a P&S is to avoid those hassles.  I'd need to properly balance every picture taken so far with the ELPH 300.With 12 Mpixels, you'd expect pretty good images, but the problem is that the ELPH 300 compression is turned up so high that the sensor's acuity gets lost (softened) in compression.  Without a 'super-fine' mode or at least a higher-quality fine mode, the best simply isn't good enough.  The 5 Mpixel images from the SD400 come pretty close to the acuity of the ELPH's images and are 1/3 the size."
20110526"
column1741:
This camera takes really great pictures.  The pics are good in all types of light.  The videos are fantastic, and I like the fact that I can zoom while shooting.  The size and weight are small. Its the perfect camera to drop in a pocket and take along anywhere."
20110526"
column1744:
The Canon ELPH300 was an update from our older Canon SD700, which we were very happy with. Just received the ELPH yesterday, and put it through its paces yesterday at a school play.  So far, we love this camera. Perfect size, user interface couldn't be easier, and the picture and video quality are stunning for a point-and-shoot.  We've had a string of cameras that have lasted us through about 10K photos each, and this one looks to be another in that line."
20110525"
column1746: Best camera of this class. Period.
column1747:
Well, its better than the Nikon coolpix 3100 that I retuned.  The Nikon did cost me $135 , so I cannot bash it too much just because of the  price.  The biggest quality is the clarity of the HD video, every detail can be seen ,  and yes you can optically zoom while  recording.  Not  like the Nikon which could only digitally zoomed.  Unlike the Nikon, the footage didn't loose quality  while zooming. ( Digital zoom decrease quality on both , pictures and videos )It also  takes great pictures , I know , Isn't that supposed to be the  priority lolMy biggest issue is that it takes a lot of memory for the full HD.  If you don't have at least a 16 GB, you might reconsider  recording in full HD.  I am talking about 555 MB for a 2:07 seconds videos. Yes , you read that right, 555 Megabytes for a two minutes and seven seconds full HD video.  I have two Sandisks SDHC class 10 , one 4GB and one 16GB, the 4GB was almost full before I knew it .  For  Those of you who  are wondering, yes it is fast , nowhere near like a rapid shooting SLR  camera, but with the class 10 , you will get the best for your  money. I was getting  2 second lag between shots.  It was perfect for me although some people might consider that as very slow . Compared to the Nikon I returned , that was a great improvement just in that area,  the Nikon was Slower.Also a little advice, not all SDHC class 10 are the same. From my researches (please forgive me if I am wrong) I could only find one brand that could do 30 MB/S maximum and it was Sandisk.  At least on Amazon .Update: If you turn the preview off, it will take up to a second for the camera to be ready between shots.  It now feels like a rapid fire SLR. Buy his camera, you won't be disappointed ."
20110523"
column1750:
Just got this camera and boi am I in lurveee!!!lol Its beyond my expectations, truly amazing cam. More than worth the price, so dont hesitate, snatch it up!!"
20110523"
column1753:
This is a good little camera. Its a little slow for me but I think thats only because I'm used to my DSLR. I use it all the time and it takes great pics. It also has a ton of special effects to play with which are always fun. I like the fact that taking a video is just one button and that you dont have to switch modes to shoot a video. Comes in handy when you are trying to catch a certain moment. The HD video is surprisingly good for such a small camera. I was able to shoot a full entry video for my friends pageant and it did better then the video camera we had used in the past. I just ordered the underwater case to use on my cruise next month. I cant wait to use it."
20110519"
column1756:
This camera works great except for one serious defect: lens cover is really weak and it doesn't open/close properly. I have encountered this malfunctioning twice (I had my camera replaced once) so I assume there is a problem with this camera. I have tried several types of digital cameras before but it has never occurred with any other cameras."
20110517"
column1759:
I was in the market for a new camera, and this one exceeded all of my expectations! Honestly, this camera has THE FASTEST startup time I have ever seen on a camera. It is ready to go within a second of turning it on; I didn't realize how glad I am for that until I saw my friends' get anxious waiting for their cameras to finally take a picture.The red version of this camera was $20 cheaper; so, I went with it instead of the black. I'm glad I did. It's super sleek and stylish. It gets tons of comments.Shutter Speed/Aperature: No complaints. GREAT. Especially for price.Menu Navigation: This is my first Canon; so, I had a little getting used to the controls, but I really like them now.LCD Screen: It's big and super clear.Battery Life: Incredible! I bought a back-up battery too and haven't had any issues with either battery dying on me.Picture quality: Camera produces superior quality pictures. No lying. It's good.Everything else: Fantastic. I'm really happy with this camera. Add in its compact size, and their is no way anyone could legitimately complain."
20110517"
column1762:
Yea there are better cameras on the market, but they are way but money or are bigger, remember you are not taking the place of a DSLR but are getting a very small all in one, that does everything asked of it very well , Having a cmos sensor instead of a ccd sensor really makes the videos better, I have had all major brands of point and shoot cameras and a Nikon D-50 DSLR , And can say Panasonic has the best for small zooms, Canon has the best for low light always has and now This 10mp 5X Canon is like the 6mp 10X Panasonic (DMC-TZ3) because the 5X Canon is like a 9.5X at 6mp if you view actual size of the Photo. However The canon with it's cmos sensor blows away my Panasonic in low light and it does HD video almost to par with a camcorder, Feels good in your hand too , slight sand texture on body makes it feel solid and expensive and easy to keep from slipping. A extra battery is not very much also."
20110517"
column1765:
Absolutely an amazing camera!!! Small so that you can take everywhere  ( even in your small purse when you go to the club). The resolution is to die forand it is so easy to use. I want to add that I read a  lot of different reviews from different cameras until I found this one. If you are looking for something compact yetworth this is it!! I am enjoying mine."
20110515"
column1768:
Unfortunately, I didn't have much time to try it out  as after a few hours I received the dreaded 'Lens Error' message, and it stopped working.I purchased the camera from another vendor, and I probably took about 10-20 indoor shots before the zoom lens broke. My observations are: very noisy ISO 400 and above, IS at 1/20 seems to be the threshold, picture quality quite dull and muted.I used center focus, and it did focusing, focus lock, recompose very well. The speed burst mode worked well too. In general, it's very responsive and the controls are well-planned. I'm just surprised how poor the images look. I will say, my other cameras are the 7D and the G11 so perhaps my expectations are too high. However, I did compare other photos I shot with my dinosaur Canon SD200, and they looked much better for a point & shoot. I really think they should continue to match/reduce megapixel count to the resolve power of the sensor.I've also researched the cryptic 'Lens Error' message and it looks like it's a very common problem with Canon point & shoots. Canon has a high failure rate amongst point & shoots, while others such as Panasonic (and I don't own any Panasonic cameras) have better quality controls."
20110515"
column1771:
I bought this camera to take pictures of my daughter's first Prom.  Very nice, easy to use, took better pictures than our Canon Rebel.  Very vivid pictures. No delay, took photos very quickly. I did buy a scandisk extreme 8G card.  My co-workers asked what kind of camera I used, the pictures were so nice. I am very happy with this camera."
20110515"
column1774:
After having the camera for 3 weeks and taking good care of it, I got an e3 error. Software problem. Never once dropped it but there was an internal software problem. Just sent it in to be fixed after owning it for 3 weeks. It works for 60 sec before a message comes up saying e3 error and then it shuts off. I've had 4 canon powershot cameras and this is my first time experiencing this type of problem but I trust canon and always come back to it. I always recommend canon over other makers and this is the first time I've had a problem with a canon camera that wasn't self-induced. It should be fine once it's fixed and shipped back to me. Theres a one year warranty and canon's customer service is very helpful. I'll always stick with canon."
20110514"
column1777:
Pros: absolutely fantastic photos in low-light scenes like clubs, parties, and concerts; lots of fun features to keep you entertained (slow motion movies, miniature effect); records detailed 1080p video; fast, always ready, instant on; low noise, especially for a point and shoot; sharp pictures with punchy colors; HS system isn't marketing fluff, it works; teeny.Cons: jell-o effect (rolling shutter) in HD movies, which isn't the camera's fault, it's the nature of CMOS sensors; weird autofocus box tracking thing in auto; scratches like a bitch; screen could be higher resolution; the lens sits in this little ring that protrudes a tiny bit from the front of the camera, and dust collects in this ring like crazy, I have to use a tooth pick to dig it out; flash recycle times aren't incredibly fast.In short, if you need a camera that fits in your pocket (it's smaller than my BlackBerry) and can keep up with your life, get this. There's a few little things you could nitpick, but I dare you to find a better camera for the price."
20110514"
column1780:
This has got to be one of the best Point and Shoot cameras out there (and believe me, I've owned / tested a lot!).  Pictures are very good (a bit soft) and HD video is great.  As of May 2011, this is the one Point and Shoot camera I'd recommend to folks (over S95, Nikon P300 (barely), or Oly XZ-1)."
20110512"
column1783:
I've had this camera for about 2 weeks now. I received it well within the timeframe specified by the shipper. I havent used the camera much but my initial reactions are:Pros:1. Very small and sleek: I used to have a canon powershot A95. So this is a welcome change. Fits very easily in my shirt pocket and really lightweight.2. Picture clarity: This is really good. Took about 30-40 pictures near the lake and experimented with the different scene settings [foliage] - I can see the difference clearly.Cons:The LCD screen is quite large [compared to the A95] and is always open. So I get a little worried about fingerprints and smudges. I am trying to find some sort of a cover for this similar to what I have for my iPhone.I think the lens is wider than that A95, so pictures taken when I am about 10 paces from the subject seems to include a lot of area around the subject. In fact I love that it has a wide-angle lens.To me, neither of these two 'cons' are a deal-breaker.I plan to experiment more in the coming weeks, so I will be updating this review in about 3-4 weeks.Bottomline: If you are looking for an affordable, sleek, lightweight camera with really good results, go for it! I love canon."
20110512"
column1786:
I've owned several Canon Powershots and all have recorded videos in .AVI format.  I purchased this today and shot a sample video.  I then learned to my dismay that the video was recorded in .MOV format, not .AVI.  I've read many reviews on this product but didn't see that fact mentioned.  So for any of you that prefer AVI format, be warned.Also, for anyone who dislikes the rough, sandpapery finish on the black model, the red model has a smooth finish."
20110512"
column1788: Great size and video, poor image quality
column1789:
I bought this camera after reading all the positive reviews here. Overall, I can say that I'm kinda satisfied given that I wanted a small pocket-sized camera that takes good video WITH optical zoom. I wasnt really looking for or expecting great photos.PROS :1. It fits into my purse beautifully, is light and doesnt weigh down my purse (with all the other junk inside it), and form factor is wonderfully portable. Moms : you will love this! :-)2. Video with optical zoom on a small point and shoot!! Yoohoo! This is the main reason I bought it. Of course, you have to hold the camera very steady otherwise there is video-shake, but that is to be expected since this is such a tiny camera. I like the slow 5X optical zoom, because it doesnt cause jumpy video. So far, I've taken lots of video of my kid using this, and quality is very acceptable for my standards (which are not very high).CONS :1. The photos that I've taken so far are really disappointing. I have read other reviews saying they got very good pics, so that is leading me to wonder if I'm doing something wrong here. I cant beleive that a Canon would take grainy pics (even in broad daylight, shooting in Auto mode with largest resolution). Not that I'm expecting DSLR quality, mind you, but I was really surprised at the lack of color richness and sharpness. Can someone please let me know if I'm missing something here? I've owned a Nikon Coolpix point and shoot in the past which took way better photos than this one.Overall, since it meets my specific needs, I'm keeping this camera. But if someone is looking for an all-in-one point and shoot that takes both good pics and video, then look elsewhere!"
20110509"
column1792:
This is one of the worst camera I ever bought. Couple of years back I bought powershot S3IS which is still far better than this camera.Stills at night and video on normal light condition are better than my old camera. But in normal light condition pictures looks lifeless, I wont recommend this if you used an average quality camera before."
20110508"
column1795:
I bought this to have a small pocket size camera when I didn't want to bring along my higher-end Canon DSLR.After taking many shots and small video clips I am very impressed-just what I was looking for!.  The size is fantastic for travel or slipping in your purse/pocket, and easy to take quick shots without drawing attention (like a bigger camera).  I love the red color since it's easy to see and doesn't show fingerprints.  The pictures are all very sharp, zoom is great for most common purposes and videos are crisp.  The shutter isn't super fast like my high end camera, but for a everyday pocket camera it is more than fine.  easy to use, good battery and easy to transfer photos.  highly recommend!!...solid choice for a pocket camera.  Got in 2 days with my Amazon Prime."
20110507"
column1797: Good camera with some very nice bonuses
column1798:
Needed a replacement for my Canon SD750, and this seems to be just fine.Thing that most impressed me is the video mode, with various quality options, but MAINLY actual OPTICAL zoom during recording, and it uses some special technique where the zoom works slower, but it doesnt make noise or vibration, thus not interfering with the recording - very nice ! Will be interesting to compare it to my Canon D60 video capability [when  I get it back]m since DSLRs don't have this nice mechanical smooth zoom functionLow light photos are pretty good also, impressive. General image quality seems to ok, but I still need to do some deeper analysis.The physical layout is pretty  basic and simple, nothing special... the outside does feel like light sandpaper as others have stated, but I guess that good, so theres no risk of it slipping out of your hands.Anyway, haven't had much time to play with it yet, and if any new facts come up I'll update this post, but very happy with it for now !"
20110505"
column1801:
The 300 HS has good features and takes good photos. However, after about 4 days of use, it has developed numerous small radial dents in the bezel around the lens.  This is rather troublesome for long term durability.  The camera has been carried in my pocket and has been treated very well.  I think Canon skimped on the finish and metal thickness of the bezel. Also the black finish around the bezel is easily mared.  It's a great little camera in terms of features and photo quality, but I am considering returning it because of the issues stated above.  I would think very carefully about purchasing this camera.  See the review of the 300 HS at www.steves-digicams.com.  He has similar conerns about dents in the bezel.  Unfortunatly, I did not read Steve's review until after I purchased the camera.  I am very disappoined in Canon on this issue.  By the way, I have owned at least 25 digital cameras over the last 8 years (70% Canons) I have not seen an issue like this before.  I believe that this is a design defect which could eventually effect picture quality."
20110504"
column1804:
I have recently purchased the elph for a trip to Vietnam and Cambodia.It proved to be a reliable and tough little workhorse which I could not fault for the purposes I had in mind.It proved to take a full day of tourist happy snapping without skipping a beat under a diverse and sometimes arduous range of conditions.The power source on the camera could go for days of shooting and reviewing.I would not hesitate to recommend this item."
20110504"
column1807:
This camera does everyhting they promised, the slow-mo is cool, but the relolution is much lower then the HD regular video. So far am very pleased with this purchase."
20110504"
column1810:
Very nice size for a 12 MP camera. The recharging of the battery is very fast as described I think it was 1.5 hours, good low light stills and video."
20110503"
column1812: Traded in my Sony DSC-TX5 for this. Couldn't be happier!
column1813:
I just sold my Sony DSC-TX5 because I was not happy with the image quality. I've played with the new DSC-TX10 and the image quality is pretty much identical to my DSC-TX5. The Sony is a fairly highly rated compact camera but about 40% of the images turned out somewhat blurry, simply lacking sharpness, even in bright light conditions. The Sony does have a lot of nice features such as the 10 feet waterproof, panorama, and low light mode, but what's the use if you have to delete 40% of the pics you take??Getting back to this camera, I am indeed very impressed with it! Images are crystal clear. This is true even when I take side shots while rollerblading! Hand-held night shots are pretty impressive too. Video is great quality (although it eats card space fast). Camera is fast, responsive, and very compact (fits in your jeans no problem). Love the textured coating! I had the Canon SD790IS before and I was looking for something that could give me the same quality of pictures but perhaps smaller and with a wider lens. This is it!Only drawback is that sound quality in video is not great. The microphones seem to be very sensitive and even when you're recording in silence, there's a constant sound of static in the video. I suspect, it would fail miserably in a club setting. All in all, a solid Canon product! Got mine off BestBuy actually (made in Japan!)"
20110427"
column1816:
I bought the 300HS to be my sole photo and video camera. A trip to Disney and 400+ photos & video clips later, I declare it a success. This camera does everything well.With the 300HS, shots that should be easy are easy and they come out well. For shots that are difficult you can switch to manual mode and pick one of several presets for different conditions, or go fully manual and set the exposure, etc. directly. Every shot you'd expect a point & shoot to take, the 300HS takes well. As light levels go down, image quality degrades gracefully -- there are no surprises. The shutter is responsive enough and the camera & flash recycle quickly enough for most uses. I've found no annoying quirks with this camera, it seems to do everything well.For me, this camera replaces a Canon SD1400is that fortunately I broke just in time for the trip. Yes, fortunately. The 300HS is just a minor step up on paper, but everything works so much better -- the images are much sharper, the colors are better, no focusing problems, you can zoom during a video, and it refocuses as the subject moves during a video.Like all Canon Elphs, the camera easily fits in a shirt pocket. The 300HS has a textured finish that makes it less likely to slip out of said pocket.One nice feature is separate buttons for taking a still photo vs. recording a video, so you don't accidentally start a video when you think you're taking a photo and vice versa. A cool feature is slow motion video -- great for analyzing a runner's stride, a golf swing, or just for fun.Minor complaints: You can trim a video clip but there's no way to join two adjacent video clips. The microphones are on the top edge of the camera so I often accidentally cover them with my finger. The 10-minute HD recording limit may prevent you from videoing your kid's school play (though 640x480 records up to an hour). The battery ran down when I used the camera all day, but it's a standard size and aftermarket batteries are cheap; I carry a couple I had left over from my previous Elph. The camera doesn't come with a memory card (I use a Sandisk Ultra 16gb type 4, though type 6 is recommended).Overall the Canon Elph 300HS has great specs, takes great pictures and videos, and is a pleasure to use. You should buy one."
20110423"
column1819:
This is a great camera,  small, easy-to-use and takes very good quality photos and good on the video.This is the fifth canon compact  digital camera that I have owned and without a doubt is the best.  The picture quality is very good on macro, zoom can be a little grainy if you don't have a stable platform to take the photo from.Quite a number of my photos are aerial shots from the helicopter and I find sometimes the delay between taking photos can miss the preferred shot, it's a matter of judging your timing and speed.The video shots I have taken have tended to be a little jumpy but I believe that was me, I need to keep the camera more stable when filming.Overall I'm very happy with the camera, takes great photos and is good value for money."
20110421"
column1822:
I bought this as a companion to my D90. It takes great pictures and is the perfect go-anywhere replacement for my trusty, 5-year-old Elph. Super slim and slip-resistant finish. Fast lens and CMOS sensor takes great low-light photos without flash.I originally bought a Powershot S95 but returned it. The S95 is not as pocket-able, does not zoom while shooting video and doesn't shoot 1080p. I miss the custom settings of the S95, but it's an acceptable tradeoff for the 300 HS's small size and simplicity.I also returned a Panasonic Lumix ZS6 that someone got me for Christmas. The menu system and slow lens/indoor shooting in the Lumix is terrible (in my opinion).Negatives: The lens isn't THAT fast: you'll still have blurry shots of fast-moving kids indoors unless you turn the flash on. Scene selection in the menu system seems awkward.Overall, the 300 HS is an excellent camera. I am glad I returned the S95 and ZS6."
20110419"
column1825:
EDIT #2 (December 2011). I become more and more disappointed in this camera as time goes by. Just reviewed loads of photos from this summer/fall and I hate to say it, but -- they suck! My former Canon AS1100 (vintage 2008) took photos soooooo much better than thing. Interior shots are especially bad, whether flash is used or not. I figured to take this camera on a long international journey, but forget it. The photos are that disappointing. I did take the AS1100 on a long international journey (six months in Africa) and its photos were awesome. One even won a photo contest. The AS1100 hd a CCD sensor and the Elph 300 a CMOS -- that's the thing.So, I guess I'll be shopping for a new camera in the next few months. :(EDIT: I originally gave this 5 stars. Well, after shooting many photos under a variety of conditions during a recent vacation, I have to drop it to 4 stars. Using the camera's Auto mode, on many shots, the image quality is poor to mediocre. I assumed Auto mode image quality would be superior to the last two (and less expensive) Nikon and Canon point and shoots I have owned, but that is definitely not the case. Auto mode images tend to be soft and faint and not realistic, e.g., grass is a faint green, not the rich green of healthy grass. Pretty disappointing! To get the most from this camera, you have to use Program mode and set ISO at 100 or 200, and experiment with the manual white balance settings. Then photos come out much better, with improved quality and richness and color accuracy. Unfortunately, the camera doesn't allow you to apply custom ISO and WB settings to various scene modes, like Foliage or Fisheye.ORIGINAL: One of the best things about this camera is its 24 mm wide angle lens. This is wider than the 28mm lens that is standard on most pocket-sized point and shoots (and the Elph 100, a step down from the Elph 300) and it is very cool. If you're not familiar with how 24 mm vs. 28 mm compares, do a little Googling. It's outstanding for landscape shots and group shots and makes photos more engaging and descriptive, with no downside. Great move, Canon!The small size of the camera is fantastic. Pocketability and performance are very nicely balanced in this well built and well designed camera. It was good to see Canon back out of the megapixel war and reduce the megapixels on this model to 12.1, from 14 in its predecessor (the SD 1400). With the 5x optical zoom, CMOS sensor (vs. CCD), HD video and an impressive palette of shooting options, there's a lot to like in this little gem.One peculiarity is that the volume on video playback on the camera is extremely low. It's difficult to hear if you're playing back videos on the camera. It's a lot lower than another Canon point and shoot that I used for a few years. I think I have it adjusted to the max, though I have to take a closer look at the manual. Which leads me to ...Raspberries to Canon for not including a full user manual booklet. Since when has it become acceptable to sell a product without providing the customer with an easy means of learning how to use it? (I know, lots of mfr's do it but still). I travel extensively for months on end with a point and shoot and refer to the manual fairly often. If I want to look up some detail or just browse, I could just grab the manual from my pack over a cup of coffee. Does Canon expect me to lug around a printout of the full PDF manual? It's not always convenient to have a netbook running and use the manual on it. Nor is it as enjoyable or instructive as flipping through a book.Though I can see some logic in not providing a full booklet and am all for not wasting paper, I would be happy if Canon made available for purchase a proper user manual for $10 or $12 or whatever."
20110409"
column1828:
I was interested in the Flip HD pocket video camera or the Kodak Playsport. Then I came across a Youtube video by 'The World According to Jon' where he argues against purchasing a pocket video camera. Instead he recommended buying a *real* digital camera with video capability. I followed his advice, and after several days of painstaking research, I finally decided to buy a Canon Elph 300 HS.Size:I went to a brick and mortar store, and was shocked to know how tiny this camera really is. It is almost like the size of a credit card, and almost as thin as a smartphone. It is very light and very pocketable.Build:I bought the black unit. It has this anti-slip, gritty feel to it. I appreciate this tiny nuance to avoid accidental slippage. The camera body is metal and not plastic. It feels good in your hands and it looks pricy rather than cheap. It looks very stylish and hip too.Features:I'm amazed how Canon was able to squeeze tremendous features into a camera this tiny. It has features available only to more expensive and larger digital cameras.Price:This camera is way *UNDERPRICED* ... but don't tell Canon about it. BTW, I got mine on sale at BB for $20 off retail.Performance:I ordered two 8-gigs SDcard from Amazon which has not arrived yet. So, I used an old Sandisk 2-gigs, class 2 SDcard. I used the Smart AUTO function and took pictures in low light (only the light from my computer monitor in a darkened room). The quality of the pics was very good. I took a few seconds of 1080p video hoping that my Canon won't choke. I was amazed that the Canon took a 1080p video although the quality was a little bit grainy (in very low light). I took several pics underneath flourescent lighting in the gym, and the pics were excellent. Flesh tones were true and not saturated.One of my favorite features so far, is the Movie Digest. If you select this feature, this little Canon will take a few seconds of video before it takes a picture. So at the end of the day, you can stitch together a full-length video show out of the few seconds of video snippets. Simpy amazing !!!!!I'm still exploring the various features of my tiny Canon. I'm like a kid playing with a new toy I just unwrapped under my Christmas tree. It is Christmas in April.Conclusion:If time is priceless, then this camera is a good investment because it captures and freezes moments extremely well that would have otherwise been lost forever.I have absolutely no regrets with this purchase. It is money well-spent and the ROI is mind-boogling. This little camera is way beyond my most optimistic expectations."
20110409"
column1831:
I bought this camera to replace my Sony Cybershot DSCW170/B 10.1MP Digital Camera after that camera broke from only 2.5 years of use.  I really liked the performance of that camera but was surprised at its fragility.  I really like the simplicity of operation and the quality of pictures this Canon takes so far and really hoping this one lasts longer."
20110406"
column1834:
Beautiful product quality and excellent functionality in an amazingly small and very attractive package, all at an exceptionally low price considering. Picture quality is very good, surprisingly close to the Leica D-Lux 4 (Panasonic LX3) and the Olympus XZ 1 that I compared it against. The best and best value compact point and shoot on the market for sure. I haven't yet tried its full HD / stereo recording (one can use the zoom too), but reviews are glowing. Bravo, Canon!"
20110404"
column1837:
Bought this camera to use as a pocket point and shoot, as my canon dslr is not always convenient to carry around.  I bought this camera because of it's size, and i was not disappointed.  It is as thin as an iphone, and easily fits in my pocket.  Image quality is very good for a point and shoot, and the low light hs system seems to work very well.  While it won't come close to replacing my dslr for low light photography, it takes very good low light photographs.  battery life is adequate, but i would recommend a second battery if you will be shooting for extended periods of time. If you are looking for a pocket point and shot, this is a Great Camera."
20110402"
column1839: Not a bad little camera but some things need improving
column1840:
I bought this to replace my old A590IS. I also have a good canon HD video camera and a Nikon D40 dslr. I'm going to Florida in a week and wanted a great point and shoot that could do it all. I was going to only use the 300 HS and keep my video camera and DSLR at home. I did a lot of research and bought the ELPH 300 HS. I'm impressed with the features and the speed it can take photos. However I'm disappointed at the size of the videos, audio and very short battery life. I set the camera to 720P and recorded myself playing guitar for 10 minutes. I then loaded it onto my computer and noticed it took up 1.62GB of space. I compared this to a 10 minute 1080 video from my canon HD video camera and that only took up 800mb. There is no excuse why the 300 HS has to take up twice as much space on a ten minute video. For example the new flip video HD will record 2 Hours of HD video on only 8GB. If you recorded 2 hours on the 300HS at 720P (not even the highest setting) your looking at about 20GBs.  Also there should not be a time limit of ten minutes for the videos. It should let you continue recording until the memory card is full (I have a 32GB card in the camera). On the plus side the video looks great, the camera focuses great and I like the slow zoom when recording. Now the thing that bothers me more then the size of the video is the static sound. It actually picks up sound very good with no distortions but there is what I can only describe as a water fall sound in the background during my videos (and there was no other sounds in the room that would cause this). I can not use this camera to record my guitar lessons or demos seeing as the water fall sound just kills it. I also only got about 150 pictures and just a few videos before the battery went dead. I do have another one I keep with me but this seems a little fast. If canon could fix the static/waterfall sound during recording, bring down the file size of the videos and kick up the battyer life a little this would be a perfect little camera."
20110330"
column1843:
I have wanted a camera for some time that could take decent low-light photos and 1080p hi-def video.  I thought I'd have to go with a bulky Four-Thirds camera or an SLR.  But the CMOS sensor in the 300HS does a nice job in low light.  It would be interesting if someone could do a side-by-side test to see how close this camera comes to, say, the Panasonic DMC-GH1K in this respect.  I also like the multiple-frames-per-second stills (even faster at 3 megabytes).  The 24mm (equivalent) lens is free of fish-eye distortion (except in extreme close-ups where you might actually want it), perhaps due to computed correction within the camera.It is a bit inconvenient to switch between functions because the buttons and the screen icons are small.  Although a rotating function dial like the ones that Panasonic and Fuji use would make switching easier, clearly there isn't room for one on a camera this small.  If the camera is to fit in a pocket this is one of the necessary trade-offs.I had been concerned that the 300HS would be significantly larger than the SD780IS it replaced, but no worries.  The difference in thickness, the most important dimension for me in a pocket camera, is not significant.  So here is this little gem with 5X optical zoom, optical image stabilization, fast frame rate, hi-def video, and good low-light capability, and it all fits in a pocket!  Don't tell Canon but they aren't charging enough for this camera."
20110330"
column1845: Great Camera with a rough finish
column1846:
