I have not had the camera for long (2 weeks) but so far it's great.Pros:-Very compact.-Great video and photo quality.-Wide angle lens is the best and now a must in all my future point and shoot cameras.-Miniurature scene mode is fun to use-Slow motion video is also great.-Compact battery charger is genius when you compare to the charger I have for my Nikon (bulky charger with a 3 foot cord/ a pain in the rump to pack when travelling light).-Power on and ready to shoot is super fastCons:-getting to a scene mode in a hurry is difficult.  Once you get the hang of it you get faster but still not ideal.-Rough finish on Black model (see more below)-Wrist strap does not tighten-up like my old Canon SD450 did.-mini usb cover looks weak (be gentle on it)I had to write this primarily because while researching the camera I was never made aware that the black Elph 300 HS has a very textured feeling.  At the end of a long winter here in Montreal my wife and I have quite dry hands and the feeling of the (slightly rough) textured finish is well kinda Icky feeling.  I can't describe how it feels except it's a slightly like holding a piece of sand paper.  Something you get used to after a few minutes but noticable after you haven't held the camera for a few hours. I hope the summer months will soften my hand and therefore the feeling.I would have prefered that black rubberized finish that you see alot on other devices such as my BB Bold, or the smooth finish you find on the silver model.However this roughly textured finish will certainly give you a better grip on the camera and help prevent you from dropping it."
20110329"
column1849:
I currently own a 5D Mark II and was looking to replace my Canon S80 which is now 6 yrs old. While I love the S80 and the quality pics it captured, the bulkiness of this point-and-shoot (P&S) became inconvenient. My wife was adamant she wanted a more compact P&S this time around.In addition to great pics, I was looking for a P&S with 1080p video capability so I wouldn't have to get a separate camcorder. Let me say that the 300 HS is a quality camera packed into a sleek body that I can easily slip into any pocket on the run.Most Canon cameras (I am a Canon loyalist) take great shots. But what most impresses me about this camera are its low-light capabilities.  It obviously can not match the image quality of a DSLR, but for a P&S, I was impressed!  Indoor night shots of my kids WITHOUT flash (incandescent lighting only) come out amazingly crisp with minimal noise. Autofocus is quite impressive as it tracks faces in the frame further enhancing ease of use. Menu functions are quite intuitive (if you've owned previous Canon models). It's got plenty of preset shooting modes. And it's quick between shots for a P&S (a couple seconds with flash photography).I also compared the 1080p video vs Flip Ultra HD which shoots in 720p. The video quality is like night-and-day with the 300 HS finishing ahead by a mile. Low-light video is grainy but still watchable (unwatchable on Flip). In daylight, video looks beautiful. Video is easily imported into both iphoto and imovie.  Just make sure you have a large memory card as 1080p takes up 16GB/hour of video.  I bought a 32GB card.I did purchase an extra battery after reading battery life can be short. I've had the camera a week and have used it for 15-30 minutes daily (including video capture) and I have not needed to recharge yet.I'd also recommend the black body as it has a textured housing that makes holding this small camera much easier.Also purchased a Caselogic TBC - 302 compact camera case which fits this camera perfectly.  It has a small side pocket that I slip the extra battery in.Overall, considering the excellent quality of the camera, easy portability, and great price, this camera is worth every penny."
20110324"
column1851: Best camera I have had yet!
column1852:
I needed a camera that was small but took clear clean pictures and video. The Cannon ELPH 300HS delivers! I looked around for a while before making my mind and I am so glad I took my time. I have a two and four year old who are very active and we take lots of trips so I wanted something that was going to catch all the action but was still small enough to take around with me all the time. This camera is perfect for everyday picture taking and the full HD 1080p video with the HDMI hook up is a huge plus! Great camera for a great price!!"
20110322"
column1855:
Got it today. Taking pictures & video in low light. I'm very impressed - this is MUCH better than your camera phone, will make you forget Flip Video forever, and is tiny, tiny, tiny. Macro photos in low light, obscenely good. In twilight, flash off, snapped a photo of my computer keyboard, and saw an eyelash on my 'option' key (that's 'alt' key for Windows folk).Let me say it again, in low light this camera is amazing.Build quality is excellent, buttons are large enough for western fingers, and it's undeniably cute. Adorable even.My goal was to get something pocketable that would do better than my iPhone 4 for still pix. Check for sure. Replace my Flip HD. Check (and then some).I have a Canon G10 which takes awesome photos in good light. And shoots raw. And my rm has a Sony NEX5 which is even better. But the G10 is heavy, so I don't bring it. And the NEX5 isn't mine.I've bought other compact digicams in the past, but they have been so BAD compared to bigger ones. This one is quite amazing, a tiny bit of a compromise, but not by much. I'm finally happy with a compact digicam. You can slip it in your pocket just like a cellphone."
20110321"
column1857: Trade up to this very nice camera
column1858:
There were five things that attracted me to replace my ELPH 1100IS (which I consider one of the best of the point-and-shoots at its time) with the 300 HS: 12 MP, 24mm wide angle, 5x zoom, Image Stabilization, and new High Sensitivity CMOS sensor.  Lesser features were the HD movie mode and burst still shots.  The camera delivers all these very well except the 12MP, which I'll get to later.  The controls are slightly different from the traditional ELPH cameras.  The 300 HS has a dedicated movie button (so you don't accidentally take a movie in the middle of the old slide control), and a dedicated Review button (which allows you to switch back and forth between the Shooting and Review mods much more easily).  There is a mode 'switch' to select between AUTO, and Manual.Strangely, I get higher resolution pictures with the AUTO mode than any of the (MANY) Manual modes.  For example, in the Best Image Selection mode, I get a resolution of 900 Line Widths per Picture Height, where in the AUTO mode I get 2,000 LW/PH.  This is due manly to the Best Image Selection pictures being shot at 1984 x 1488 instead of 4000 x 3000 pixels.  However, with the 1100 IS I got 1,800 LW/PH.  Mathematically, the 12MP 300HS should have gotten 22% better resolution than the 8MP 1100IS, but only gets about 11% better resolution.  Maybe this is because the relatively small lens of the point-and-shoot cannot resolve the pixels on the chip.Image Stabilization seems to be improved over the 1100, and the CMOS sensor is noticeably more sensitive than the 1100IS.  This (and the improved IS) result in sharper pictures in low light, because they are taken at higher shutter speeds and ISO levels.There a few 'gotchas'.  The rocker switch is slightly recessed and harder to operate.  To select ISO Lock (for taking panorama pictures) one must first select the Manual switch, activate the Function Set, and select the Program mode.  All this was not required in the 1100IS.  One can read my test procedures at [...]All in all, this camera takes really good pictures."
20110319"
column1860: Wonderful compact camera with hd video
column1861:
I'm a DSLR photographer who shoots professionally and has managed a camera store in the past. I wanted something I can take with me everywhere but still produces good quality shots. I also wanted a camera that could shoot good looking videos. I researched several models and after much deliberation decided on the Canon 300 HS. I'm very happy I did.Image Quality:I tested cameras and lenses all the time while managing the camera store so whenever I purchase a new camera or lens I always test it. The Canon 300 HS doesn't produce the quality of images my Nikon D7000 does but I didn't expect it to. The edges get a little soft with the 300 HS when looking at the image at 100% whereas the D7000 images are almost tact sharp.Comparing the 300 HS to the Canon Powershot SD1000 from a few years ago, the 300 HS blows it out of the water. The SD1000 is a 7 MP camera. Shooting the same shots on a tripod with the same focal length on the lens the 300 HS uses its extra MPs well. When looking at the images from each camera at 100%, at the wide angle zoom setting and normal zoom setting both cameras have about the same relative slight softness on the edges. However the 300 HS has more MP so it actually produces much more detail in the image. I think it was smart for Canon to keep the MP at 12 because last years models while being 14 MP (SD1400) didn't give any extra detail from what I could tell than the 12 MP version (SD1300). The SD1400 was basically just creating larger files. When zooming in the telephoto setting the 300 HS clearly produced a sharper image than the SD1000. Often cameras have sweet spots in the zoom range in which it will produce crisper images. The 300 HS has consistently good sharpness throughout it's zoom range.HS system and ISO:The image processing with the HS system truly works to reduce noise at higher ISOs enabling people to produce better quality images in low light. The improvement in image quality gets more and more visible the greater and greater the ISO. ISO 400 with the 300 HS was almost as good as ISO 200 on the SD1000. ISO 800 on the 300 HS was a tad better than ISO 400 on the SD1000. ISO 1600 on the 300 HS was between ISO 400 and 800 on the SD1000. ISO 3200 on the 300 HS produced the same quality of image (noise) as ISO 800 on the SD1000. A 2 stop in film speed improvement is big.1080p video and slow motion:With good light, the 300 HS produces wonderful smooth 1080 videos. If you look at a lot of HD videos from compact cameras the video often looks jumpy. From what I've seen it wasn't until you got to the Canon G12 or Panasonic LX5 that the video looked smooth. Both of those cameras only shoot 720p whereas this camera shoots 1080p. The video also very good detail. It truly looks HD.If you are wanting zoom and continuous AF with your video this camera is the one you want compared to the 100 HS which doesn't allow you to zoom. The continuous AF with face recognition is stellar with this camera in video mode. I was videoing my wife while she was driving. It focused on her face. I switched to the scenery outside. It immediately focused on that. I then went back to my wife and it found her face and focused on it right away. I even videoed her reflection in the rear view mirror and it found her face in the mirror no problem and focused on it. AMAZING!!!!Commenting on a complaint I've read about the zoom being slow in video mode. If you like getting motion sickness whenever someone rapidly zooms in or out during their video this is not your camera. As smooth looking as the video is, the zoom is also. The smooth zoom creates nice looking transitions instead of warp speed ahead looks.The slow motion is a fun feature that works well. You need to have good lighting though. In low light even with high ISO's it produced very dark videos. In a review someone commented that it should have sound with the slow motion video. I honestly don't know how that could work unless you want to listen to everything at 1/5 it's normal speed. I think it's a good thing that it doesn't have sound with the slow motion videos.AF:I commented on AF partially in the video portion of the review. It does have several AF modes for various situations. The face detection works great. If you have a person in the picture but want something other than the person to be in focus you will need to change AF modes from face detection. The reviewer that had the problem with the 300 HS focusing on things he didn't want the camera to focus on likely didn't have the correct AF mode for the shooting situations. The 300 HS does have a center AF if you prefer that.Areas for Canon to improve on with the 300 HS:The camera is so well thought out that I'm surprised Canon let this slip. I love having a wide angle zoom go down to 24mm. It's great for scenery and photojournalist type shots. If you shoot at the widest angle zoom and use the flash, the lens on the 300 HS blocks the flash's exposure on the bottom right corner of the image. The corner is completely black. If you zoom in a bit so you aren't at the widest angle setting when using the flash you will be fine. Still all Canon had to do is not put the flash so close to the lens.When shooting video in lower light situations the video does start to get noisy and grainy quicker than some other cameras.Conclusion:All in all this is a wonderfully thought out camera with great image quality and image processing and it shoots stellar videos for it's compact size."
20110319"
column1863: Great camera if it's what you're looking for
column1864:
I've only had it for a couple days now, but I can honestly say this camera was worth every penny so far. It has a lot of interesting features, and is the only camera I have found that hits all the strong points I was looking for (120 fps @ 640x480 resolution, full 1080 hd video, optical zoom and auto focus during movie recording, strong low-light performance, good image stabilization, and small form factor [very small. much smaller than other cameras like it that I was considering])Other things of note: I have Photoshop, and use it regularly, so I wasn't looking for a camera that can do everything by itself. This camera cannot shoot hdr pictures by itself like the Exilim ZR-10 or 100 can, nor can it take panoramic pictures all by itself. It does have a 'panorama helper' kind of application, which will help you line up the shots, but you must then use software later to merge them (it comes with software, compatible with both mac and pc, that will help you merge photos, as well as sort through them and manage them, but I find that Photoshop does a much better job than the packaged software does at creating panoramas. I also use the HDR toning option on Photoshop to simulate an actual HDR picture. As long as all the details are there (not blown out or too dark to brighten), PS can create a very convincing HDR picture, and this camera does a good job at getting all the detail in pictures.It also doesn't take the fastest pictures (around 3 per second) on continuous mode, but I rarely (if ever) take more than 1 picture at a time. I may take pictures in succession, but I generally set each one up, rather than just shotgunning a bunch of pictures.The pictures are very sharp. I haven't had much time with video or sound yet, but the little that I have played around with it produced pretty good results. (altho sound can get very distorted with windy sound in a windy environment, as many camera's microphones can. still thinking about/searching for a remedy...)Also, just a little side note, the finish on the camera is left a bit rough. This is a good thing, as it gives the camera more grip, and makes it less likely to slip out of your hand. I have used cameras that were shiny and slippery before, and it make taking pictures with one hand much more difficult and risky. The rough texture keep this camera more firm in your hand. This also makes the camera less prone to finger prints, altho the screen will collect plenty of those (but that has never really bothered me much)Just a couple knocks against it that I have found so far, but they are not deal breakers for me. It says that it can take pictures with shutter speeds between 1/2000s and 15s. This may be true, but it is not user choosable. You cannot set the shutter speed of the camera. It has options for 'Longer Exposure' (or something named like that), but does not let you choose the speed. I have not gotten it to hit a 15 second exposure yet. I was thinking of trying a city scene on a tripod where you set the exposure long so that the car lights look like streaks, but it doesn't seem to stay open long enough.Also, the zoom doesn't seem to be variable, it goes at one speed, and it's pretty fast, so sometimes it can be hard to hit that sweet spot if you are trying to get a shot somewhere in the middle (5x zoom, which I think is very reasonable for it's size), and optical zoom is pretty slow while recording video, but still an option, which is more than many cameras of this type can say. The battery may also be a tad short (especially if doing a lot of video and/or zooming in and out, but that will shorten the life all camera batteries), but they are pretty small, and you can get extra, generic batteries for very cheap.There is no way to plug in the camera to a wall for continuous shooting/video, so you need to replace the battery when it dies. However, I have seen the option of having a battery stand-in that sits in the battery slot and runs a line down to an adapter that plugs into the wall, but this will require you to leave the battery door open while using it)For everything your getting, I think this camera is well worth $250. It takes sharp, accurately colored pictures look great on their own, as well as with Photoshop. If you do not own any imaging editing software, this camera still produces great pictures, has a ton of very cool, very interesting modes (some of which I've never seen on any camera before), and comes with some simple editing software (mainly for merging panorama shots. there is also other, free image editing software out there on the internet if you are so inclined)Edit:You CAN choose the shutter speed, it's just not as simple to find as some of the other options. You have to go into program mode, choose the Long Shutter option. Exit program mode. When you're back to the normal screen, press the up button (+/-). From there, you can choose the shutter speed by pressing right and left. Glad to find the option!"
20110317"
column1867:
So far I'm really enjoying this camera. I've had it for two days now so I'm giving my first impressions. As time goes by, I'll flesh out my review. And this point of view is from someone who has only used point and shoot cameras, by the way. :)Why I bought it - I wanted a more powerful point and shoot camera. I'm still very much a novice photographer but I do like having quality shots, especially for such events as weddings, graduations, bdays, and everyday outings. Originally I wanted the S95 but saw that the new PS ELPH 300 HS had comparable specs and was powerful but still had a simple design. $250 is the most I've paid for a camera but also cheaper than the S95. Nonetheless, I saw this purchase a long term investment of sorts!Design layout - the black model looks sleek, is thin and very pocketable. It doesn't weigh down my purse at all. It has a rougher material design rather than the smooth metal surface I'm used to, which is a nice change. I feel like a get a better grip on the camera which is already so small. Overall, I like the design.Button layout - Having owned two digital cameras in the past (Sony and Fujifilm) I didn't have a hard time figuring out what buttons do and the menu system. Low learning curve overall. And nothing reading through the manual can't help. :)Image/video quality - I've been playing with the different effects (fisheye and miniature are cool), video shooting (1080p HD and you can zoom during filming), macro mode, different aspect ratios (square mode, 16:9), indoor, outdoor, flash, etc. Very happy/impressed with the quality. Shots turn out very clear and crisp and you can see a lot of detail in the photographs- even in macro mode, which has been terrible in my old cameras!To be continued. Again, I'll flesh out my review as time goes on.So far, I really like this camera!"
20110314"
column1870:
This is a point and shoot class camera, if you understand that going in, you are going to be more than impressed with it. I'm going from an SD630 and hands down, this beats it. I even had an SX210IS and these images are on par with it, if not better. I had to return my SX210IS as it had issues with dust on the image sensor and I've been waiting for a new P&S class to come out. I bit the bullet on this camera and what can I say - I am happy!300HS vs 500HS:There is a 500HS version of the camera, which is approx $50 more. To this point, the only differences I can tell are the LCD on the back as well as aperture priority and shutter priority, while the 300hs does not. The touch screen on the 500hs can also be used to focus on a particular subject. The 500hs also has a wider aperture at 2.0, the 300hs has 2.7.Form Factor/Display:Small. Awesome. There is a texture on the camera, I really like this as it seems like it will help if you hands are wet (sweat, snow, etc). Easy to operate one hand and if using both hands, flash isn't in a horrible place. Display is very bright and button seem intuitive as with other Canon cameras. Battery and SD are on the bottom door, USB and HDMI are in a covered side port. Comes with a wrist strap if you desire a little extra security.Boot Time/Software:Camera is ready to take photos very fast. From the time you press the button, it's pretty much set to catch the action. Time between photos wasn't terrible (about 1.5 seconds) and if you need it, there is continuous shot mode. Had no problem with the Canon software on Windows 7. I've used the Canon Photo Window import for a while, does a good job of getting photos off the camera without duplicates. I use Picasa to then manage my photo library (I skip the Zoom Browser, but it's really not bad if you want to use it, I'm just a slave to Google/gmail)Computer Connectivity:I didn't find this anywhere in the specs, so if you're looking, the camera uses mini-USB, similar to all Canon's that have come out over the last few years.Optical Zoom:You're going to be impressed with the form factor of this camera and it's 5x OPTICAL zoom. I immediately disabled digital zoom as 12.1MP + 5x Optical will get you very close to the action. You're better off digitally enhancing the photos later on.Battery + Memory Card:This uses the NBL-4 (again, I found confusion on this and accessories) - so if you have some of those laying around keep them as they'll work just fine in this camera. This is nice as my SD630 uses the NBL-4 so now I have 2 chargers + 3 batteries. It took my 16GB SDHC (Sandisk Ultra) without any issues and holds thousands of images. Images have tended to be between 2 and 3mb on the highest settings.Image Quality:Look, I'm no photo fanatic, I don't expect the people buying this camera are. I am looking for solid images and this camera delivers. There are a ton a feature you can delve into and I'm sure they are good. It has manual mode, so if you fancy that, you can go down that path. But I'm the type of person that knows when something looks good, OK or great. This camera consistently delivers GREAT photos. I'm happy with the low light and images aren't blurry or grainy (within reasonable expectations).Video:FINALLY! Optical zoom on a Canon during video! 1080p brings this camera up to par with others in its class and it does a decent job. I didn't notice any major noise when zooming in and out while recording video. I know this is the excuse Canon has used in the past as to why they never had this feature. It shoots nice clips for those quick moments. This will NOT replace a true DV cam, but hey, for a few minute clips here and there, you will simply not be dissapointed."
20110313"
column1873:
I was debating getting a pocket HD cam and thought why not just get this, the price is about the same and maybe the video quality will be a little better.  Plus, portable point and shoot with fun modes built in. The video quality is comprable to the pocket HD cams, and it is smaller than the pocket HD cam I had before.  I am still surprised at the size.  It is smaller than my smartphone.I'm having trouble in lower light settings with all functions of the camera, but I'm still learning it.  The camera isn't as intuitive as I hoped, but as soon as I figured out where all the menus were I was more or less good to go and play around.Currently the amazon info says it has creative light 'Creative Light Effect Transform background bright spots to stars, hearts, music motes and more.' I was looking forward to this, but I haven't been able to find it, and it isn't listed as a shooting mode on the canon site.  That makes me a little bit sad.  One of the other things that isn't clear from the camera info is that you cannot shoot slow motion in HD (240fps is 320 and 120fps shoots at 640) and there is no audio.  Not the end of the world given all the other things the camera does, but again, something I was hoping to play with that I won't be able to.Overall the quality is what I would expect given the price.  I am still in awe of the tiny size and weight.  It really does fit in my pocket.  I'm happy with the quality of the HD video for web display (it doesn't look so great going through HDMI on our 42in HDTV).  And once I figured out how to access the different shooting modes etc, it became very easy to use."
20110312"
column1876:
I expected a lot better from a camera in the Canon Elph series than the 300 HS produced. The camera I received doesn't want to focus on the objects that I want it to focus on. I have tried both automatic and manual modes, and it still won't produce a consistant in focus photo. The couple of photos that I did manage to get in focus, were much to grainy. The camera is a severe disappointment for me, and is being return for a refund.The body of the camera has a rough feel texture. Another problem with this camera is that no where on the body is it designed for you to effectively hold the camera. The flash placement is such that it can easily be blocked or adversely effected by how the user holds the camera."
20110310"
column1879:
Got this camera from my Japanese friend as a birthday gift, which is IXY 410F.  I found out that camera name in USA is ELPH 300 HS.  After open the box and play couple days, the weight is super light as my old school Canon SD1000 and the indoor picture quality is not bad comparing with my current S95, so it catched my eyes right away after we received it.  Even it's SD1400 replacement from canon point of view, I have to say this tiny camera with S95 quality.ELPH 300 HS vs S95ELPH 300 HS wins on 1080P movie, weight (70% of S95), CMOS sensor, 24mm, 5x zoom, shooting speed (2 time faster than S95), cost (62.5% of S95)S95 is better on the sensor size (1/1.7' as G12), Aperture F/2.0, RAW.I would say...For sure S95 won on manual setting, but I used my Canon Rebel XS most of the time when looking for quality pictures, and S95 didn't provide more point-and-shoot advantages than ELPH 300 HS to me. CMOS sensor is more sensertive comparing with CCD, so I cannot tell huge difference between bigger size CCD and smaller size CMOS sensors even from those indoor low light pictures.  End out, I traded the manual settings to small size, light weight, and fast shooting speed.So, my S95 moved on eBay...... and IXY 410F (ELPH 300 HS) is in my wife's bag......  I have to wait for it to be available on Amazon to get another one for myself."
20120406"
column1882:
The quality of this camera is amazing! It's so thin and study! Get it nooooowwwww! Best quality at this price!"
20120405"
column1885:
The camera iscompact, easy to use. If you need something small to take vacation, party or general snapshots I think you'll be pleased."
20120405"
column1887: Nice Cool Camara But Image Quilty Not As Expected
column1888:
Video Quality is great better then expected,Has aolt of great video and picture featuresbut the images quality is much less then expected,too dark and red eye can also use some help.i wish i could return this, and get something better"
20120404"
column1891:
Let me be the first to say that I am not a camera genius.  I wanted something that was simple to use and could take good pictures for email and web.  That is exactly what I got.  I love it.  It is extremely simple and takes, in my opinion, great pictures by just pointing and pushing the button.  I'm very pleased."
20120403"
column1894:
I bought this camera in June 2011.  The pictures were good, though not as great as I had hoped.  They were only somewhat better than those I had taken with a Sony Cybershot purchased in 2003.  The HD video, however, was excellent and quickly became a favorite feature.  Unfortunately, the camera refused to open when I turned it on in September.  I sent it back to Canon and they replaced it.  I paid shipping.  I had a new camera in a week.  The camera they sent me, however, was defective.  The shutter would not consistently open all the way or close completely.  I needed to send it back again.  They paid shipping this time, and replaced it once more.  Another week without a camera.  In January, I noticed a spot had developed on the lens that showed up on any photo I took with telephoto.  Very frustrating.  I didn't address it immediately with Canon, however, having already been frustrated with my experiences with the camera.  Then last week I took the camera to the park--I placed it in my front pants pocket as I've always done, and when I took it out, the top of the camera had split open and one of the tabs that held the camera together was sticking out.  I sent the camera back to Canon.  They considered this damage to the camera and refused to fix it without charging me $140.  Now, nine months into this camera, I'm left with virtually nothing--I'm not going to invest anymore money into the camera because of its durability issues.  My Sony lasted eight years--the main reason I wanted to upgrade was the advances in technology.  I didn't treat this camera any differently than I treated the Sony.  My recommendation is to stay away from this Canon Powershot Elph 300 HS--it's a durability nightmare.  Four major concerns in nine months, and now, no Canon support."
20120402"
column1897:
I've been using the camera for a while now and have not had any issues. It is easy to use and takes good pictures. I do recommend it. Excellent optics,small & thin... very compact.The only problem is I should have waited a couple of months to purchace it. It dropped from $180.00 to $130.00 in that time period."
20120401"
column1900:
I purchased this camera in May 2011 as a replacement for another Canon Powershot that had a lens failure (lens stuck out and could not retract). In March of 2012, our gently used PowerShot ELPH 300HS lens, while on vacation, also spontaneously had the lens failure 'Lens Error... Will shut down automatically.. Please restart camera' error. Ugh.All of the recommended tips to 'unstick' the guide pins on this lens failed so, I have another $250 down the drain. Never again. I researched this purchase extensively, and chose the 300HS so I could reuse the battery packs and charger from my previous PowerShot. The camera worked well prior to it's demise. However, after the second Canon PowerShot to die the same death with potentially dirt or fragile guide pins in the automatically retracting/extending lens...I have determined that this type of lens in general is a serious design flaw and should be avoided.With a camera at this price range, it's really not worth sending back for repairs, as it will be at least 1/2 the cost of the camera to repair.I would highly recommend people consider more ruggedized versions, or a 'sealed' lens that does not have fully automatic extension/retraction. This may be available in some of the higher-end waterproof digital cameras out there on the market that do not have the concentric lens barrels that can get small dirt or sand particles stuck in them causing this error. Another option I would consider is investing in slightly higher end fixed-lenses, or simply rely on better smart phones with built-in cameras if portability is a key factor."
20120331"
column1903:
i've had this camera for about 6 months and I still enjoy it. It's small size is very nice  while out with the family. it has many great function modes. The video is also wonderful. I have shaky hands and the camera adjust while in video mode to compensate"
20120331"
column1906:
I am admittedly not a pro, nor have I used this camera extensively. So please realize that these are just my initial impressions.At this point I am thrilled to have bought this camera. The quality of pictures has been impressive, the camera has been very easy to use and, I LOVE the size of it.I WILL be VERY careful with it as I have read all the reviews about 'the dreaded lens errors'! Actually, those reviews are part of the reason I bought this camera. When you remove all the poor reviews related to the lens error this camera would really have an exceptional rating! So if I am careful and can avoid that one problem I should be exceptionally happy ;)"
20120330"
column1909:
Great little camera.A few things I liked:1) Black finish with unpolished texture to entire casing (gives it a rough, durable-feeling, unslippery grip to it) - kinda manly, too!2) Long battery life - I took it on a ski trip and it lasted me about three days of frequent shooting (HD video-shooting will definitely zap the battery a little faster)3) Cool picture-taking functions: e.g. function to stitch pictures together for a panoramic photo like city skylines, color-isolation like B&W photo of a woman with only red for the color of her dress, and too many more to mention but those are two I really had a chance to play with.4) Options for fine-tuning your photos and details: e.g. light-setting whether in dim-lit settings, bright sunny outdoors, cloudy day, or under fluorescent, etc.5) 1080P videos with really good stabilization.  I've tested the slo-mo function and that was really cool, too.6) Size: this camera was quite slim and fits in pocket nicely7) Price: Bought it for 149 from AMZNCONS:Well, there wasn't any, really.  I was so tempted to purchase the S90 mainly because I heard it takes closer to DSLR quality photos, but I'm satisfied with my Elph300 purchase mainly because of size and price factors.  Plus, the Elph300 received quite a lot of good reviews and has been in many hands that will vouch for it.If I had to list some CONS, I'd probably say1) It didn't include an HDMI cable - since camera takes full 1080p, it would have been great to actually see this quality displayed on a TV screen2) On my ski trip, the camera fogged up on me most of the time, but I don't think that would have been avoided with any camera due to the quick change in temperature causing humidity to fog up the insides of the camera.All in all, great purchase!  Can't go wrong at that price point.  Really good bang for the buck.  I'd highly recommend it.  Happy Shooting, everyone!"
20120329"
column1911: Who knew a p&s could be so spectacular?
column1912:
I love this little camera. I was in the market for a point and shoot I could carry around in my purse for just taking photos, since I don't carry my high-end DSLR around. I'm a Canon fan-kid all the way, however I bought a Nikon p&s prior to this one. I returned it the next day and bought this one without a second thought. Canon always delivers the best, and this is the BEST point and shoot camera I've ever used, especially for the price. I'm very picky when it comes to quality, I have no complaints with this camera. It has fun effects to play around with, too. I don't think I'll ever regret this purchase, and you won't, either!"
20120329"
column1914: Best point and shoot for the price
column1915:
I bought this camera because we were going to go on vacation and I wanted to have nice pictures. This camera did not disappoint, it is very small and takes wonderful pictures. I don't like to record much videos so I pretty much ignored that part when purchasing this camera. But once I got my hands on it and started recording things I was blown away by the quality. It has a wonderful image stabilization that will make your pictures and videos much less shaky. The video is also in 1080p so once you move the file over into your computer and watch it, it looks amazing. I recommend this camera to anyone just looking for a good point and shoot, but I would recommend you also buy at least a 16GB sd card."
20120326"
column1918:
This camera appears to have been discontinued by Canon. The small size of this camera belies the quality and many options available in this very small and light package. Think of it as the smaller version of the S-95 model, one I had for a while recently.The features of this camera are many, most of them  available through the menu, which is a little tedious, but thorough.The colors are very good, you can easily get  a good quality 8x10, as long as it's well-lit and well exposed.I have not used the video feature in the camera yet, but it has a slow-motion option, something not usually seen in cameras in this price range.Hurry and get this model, before it's all gone from the store shelves. If that happens, get a used model in good condition."
20120324"
column1921:
The is definitely a fun an easy to go anywhere camera. How small it is this camera amazes me for the great pictures it takes. Very happy getting this camera and would recommend to buying it because this camera does hold up to its repetitation."
20120323"
column1924:
Absolutely love this camera. The pictures it takes are just amazing and the HD recording is unreal for the size of this camera. Would highly recommend this camera to anyone that needs a nice small camera to take amazing photos."
20120322"
column1927:
Pros:  This camera performs better than my Panasonic ZS5 in low light indoor conditions, but that's where it's benefits end.Cons:  Lots of blurry and not sharp pictures in normal light situations  - where you would think camera should perform 'great'.  Also, it's auto focus is the worst: you might want to take a picture of a walking person or moving object, but it will focus on a fence, you will want to take a picture of a building - but it will focus on a branch of a nearby tree. You can tweak the settings, force infinity mode - but nonetheless, after my smart Panny the performance is extremely frustrating (keep in mind that they are selling for almost the same price nowadays).  Macro shots - look decent, but the ones coming out of Panny still have more details and are more sharp.I also feel that there is a lack of scene settings: they have added some 'extra' modes - like miniature effect and fisheye - but i really think it's pure BS - wish they have concentrated on features that are truly usable.After playing with this cam and comparing pictures to my old one, i'm returning this one - dont want to wait until it becomes totally unusable."
20120321"
column1929: Kind of regret getting this camera.
column1930:
I do like this particular camera for its asthetics and HD video capability. I've owned it for a few months now and it REALLY doesn't do a good job for what I need it for. I take mostly close up photos against a white background and some minor background lighting. This camera cannot handle macro mode very well. More times than not, the photo ends up blurry. It also likes to not use the flash in situations that probably call for it. There is no way to force the flash that I can see. Its too bad when you have just enough light for the camera to think it doesn't need a flash, but you feel it needs one. Ultimately the photo suffers. And speaking of the photos. There is something very wonky with the color profile. When I adjust the tone, brightness and contrast of the photo in photoshop it always pushes the photo into a darker range and the colors are always a little bit off of what they should be. Its not a horrible camera. I'm sure it works much better doing outdoor photos in daylight, or photos from several feet away. Its just horrible for close up photos with indoor lighting (even in macro mode). HD video and slow motion are really nice though!"
20120320"
column1933:
I've been using the camera for a while now and have not had any issues. It is easy to use and takes good pictures. I do recommend it."

I upgraded to this camera from an older Canon and It works really well. It works so well that I bought one for my girlfriend too after I tried mine."

Great camera for the price!  Lightweight, compact, portable, and everything I want in a small, simple camera to take camping, concerts, and for just about whatever.  I highly recommend it!"
20120316"
column1945:
I am very disappointed in this camera.  I bought it because I have had good experiences with Canon cameras in the past, and because it is small and lightweight, and therefore, seemed like an ideal travel companion.  But it CANNOT handle bright light.  I tried every possible setting, and still, bright light shows up as white, and the rest of the picture is blurred or colors are all distorted.  One good thing is the video setting - it shoots nice videos.  But again, the bright light issue 'overshadows' all the pros for me."
20120315"
column1948:
I love canon products and refuse to buy anything different because they are so durable. however, the quality of the picture is not QUITE what I had hoped... some pictures turn out blurry. this also may be user error of course :)"

column1950: Canon PowerShot ELPH 300 HS 12.1 MP CMOS Digital Camera with Full 1080p HD Video (Silver)
column1951:
This was a gift for my grand daughter. It is a great camera, it was easy for her to master in a few hour. My order was process promptly. Thanks for your attention to details."
20120315"
column1954:
Camera is compact and light.  Very easy to learn to use and takes great pictures.  Great quality for the dollars spent."
20120314"
column1957:
If you need a camera to augment a more prosumer-type camera, this camera is small enough to fill the bill. The only cons, IMHO, were lack of TTL and flash placement (I personally prefer pop-up flash - finger can block flash accidentally)."
20120314"
column1960:
I was looking to replace my little point and shoot camera that I have had for years and years. I trust Canon the most for point and shoots and based on the reviews of this one decided to pick the Elph 300. I also use a Nikon D60 and wanted something that had excellent picture quality so I would not have to lug around my Nikon for quick shots. This camera is definitely it. It is so small! I'd say it is just a little bigger than a credit card. It is very light weight. The body has a sand paper like texture to it which makes it easier to grip. The view screen is very nice. I like the different ways you can customize your settings. It's pretty standard. It has tons of effects, if you like that sort of thing, like fisheye, toy cam, color swap, color accent, b&w, etc. As well as, various modes of shooting in different conditions. To access the effects takes a second. It takes great pictures! Really really great pictures! I have been playing around with it since I got it and I am pleasantly surprised every time. So far, I have yet to find a condition where the camera didn't take a great photo. I highly recommend this camera!"
20120313"
column1963:
You won't be disappointed in this one! For a point and shoot camera, I found that the Canon PS Elph 300 lived up expectation and more. I just used it last week for my brother's girlfriend st. patty's day run in kansas city and the shots I got were phenomenal. Even the video I captured was awesome. I can't complain really. Setting the software up with my macbook was a breeze. Go ahead and pick one up. You wont regret it."
20120313"
column1966:
Unit seemed too small in my hands, you have to be careful or you cover the flash.  Takes shots way too slowly I felt like I would miss too many pics."
20120313"
column1968: Compact, Clear pictures, nice video, good manual functions
column1969: I bought this camera so i could have something to carry in my pocket on hikes and skateboarding and just whenever.  The quality of the picture is really good for a compact camera and the HD video is very clear.  The camera has a good amount of manual functions which I like to play with but also the auto does a good job of creating a quality image.  I also like the grippy texture on the outside, it makes it easier to handle.  I haven't owned it for long so I can't say anything about the durability but definitely a nice camera. I initially had issues with the video not saving right, so make sure you have an SD card class 6 or higher for the HD video and that you format the card (settings then format on camera).  The only downfall is the very wild angle lens.  I like the wide andle for some shots but sometimes it makes close up images a little weird (people have big heads and little feet)  This is not usually a problem and can provide cool effects and widen the shot which is good for indoors.  However, if your shooting outdoors i feel it limits some shots, for the most part you can solve this problem by zooming in a little.overall great camera for the value"
